member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.CanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could be null sometimes, so the check for null is necessary before its usage.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.NotNullAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked element could never be null.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.ItemNotNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be appplied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can never be null.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.ItemCanBeNullAttribute
member.summary: Can be appplied to symbols of types derived from IEnumerable as well as to symbols of Task and Lazy classes to indicate that the value of a collection item, of the Task.Result property or of the Lazy.Value property can be null.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the marked method builds string by format pattern and (optional) arguments. Parameter, which contains format string, should be given in constructor. The format string should be in -like form.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Annotations.StringFormatMethodAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.param: Specifies which parameter of an annotated method should be treated as format-string

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.ValueProviderAttribute
member.summary: For a parameter that is expected to be one of the limited set of values. Specify fields of which type should be used as values for this parameter.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.InvokerParameterNameAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the function argument should be string literal and match one of the parameters of the caller function. For example, ReSharper annotates the parameter of .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed.
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally (throws or terminates the process).
Value canbenull is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon. There is no notion of order rows, all rows are checked for applicability and applied per each program state tracked by R# analysis.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("=> true, result: notnull; => false, result: null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.LocalizationRequiredAttribute

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.CannotApplyEqualityOperatorAttribute

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.UsedImplicitlyAttribute

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.InstantHandleAttribute
member.summary: Tells code analysis engine if the parameter is completely handled when the invoked method is on stack. If the parameter is a delegate, indicates that delegate is executed while the method is executed. If the parameter is an enumerable, indicates that it is enumerated while the method is executed.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.PureAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method does not make any observable state changes. The same as System.Diagnostics.Contracts.PureAttribute.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.MustUseReturnValueAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the return value of method invocation must be used.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.ProvidesContextAttribute
member.summary: Indicates the type member or parameter of some type, that should be used instead of all other ways to get the value that type. This annotation is useful when you have some "context" value evaluated and stored somewhere, meaning that all other ways to get this value must be consolidated with existing one.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.PathReferenceAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a parameter is a path to a file or a folder within a web project. Path can be relative or absolute, starting from web root (~).

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.SourceTemplateAttribute
member.summary: An extension method marked with this attribute is processed by ReSharper code completion as a 'Source Template'. When extension method is completed over some expression, it's source code is automatically expanded like a template at call site.
member.remarks: Template method body can contain valid source code and/or special comments starting with '$'. Text inside these comments is added as source code when the template is applied. Template parameters can be used either as additional method parameters or as identifiers wrapped in two '$' signs. Use the attribute to specify macros for parameters.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Annotations.MacroAttribute
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro for a parameter of a source template.
member.remarks: You can apply the attribute on the whole method or on any of its additional parameters. The macro expression is defined in the property. When applied on a method, the target template parameter is defined in the property. To apply the macro silently for the parameter, set the property value = -1.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Expression
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro that will be executed for a source template parameter when the template is expanded.

members.member:
Allows specifying which occurrence of the target parameter becomes editable when the template is deployed.
If the target parameter is used several times in the template, only one occurrence becomes editable; other occurrences are changed synchronously. To specify the zero-based index of the editable occurrence, use values >= 0. To make the parameter non-editable when the template is expanded, use -1. >

member.name: P:KGySoft.Annotations.MacroAttribute.Target
member.summary: Identifies the target parameter of a source template if the is applied on a template method.

member.summary: Gets or sets the value associated with the specified .
member.returns: The element with the specified .
member.param: The key of the value to get or set. In this dictionary it can be even .
member.exception: The property is retrieved and is not found.

remarks.para: In this dictionary both the and the can be .
If the is not found when a value is being retrieved, is thrown. If the key is not found when a value is being set, the key and value are added.

You can also use this property to add new elements by setting the value of a key that does not exist in the , for example: myDictionary[myNonexistentKey] = myValue; However, if the specified key already exists in the , setting this property overwrites the old value. In contrast, the Add method throws an , when already exists in the collection.
Getting or setting this property approaches an O(1) operation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.Array2D`1
member.summary: Represents a rectangular array, whose indexer access is faster than a regular 2D array. It supports accessing its rows or the whole content as a single dimensional or . Depending on the used platform it supports allocation and casting to .
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the collection.

remarks.para: In .NET Core 2.1/.NET Standard 2.1 and above an instance can be easily turned to a instance (either by cast or by the property).
The actual underlying single dimensional array can be accessed via the property that has an property.

If the current platform supports it, the underlying array might be obtained by using the . Unlike the underlying , the implements the interface. Calling the Dispose method is required if the was not created from an existing instance. Not calling the Dispose method may lead to decreased application performance.

Due to the Dispose method is a non-readonly . It is not recommended to use it as a readonly field; otherwise, accessing its members would make the pre-C# 8.0 compilers to create defensive copies, which leads to a slight performance degradation.
remarks.note: See more details and some examples about KGy SOFT's span-like types at the Remarks section of the type.
Try also online.

The actual underlying single dimensional array can be accessed via the property that has an property.

If the current platform supports it, the underlying array might be obtained by using the . Unlike the underlying , the implements the interface. Calling the Dispose method is required if the was not created from an existing instance. Not calling the Dispose method may lead to decreased application performance.

Due to the Dispose method is a non-readonly . It is not recommended to use it as a readonly field; otherwise, accessing its members would make the pre-C# 8.0 compilers to create defensive copies, which leads to a slight performance degradation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.ArraySection`1
member.summary:
Represents a one dimensional array or a section of an array. This type is very similar to /Memory<T> types but can be used on every platform in the same way, allows span-like operations such as slicing, and it is faster than Memory<T> in most cases. Depending on the used platform it supports allocation.
See the online help for examples.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the collection.

remarks.para: The type is similar to the combination of the type and the .NET Core version of the type.
In .NET Core 2.1/.NET Standard 2.1 and above an instance can be easily turned to a instance (either by cast or by the property), which is much faster than using the Span property of a instance.

If an is created by the constructor with a specified size, then depending on the size and the current platform the underlying array might be obtained by using the . An instance that was instantiated by the self allocating constructor must be released by calling the Release method when it is not used anymore. The type does not implement because releasing is not required when is created from an existing array but not calling it when it would be needed may lead to decreased application performance.

Though is practically immutable (has only fields) it is not marked as readonly, which is needed for the Release method to work properly. As is a non-readonly it is not recommended to use it as a readonly field; otherwise, accessing its members would make the pre-C# 8.0 compilers to create defensive copies, which leads to a slight performance degradation.

list.item: You can always easily reinterpret an instance as a two or three-dimensional array by the AsArray2D and AsArray3D methods without any allocation on the heap.
You can also reinterpret the element type by the Cast method that returns a instance. Casts are also available as two or three-dimensional views by the Cast2D and Cast3D methods.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2
member.summary:
Represents a generic cache. If an item loader is specified, then cache expansion is transparent: the user needs only to read the indexer to retrieve items. When a non-existing key is accessed, then the item is loaded automatically by the loader function that was passed to the constructor. If the cache is full (elements reaches the ) and a new element has to be stored, then the oldest or least recent used element (depends on the value of ) is removed from the cache.
See the online help for a more detailed description.
member.typeparam: Type of the keys stored in the cache.
Type of the values stored in the cache.

remarks.note: To create a thread-safe instance that fits the best for your needs use the members of the class.
remarks.para: type provides a fast-access storage with limited capacity and transparent access. If you need to store items that are expensive to retrieve (for example from a database or remote service) and you don't want to run out of memory because of just storing newer and newer elements without getting rid of old ones, then this type might fit your expectations. Once a value is stored in the cache, its retrieval by using its key is very fast, close to O(1).

A cache store must meet the following three criteria:
Associative accessAccessing elements works the same way as in case of the type. implements both the generic and the non-generic interfaces so can be used similarly as or types.
TransparencyUsers of the cache need only to read the cache by its indexer property. If needed, elements will be automatically loaded on the first access.
Size management type has a , which is the allowed maximal elements count. If the cache is full, the oldest or least recent used element will be automatically removed from the cache (see property).

Since implements interface, Add, Remove, ContainsKey and TryGetValue methods are available for it, and these methods work exactly the same way as in case the type. But using these methods usually are not necessary, unless we want to manually manage cache content or when cache is initialized without an item loader. Normally after cache is instantiated, it is needed to be accessed only by the getter accessor of its indexer.
remarks.note: Serializing a cache instance by implementations involves the serialization of the item loader delegate. To deserialize a cache the assembly of the loader must be accessible. If you need to serialize cache instances try to use static methods as data loaders and avoid using anonymous delegates or lambda expressions, otherwise it is not guaranteed that another implementations or versions of CLR will be able to deserialize data and resolve the compiler-generated members.
.NET Core does not support serializing delegates. If the instance was initialized by a loader delegate it is possible that serialization throws a on some platforms.

member.threadsafety: Members of this type are not safe for multi-threaded operations, though a thread-safe accessor can be obtained for the by the GetThreadSafeAccessor method. To get a thread-safe wrapper for all members use the AsThreadSafe extension method instead. If a instance is wrapped into a instance, then the whole cache will be locked during the time when the item loader delegate is being called. If that is not desirable consider to use the GetThreadSafeAccessor method instead with the default arguments and access the cache only via the returned accessor. To create a thread-safe instance that fits the best for your needs use the members of the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.nullLoader
member.summary:
A loader function that can be used at constructors if you want to manage element additions to the cache manually. If you want to get an element with a non-existing key using this loader, a will be thrown. This field is read-only.
When this field is used as loader function at one of the constructors, the can be used similarly to a : existence of keys should be tested by or methods, and elements should be added by method or by setter of the property. The only difference to a is that is still maintained so when the is full (that is, when equals to ), and a new element is added, then an element will be dropped from the cache depending on the current .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.Capacity
member.summary:
Gets or sets the capacity of the cache. If new value is smaller than elements count (value of the property), then old or least used elements (depending on ) will be removed from .
Default value: 128, if the was initialized without specifying a capacity; otherwise, as it was initialized.

remarks.para: If new value is smaller than elements count, then cost of setting this property is O(n), where n is the difference of before setting the property and the new capacity to set.
If new value is larger than elements count, and returns , then cost of setting this property is O(n), where n is the new capacity.
Otherwise, the cost of setting this property is O(1).

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.Behavior
member.summary: Gets or sets the cache behavior when cache is full and an element has to be removed. The cache is full, when reaches the . Default value: .

remarks.para: When cache is full (that is, when reaches ) and a new element has to be stored, then an element has to be dropped out from the cache. The dropping-out strategy is specified by this property. The suggested behavior depends on cache usage. See possible behaviors at enumeration.
remarks.note: Changing value of this property will not reorganize cache, just switches between the maintaining strategies. Cache order is maintained on accessing a value.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.EnsureCapacity
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether adding the first item to the cache or resetting on a non-empty cache should allocate memory for all cache entries.
Default value: , unless you use the initializer constructor, which initializes this property to .

remarks.para: If is large (10,000 or bigger), and the cache is not likely to be full, the recommended value is .

When is , the full capacity of the inner storage is allocated when the first item is added to the cache. Otherwise, inner storage is allocated dynamically, increasing its size again and again until the preset is reached. When increasing occurs the storage size is increased to a prime number close to the double of the previous storage size. When is , then after the last storage doubling the internally allocated storage can be much bigger than . But setting to this property trims the possibly exceeded size to a prime value close to the actual capacity.
When cache is not empty and is just turned on, the cost of setting this property is O(n), where n is . In any other cases cost of setting this property is O(1).

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.Keys
member.summary: Gets the keys stored in the cache in evaluation order.

remarks.para: The order of the keys in the represents the evaluation order. When the is full, the element with the first key will be dropped.
The returned is not a static copy; instead, the refers back to the keys in the original . Therefore, changes to the continue to be reflected in the .
Retrieving the value of this property is an O(1) operation.
remarks.note: The enumerator of the returned collection does not support the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.Values
member.summary: Gets the values stored in the cache in evaluation order.

remarks.para: The order of the values in the represents the evaluation order. When the is full, the element with the value key will be dropped.
The returned is not a static copy; instead, the refers back to the values in the original . Therefore, changes to the continue to be reflected in the .
Retrieving the value of this property is an O(1) operation.
remarks.note: The enumerator of the returned collection does not support the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.summary: Gets number of elements currently stored in this instance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.DisposeDroppedValues
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether internally dropped values are disposed if they implement .
Default value: .

remarks.para:
If the value of this property is , then a disposable value will be disposed, if
The is full (that is, when equals ), and a new item has to be stored so an element has to be dropped.
is decreased and therefore elements have to be dropped.
The is accessed via an instance and item for the same has been loaded concurrently so all but one loaded elements have to be discarded.
remarks.note: In all cases when values are removed or replaced explicitly by the public members values are not disposed.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.Cache`2.Item(`0)
member.summary: Gets or sets the value associated with the specified . When an element with a non-existing key is read, and an item loader was specified by the appropriate constructor, then the value is retrieved by the specified loader delegate of this instance.
member.param: Key of the element to get or set.
member.returns: The element with the specified .

remarks.para: Getting this property retrieves the needed element, while setting adds a new item (or overwrites an already existing item). If this instance was initialized by a non- item loader, then it is enough to use only the get accessor because that will load elements into the cache by the delegate instance that was passed to the constructor. When the cache was initialized without an item loader, then getting a non-existing key will throw a .

If an item loader was passed to the constructor, then it is transparent whether the returned value of this property was in the cache before retrieving it. To test whether a key exists in the cache, use the ContainsKey method. To retrieve a key only when it already exists in the cache, use the TryGetValue method.
When the is full (that is, when equals to ) and a new item is added, an element (depending on property) will be dropped from the cache.

If is , getting or setting this property approaches an O(1) operation. Otherwise, when the capacity of the inner storage must be increased to accommodate a new element, this property becomes an O(n) operation, where n is .

para.note: You can retrieve a thread-safe accessor by the GetThreadSafeAccessor method.

member.exception: is null.
The property is retrieved, the has been initialized without an item loader and does not exist in the cache.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with default capacity of 128 and no item loader.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.CastArray`2
member.summary: Represents a one dimensional array (or a section of it) where the original element type of is cast to another element type of . Can be helpful on platforms where is not available or wherever you must use arrays that you want to reinterpret. For example, if you want to retrieve only byte arrays from the but you want to reinterpret them as other array types.
member.typeparam: The actual element type of the underlying array.
The reinterpreted element type of the underlying array.

remarks.para: is very similar to a reinterpreted , but as the underlying buffer can only be an array, it can reside on the heap, too (just like ). Actually on platforms where and are available you can use the and properties.
remarks.note: Similarly to , also has its two and three-dimensional counterparts. See the Cast2D/Cast3D methods, and the / types.
remarks.para: Unlike , has no self-allocating constructors. But you can pass an instance to the constructor that allocated a buffer by itself. In such case it's the caller's responsibility to call the Release method in the end to return the possibly rented array to the pool.

Though this type also supports slicing, it requires that the address of the start element (in terms of ) must be aligned to an element in the underlying array of elements. It's not an issue for any start index if the size of is 1 or equal to the size of . Otherwise, the Slice methods may throw an .
remarks.note: .NET Framework 4.x only: When this type is used in a partially trusted domain that does not allow executing unverifiable code, then the indexers and some methods may throw a . You can avoid it by enabling the flag at the security permissions when creating the .
See more details and some examples about KGy SOFT's span-like types at the Remarks section of the type.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.CastArray3D`2
member.summary: Represents a cubic (three-dimensional) array backed by a single-dimensional array of element type where the reinterpreted element type is cast to . It supports accessing its planes as instances, or the whole content as a single dimensional . Depending on the used platform the reinterpreted elements can also be accessed as a .
member.typeparam: The actual element type of the underlying array.
The reinterpreted element type of the underlying array.

remarks.para: In .NET Core 2.1/.NET Standard 2.1 and above a instance can be easily turned to a instance (either by cast or by the property).

The single dimensional buffer can be accessed by the property that returns a structure. The actual underlying single dimensional array can be accessed via its property that returns an structure and has an property.

Unlike , has no self-allocating constructors and it does not implement the interface. But you can pass an instance to the constructor that allocated a buffer by itself. In such case it's the caller's responsibility to call the Release method in the end to return the possibly rented array to the pool.
remarks.note: See more details and some examples about KGy SOFT's span-like types at the Remarks section of the type.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1
member.summary: Implements an where inserting/removing at the beginning/end position are O(1) operations. is fully compatible with but has a better performance in several cases.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the list.

remarks.para: Circularity means a dynamic start/end position in the internal store. If inserting/removing elements is required typically at the first/last position, then using could be a good choice because these operations have an O(1) cost. Inserting/removing at other positions have generally O(n) cost, though these operations are optimized for not moving more than n/2 elements.
is fully compatible with as it implements all the public members of .

can be a good option instead of , too. Generally is considered to be a good choice when elements should be inserted/removed at the middle of the list. However, unless a direct reference is kept to a to be removed or before/after which the new element has to be inserted, then the insert/remove operation will be very slow in , as it has no indexed access, and the node has to be located by iterating the elements. Therefore, in most cases outperforms in most practical cases.

Adding elements to the first/last position are generally O(1) operations. If the capacity needs to be increased to accommodate the new element, adding becomes an O(n) operation, where n is . Though when elements are continuously added to the list, the amortized cost of adding methods (Add, AddLast, AddFirst or Insert at the first/last position) is O(1) due to the low frequency of increasing capacity. For example, when 20 million items are added to a that was created by the default constructor, capacity is increased only 23 times.

Inserting more elements are also optimized. If the length of the is n and the length of the collection to insert is m, then the cost of InsertRange to the first or last position is O(m). When the collection is inserted in the middle of the , the cost is O(Max(n, m)), and in practice no more than n/2 elements are moved in the . In contrast, inserting a collection into the first position of a moves all the already existing elements. And if the collection to insert does not implement , then works with an O(n * m) cost as it will insert the elements one by one, shifting the elements by 1 in every iteration.

provides an O(1) solution also for emptying the collection: the Reset method clears all elements and resets the internal capacity to 0 in one quick step. The effect is the same as calling the Clear and TrimExcess methods in a row but the latter solution has an O(n) cost.

When a list is populated only by the Add method or by the indexer, and then it is never modified, class can have a slightly better performance. Though when the list is enumerated as an implementation (occurs for example, when the list is used in LINQ queries or when used as an instance), then can be a better choice than because the enumerator of class has worse performance when it is boxed into an reference. While the GetEnumerator method of returns a value type enumerator (similarly to the class), when the enumerator is obtained via the interface, the returns a reference type to avoid boxing and to provide a better performance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the actual size of the internal storage of held elements.
member.exception: Capacity is set to a value that is less than .

remarks.para: Capacity is the number of elements that the can store before resizing is required, whereas is the number of elements that are actually in the .

Capacity is always greater than or equal to . If exceeds while adding elements, the capacity is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array before copying the old elements and adding the new elements.

If the capacity is significantly larger than the count and you want to reduce the memory used by the , you can decrease capacity by calling the TrimExcess method or by setting the property explicitly. When the value of is set explicitly, the internal array is also reallocated to accommodate the specified capacity, and all the elements are copied.
Retrieving the value of this property is an O(1) operation; setting the property is an O(n) operation, where n is the number of stored elements.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1.EnsureCapacity(System.Int32)
member.summary: Ensures that the of the is at least the specified .
member.param: The minimum capacity to ensure.
member.returns: The new capacity of the .

remarks.para: If the specified is less than or equal to the current , then the is left unchanged.
If the specified is less than twice of the current , then current is doubled.
If the specified is at least twice of the current , then is set to the specified .
If capacity is changed, then this method is an O(n) operation where n is . If capacity is not changed, then this method is an O(1) operation.

member.exception: must not be negative.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1.TrimExcess
member.summary: Sets the capacity to the actual number of elements in the list, if that number () is less than the 90 percent of .

remarks.para: This method can be used to minimize a collection's memory overhead if no new elements will be added to the collection. The cost of reallocating and copying a large list can be considerable, however, so the TrimExcess method does nothing if the list is at more than 90 percent of capacity. This avoids incurring a large reallocation cost for a relatively small gain.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is .

To reset a list to its initial state, call the Reset method. Calling the Clear and TrimExcess methods has the same effect; however, Reset method is an O(1) operation, while Clear is an O(n) operation. Trimming an empty list sets the capacity of the list to 0.
The capacity can also be set using the property.

member.summary: Adds an to the end of the .
member.param: The item to add to the .

remarks.para: accepts as a valid value for reference and nullable types and allows duplicate elements.
If already equals , the capacity of the list is increased by automatically reallocating the internal array, and the existing elements are copied to the new array before the new element is added.

If is less than , this method is an O(1) operation. If the capacity needs to be increased to accommodate the new element, this method becomes an O(n) operation, where n is . When adding elements continuously, the amortized cost of this method is O(1) due to the low frequency of increasing capacity. For example, when 20 million items are added to a that was created by the default constructor, capacity is increased only 23 times.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1.BinarySearch(`0)
member.summary: Searches the entire sorted list for an element using the default comparer and returns the zero-based index of the element.
member.param: The object to locate. The value can be for reference types.
member.returns: The zero-based index of in the sorted , if is found; otherwise, a negative number that is the bitwise complement of the index of the next element that is larger than item or, if there is no larger element, the bitwise complement of .

remarks.para: If is an , this method uses the EnumComparer<TEnum>.Comparer; otherwise, the default comparer Comparer<T>.Default for type to determine the order of list elements. The Comparer<T>.Default property checks whether type implements the generic interface and uses that implementation, if available. If not, Comparer<T>.Default checks whether type implements the interface. If type does not implement either interface, Comparer<T>.Default throws an .
The list must already be sorted according to the comparer implementation; otherwise, the result is incorrect.
Comparing with any reference type is allowed and does not generate an exception when using the generic interface. When sorting, is considered to be less than any other object.
If the list contains more than one element with the same value, the method returns only one of the occurrences, and it might return any one of the occurrences, not necessarily the first one.

If the list does not contain the specified value, the method returns a negative integer. You can apply the bitwise complement operation (~) to this negative integer to get the index of the first element that is larger than the search value. When inserting the value into the , this index should be used as the insertion point to maintain the sort order.
This method is an O(log n) operation, where n is the number of elements in the range.

member.exception: The default comparer cannot find an implementation of the generic interface or the interface for type .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1.Sort
member.summary: Sorts the elements in the entire using the default comparer.

remarks.para: If is an , this method uses the EnumComparer<TEnum>.Comparer; otherwise, the default comparer Comparer<T>.Default checks whether type implements the generic interface and uses that implementation, if available. If not, Comparer<T>.Default checks whether type implements the interface. If type does not implement either interface, Comparer<T>.Default throws an .
This implementation performs an unstable sort; that is, if two elements are equal, their order might not be preserved. In contrast, a stable sort preserves the order of elements that are equal.
On average, this method is an O(n log n) operation, where n is ; in the worst case it is an O(n ^ 2) operation.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.CircularList`1.GetRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a shallow copy of a range of elements in the source .
member.param: The zero-based index at which the range starts.
The number of elements in the range.
member.returns: A shallow copy of a range of elements in the source .

remarks.para: A shallow copy of a collection of reference types, or a subset of that collection, contains only the references to the elements of the collection. The objects themselves are not copied. The references in the new list point to the same objects as the references in the original list.

A shallow copy of a collection of value types, or a subset of that collection, contains the elements of the collection. However, if the elements of the collection contain references to other objects, those objects are not copied. The references in the elements of the new collection point to the same objects as the references in the elements of the original collection.
In contrast, a deep copy of a collection copies the elements and everything directly or indirectly referenced by the elements.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is count.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.CircularSortedList`2
member.summary:
Represents a dictionary of key/value pairs that are sorted by key based on the associated implementation. The dictionary behaves as list as well, as it has a direct indexed access to the elements through and properties or by the ElementAt method. is fully compatible with , but is generally faster than that.
See the online help for a more detailed description.
member.typeparam: Type of the keys stored in the sorted list.
Type of the values stored in the sorted list.

remarks.para: The generic class is an array of key/value pairs with O(log n) retrieval, where n is the number of elements in the dictionary.

Similarly to , supports efficient indexed retrieval of keys and values through the collections returned by the and properties. It is not necessary to regenerate the lists when the properties are accessed, because the lists are just wrappers for the internal arrays of keys and values.
is implemented as a pair of of key/value pairs, sorted by the key. Each element can be retrieved as a object.

Key objects must be immutable as long as they are used as keys in the . Every key in a must be unique. A key cannot be , but a value can be, if the type of values in the list, , is a reference type, or is a type.

requires a comparer implementation to sort and to perform comparisons. If comparer is not defined when is instantiated by one of the constructors, the comparer will be chosen automatically. Only when targeting the .NET Framework, if is an type, then the comparer will be the EnumComparer<TEnum>.Comparer. Otherwise, the default comparer Comparer<T>.Default will be chosen. The default comparer checks whether the key type implements and uses that implementation, if available. If not, Comparer<T>.Default checks whether the key type implements . If the key type does not implement either interface, you can specify an implementation in a constructor overload that accepts a comparer parameter.

The capacity of a is the number of elements the can hold. As elements are added to a , the capacity is automatically increased as required by reallocating the internal array. The capacity can be decreased by calling TrimExcess or by setting the property explicitly. Decreasing the capacity reallocates memory and copies all the elements in the .

member.example:
implements as well, so it can be indexed directly when cast to or though the property: KeyValuePair<int, string> firstItem = myCircularSortedList.AsList[0]; Setting the IList<T>.Item property or using the IList<T>.Insert method throws a for , as the position of an element cannot be set directly, it always depends on the comparer implementation.
Comparison with SortedList and SortedDictionary classes is similar to the and generic classes. These three classes serve a similar purpose, and all have O(log n) retrieval. Where the three classes differ is in memory use and speed of insertion and removal:
Collection typeBehavior
Store model and memory: Elements are stored in a binary search tree where every node is an instance of a class, which references the left and right child nodes and wraps a of the element to be stored. (A node is similar to instances in a ). This sorted dictionary variant consumes the most memory.
Insertion and removal: These operations have generally O(log n) cost at any position, which is the best of any sorted dictionary variants, though due to the slower navigation among nodes, the better general cost starts to outperform the other sorted dictionaries only in case of many elements (hundreds or thousands of elements).
Populating from sorted data: Adding a new element is always an O(log n) operation. Though when populating from sorted data, the tree always needed to be re-balanced, so it has worse performance than populating from random data.
Enumerating the collection: Considering that navigating among nodes is slower than array access, this sorted dictionary variant has the worst enumeration performance.
Store model and memory: Keys and values are stored in separated arrays, which is the most compact storage form among the sorted dictionaries.
Insertion and removal: Position of the element is searched with binary search in the array, which in an O(log n) operation. Insertion/removal at the last position has a constant additional cost, so inserting/removing at the end has O(log n) cost, otherwise O(n) cost.
Populating from sorted data: Since position of the elements are always checked, adding a new element to the end has always O(log n) cost, though it is faster than in case of a . Though, populating from a reverse ordered data has the worst possible performance, because every already existing element has to be shifted in the underlying arrays.
Enumerating the collection: Really fast, it is actually a traversal of arrays.
Store model and memory: Keys and values are stored in separated instances, which is a wrapper class around an array. This is a minimal overhead compared to the class.
Insertion and removal: When inserting a new element, first of all it is checked, whether it comes to the last or first position. Due to the underlying , inserting at the first/last position are O(1) operations. Removing an element from the last/first position by the Remove method has an O(log n) cost, because the item is found by binary search. However, removing the first or last element by the RemoveAt method is an O(1) operation. When an element is inserted/removed at any other position, it has generally O(n) cost, though the is designed so, that in worst case no more than half of the elements will be moved.
Populating from sorted data: Inserting element to the end or to the first position is O(1) cost, so it is faster than any other sorted dictionary types, even if populating from reverse ordered data.
Enumerating the collection: Really fast, it is actually a traversal of arrays.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.CircularSortedList`2.Capacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the actual size of the internal storage of held elements.
member.exception: Capacity is set to a value that is less than .

remarks.para: Capacity is the number of elements that the can store before resizing is required, whereas is the number of elements that are actually in the .

Capacity is always greater than or equal to . If exceeds while adding elements, the capacity is increased by automatically reallocating the internal before copying the old elements and adding the new elements.

If the capacity is significantly larger than the count and you want to reduce the memory used by the , you can decrease capacity by calling the TrimExcess method or by setting the property explicitly. When the value of is set explicitly, the array in the internal is also reallocated to accommodate the specified capacity, and all the elements are copied.
Retrieving the value of this property is an O(1) operation; setting the property is an O(n) operation, where n is the new capacity.

remarks.para: The order of the keys in the is the same as the order in the .
The returned is not a static copy; instead, the refers back to the keys in the original . Therefore, changes to the continue to be reflected in the returned .

The collection returned by the property provides an efficient way to retrieve keys by index. It is not necessary to regenerate the list when the property is accessed, because the list is just a wrapper for the internal of keys. member.summary: Ensures that the of the is at least the specified .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.CircularSortedList`2.TrimExcess
member.summary: Sets the capacity to the actual number of elements in the , if that number is less than 90 percent of current capacity.

remarks.para: This method can be used to minimize a collection's memory overhead if no new elements will be added to the collection. The cost of reallocating and copying a large can be considerable, however, so the TrimExcess method does nothing if the list is at more than 90 percent of capacity. This avoids incurring a large reallocation cost for a relatively small gain.
This method is an O(n) operation, where n is .

To reset a to its initial state, call the Reset method. Calling the Clear and TrimExcess methods has the same effect; however, Reset method is an O(1) operation, while Clear> is an O(n) operation. Trimming an empty sets the capacity of the list to 0.
The capacity can also be set using the property.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.LockFreeCacheOptions
member.summary:
Represents the options for creating a fast, lock-free, thread safe cache by the ThreadSafeCacheFactory.Create<TKey, TValue> methods.
To see when to use or see the Remarks section of the method.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockFreeCacheOptions.InitialCapacity
member.summary:
Gets or sets the initial capacity of the cache.
Default value: 16.
See also the Remarks section of the property for details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockFreeCacheOptions.ThresholdCapacity
member.summary:
Gets or sets the maximum number of elements, which triggers a merge operation from the underlying dynamic growing storage into the faster read-only storage. Specifies also the number of elements to be kept when older elements are dropped from the cache. The actual maximum number of stored items may be about twice of this value.
Default value: 1024.

remarks.para: The value of the property must be greater than or equal to the value of the property.

When the first element is about to be stored a dynamic storage is allocated that can optimally store about as many elements as specified by the property. When the number of stored elements reaches capacity, then the content of the dynamic storage is copied into a faster read-only storage, and for additional elements a new dynamic storage is allocated with either doubled capacity or the specified , whichever is less.

Once the number of stored elements in the dynamically growing storage reaches , the complete previous content of the faster read-only storage is replaced by the elements in the growing storage. Therefore, when adding new items continuously, the number of stored elements will be between and twice of .

If it cannot be really estimated how many items in the cache will be stored, then you can set the property, which can trigger a merge operation to the faster storage by time, regardless of reaching the required capacity limit.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockFreeCacheOptions.MergeInterval
member.summary:
Gets or sets a time period, which may trigger a merge operation into the faster read-only storage even when no new elements are added. If , then time-based merging is disabled.
Default value: .

remarks.para: Even if this property is set, capacity-based merging works as described in the Remarks section of the property.

Even if this property is set, no extra resources (such as timer) are used. No merging occurs if elements are retrieved from the faster read-only cache. A time-based merging may occur only if the dynamically growing storage is accessed.
Once the stored number of elements reaches the value of this property is ignored.
Depending on the targeted platform it is possible that no time-based merging occurs more often than 15 milliseconds.
remarks.note: Set this property when it is likely that the number of stored elements will not reach the specified capacities (maybe even ) and you still want to make sure that the stored elements are merged into the faster read-only storage even if no newer elements are added.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockFreeCacheOptions.HashingStrategy
member.summary:
Gets or sets the hashing strategy to be used by the cache.
Default value: .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions
member.summary:
Represents the options for creating a thread-safe accessor by the ThreadSafeCacheFactory.Create<TKey, TValue> methods.
To see when to use or see the Remarks section of the method.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions.Capacity
member.summary:
Gets or sets the capacity of the cache to be created. If the cache is full, then the oldest or the least recent used element (depending on the property) will be dropped from the cache.
Default value: 1024.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions.PreallocateCapacity
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether adding the first item to the cache should allocate memory for the full cache . If , then the internal storage is dynamically reallocated while adding new elements until reaching . Set it to if it is almost certain that the cache will be full when using it.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions.Behavior
member.summary: Gets or sets the cache behavior when cache is full and an element has to be removed. The cache is full, when the number of stored items reaches . Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions.DisposeDroppedValues
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether dropped values are disposed if they implement .
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions.ProtectItemLoader
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the item loader delegate that is specified by the ThreadSafeCacheFactory.Create<TKey, TValue> methods should be protected from invoking it concurrently.
Default value: .
member.value: to protect the item loader delegate (it will not be called concurrently); to allow the item loader delegate to be called concurrently.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCacheOptions.Expiration
member.summary:
Gets or sets an expiration time for the values to be stored in the cache. If , then the values will not expire.
Default value: .

remarks.para: Even if this property is , values might be reloaded from time to time because if the cache is full (see ) oldest or least recent used elements (see ) are dropped from the cache.
Depending on the targeted platform it is possible that values will not expire for at least 15 milliseconds.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCollection`1
member.summary:
Provides a simple wrapper for an where all members are thread-safe. This only means that the inner state of the wrapped collection remains always consistent and not that all the multi-threading concerns can be ignored.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.
member.typeparam: The type of the elements in the collection.

example.note: Use this class only if you want to wrap a generic instance to make it thread-safe. If you want to use a thread-safe hash set optimized for concurrent operations consider to use the class instead.
example.para: To avoid confusion, the non-generic interface is not implemented by the class because it uses a different aspect of synchronization.
The GetEnumerator method creates a snapshot of the underlying collection so obtaining the enumerator has an O(n) cost on this class.

para.note: Starting with .NET 4 a sort of concurrent collections appeared. While they provide good scalability for multiple concurrent readers by using separate locks for entries or for a set of entries, in many situations they perform worse than a simple locking collection, especially if the collection to lock uses a fast accessible storage (e.g. an array) internally. It also may worth to mention that some members (such as the Count property) are surprisingly expensive operations on most concurrent collections as they traverse the inner storage and in the meantime they lock all entries while counting the elements. So it always depends on the concrete scenario whether a simple locking collection or a concurrent collection is more beneficial to use.
To use a thread-safe hash set without wrapping any instance consider to use the class instead.

member.summary: Gets the number of elements contained in the .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCollection`1.Lock
member.summary:
Locks the access of the underlying collection from other threads until Unlock is called as many times as this method was called. Needed to be called if multiple calls to the wrapped collection have to be combined without releasing the lock between each calls.
See the Remarks section of the class for details and some examples.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCollection`1.Unlock
member.summary: When called as many times as Lock was called previously, then unlocks the access of the underlying collection so other threads also can access it.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.LockingCollection`1.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an enumerator that iterates through the collection.
member.returns: An enumerator that can be used to iterate through the collection.

remarks.para: The enumeration represents a moment-in-time snapshot of the contents of the . It does not reflect any updates to the collection after GetEnumerator was called. The enumerator is safe to use concurrently with reads from and writes to the collection.
This method has an O(n) cost where n is the number of elements in the collection.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.LockingDictionary`2
member.summary:
Provides a simple wrapper for an where all members are thread-safe. This only means that the inner state of the wrapped dictionary remains always consistent and not that all the multi-threading concerns can be ignored.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.
member.typeparam: The type of the keys in the dictionary.
The type of the values in the dictionary.

example.note: Use this class only if you want to wrap a generic instance to make it thread-safe. If you want to use a thread-safe dictionary optimized for concurrent operations consider to use the class instead.
example.para: To avoid confusion, the non-generic interface is not implemented by the class because it uses a different aspect of synchronization.
The GetEnumerator method and and properties create a snapshot of the underlying collections so obtaining these members have an O(n) cost on this class.

para.note: Starting with .NET 4 a sort of concurrent collections appeared. While they provide good scalability for multiple concurrent readers by using separate locks for entries or for a set of entries, in many situations they perform worse than a simple locking collection, especially if the collection to lock uses a fast accessible storage (e.g. an array) internally. It also may worth to mention that some members (such as the Count property) are surprisingly expensive operations on most concurrent collections as they traverse the inner storage and in the meantime they lock all entries while counting the elements. So it always depends on the concrete scenario whether a simple locking collection or a concurrent collection is more beneficial to use.

list.item: To use a thread-safe dictionary without wrapping any instance consider to use the class instead.

For a use this class only if you want a thread-safe wrapper for all members and if it is not a problem if the cache remains locked during the invocation of the item loader delegate passed to the appropriate constructor. Otherwise, it may worth to use an instead, which can be obtained by the GetThreadSafeAccessor method.
To create a thread-safe instance that fits the best for your needs use the members of the class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.StringKeyedDictionary`1
member.summary: Represents a string keyed dictionary that can be queried also by and (in .NET Core 2.1/.NET Standard 2.1 and above) instances.
member.typeparam: The type of the value.

remarks.para: Being as a regular implementation with string key, the class can be populated by keys and values as any regular dictionary. However, as it implements also the interface, it allows accessing its values by using (supported on every platform) and ReadOnlySpan<char> (in .NET Core 2.1/.NET Standard 2.1 and above) instances.

The class uses a custom hashing, which usually makes it faster than a regular with string key. Without specifying a comparer, the class does not use randomized hashing for keys no longer than 32 characters. If you want to expose a to a public service, then make sure you use it with a randomized hash comparer (e.g. with ).

Depending on the context, the can return either a value type or reference type enumerator. When used in a C# statement directly, the public type is used, which is a value type (this behavior is similar to the regular class). But when the enumerator is obtained via the interface (occurs when using LINQ or extension methods), then the returns a reference type to avoid boxing and to provide a better performance.

To use custom string comparison you can pass a instance to the constructors. It allows string comparisons by string, and ReadOnlySpan<char> instances. By default, the uses case-sensitive ordinal comparison. Please note that when using a non-ordinal comparison, then depending on the targeted platform there might occur new string allocations when using query members with or ReadOnlySpan<char> parameter values. See the properties and the StringSegmentComparer.Create methods of the class for more details.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeCacheFactory
member.summary:
Provides factory methods to create thread-safe cache instances as implementations.
See the Remarks section of the method for details.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeCacheFactory.Create``2(System.Func{``0,``1},System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{``0},KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeCacheOptionsBase)
member.summary: Creates a thread safe cache instance that can be accessed as an instance.
member.typeparam: The type of the key in the cache.
The type of the value in the cache.
member.param: A delegate for loading a value, which is invoked when a key is not present in the cache.
An equality comparer to be used for hashing and comparing keys. If , then a default comparison is used.

The options for creating the cache. If , then a default instance will be used. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: An instance that can be used to read the underlying cache in a thread-safe manner.

remarks.note: If is string and it is safe to use a non-randomized string comparer, then you can pass StringSegmentComparer.Ordinal to the parameter for better performance. Or, you can use StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalRandomized to use a comparer with randomized hash also on platforms where default string hashing is not randomized (e.g. .NET Framework 3.5).
remarks.para: A cache is similar to a dictionary (in terms of using a fast, associative storage) but additionally provides capacity management and transparent access (meaning, all that is needed is to read the indexer of the returned instance, and it is transparent for the consumer whether the returned item was returned from the cache or it was loaded by invoking the specified ).
If is , then a lock-free cache instance will be created as if a was used with its default settings.
In KGy SOFT Core Libraries there are two predefined classes that can be used to create a thread-safe cache instance: and .

list.item: : Use this one if you want the fastest, well scalable solution and it is not a problem that the delegate might be called concurrently, or capacity management is not too strict (when cache is full, about the half of the elements are dropped at once). Though rarely, it may also happen that is invoked multiple times when accessing the same key consecutively and the first call occurred during an internal merge session.

: Use this one if you need strict capacity management, you want to dispose the dropped-out values, you want to ensure that the oldest or least recent used element is dropped in the first place, you want to protect the delegate from calling it concurrently, or if you want to specify an expiration time period for the values. If elements are often dropped, then it also uses less memory than the lock-free implementation. Depending on the configuration the actual type of the returned instance may vary but in all cases an instance of the public type will be wrapped internally.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeDictionary`2
member.summary:
Implements a thread-safe dictionary, which can be a good alternative for where it is not available (.NET Framework 3.5), or where has a poorer performance.
See the online help for a more detailed description.
member.typeparam: Type of the keys stored in the dictionary.
Type of the values stored in the dictionary.

list.item: If you would only use the method, then consider to create a thread safe cache by the instead, which is much faster than both and , and supports capacity management as well.
If you want to wrap any into a thread-safe wrapper without copying the actual items, then you can also use .

remarks.para: The purpose of is similar to but its approach is somewhat different. The uses a group of locks to perform modifications (their amount can be configured or depends on the number of CPU cores); on the other hand, uses two separate internal storage: items with new keys are added to a temporary storage using a single lock, which might regularly be merged into a faster lock-free storage, depending on the value of the property. Once the items are merged, their access (both read and write) becomes lock free. Even deleting and re-adding a value for the same key becomes faster after the key is merged into the lock-free storage. Therefore, is not always a good alternative of . If new keys are continuously added, then always a shared lock is used, in which case might perform better, unless you need to use some members, which are very slow in (see the table below). If the newly added elements are regularly removed, make sure the property is ; otherwise, the already merged keys are not removed from the even if they are deleted or when you call the Clear method. To remove even the merged keys you must call the Reset method, or to remove the deleted keys only you can explicitly call the TrimExcess method.

example.para: This section compares with , demonstrating also some examples with different core counts.

When to use :
If it is known that a fixed set of keys will be used. is fast if the already added keys are updated, or even deleted and re-added with any value. In this case consider to set the to , so it is not checked whether a cleanup should be performed due to many deleted items.
If you access mainly existing keys by the AddOrUpdate methods, which are separate try get/add/update operations at but are optimized at to avoid multiple lookups.
If it is needed to access , enumerate the items or /, or you need to call ToArray, which are particularly slow in case of .
If it is expected that there will be many hash collisions.
If the dictionary is needed to be serialized.

Performance comparison with (default concurrency level depends on ):
Member(s) or operation, concurrency level = 2, concurrency level = 8
CountFastest5.01x slower530.44x slower
TryAdd (10 million new keys, sequential)1.07x slowerFastest1.25x slower
TryAdd (10 million new keys, parallel)1.02x slowerFastest1.53x slower
TryGetValue (no collisions, is int)1.55x slowerFastestFastest
TryGetValue (no collisions, is string)Fastest1.26x slower1.26x slower
TryGetValue (many key collisions)Fastest1.92x slower2.01x slower
Indexer set (sequential, is int)Fastest1.07x slower1.07x slower
Indexer set (parallel, is int)Fastest2.03x slower1.01x slower
TryUpdate (sequential)Fastest1.21x slower1.17x slower
TryUpdate (parallel)Fastest4.02x slower1.27x slower
TryRemove + TryAdd (same key, sequential)Fastest1.12x slower1.16x slower
TryRemove + TryAdd (same key, parallel)Fastest2.53x slower2.43x slower
Enumerating itemsFastest2.87x slower262.45x slower
Enumerating Fastest117.92x slower368.11x slower
ToArray1.69x slowerFastest2.12x slower
AddOrUpdate (random existing keys, sequential)Fastest3.35x slower3.16x slower
AddOrUpdate (random existing keys, parallel)Fastest9.74x slower2.27x slower
GetOrAdd (random existing keys)1.11x slowerFastestFastest
If is string and it is safe to use a non-randomized string comparer, then you can pass StringSegmentComparer.Ordinal to the constructor for even better performance. Or, you can use StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalRandomized to use a comparer with randomized hash also on platforms where default string hashing is not randomized (e.g. .NET Framework 3.5).

Incompatibilities with :
Constructor signatures are different
The and property of return wrappers for the current keys and values (enumerating the same instance again and again may yield different items), whereas returns a snapshot for these properties.
The property of and throw a just like for their owner instance. In contrast, in case of only the dictionary itself throws an exception when accessing the , whereas its keys and values don't.

Incompatibilities with :
Constructor signatures are different, though due to default parameters they are compile-compatible.
The does not have an EnsureCapacity method.
The GetObjectData and OnDeserialization methods are protected rather than public.
The enumerators of the and properties do not support the IEnumerator.Reset method.
The property of and as well as for the itself throws a .

member.summary: Values here are accessed without locking. Once a new key is added, it is never removed anymore even for deleted entries.

member.summary: A temporary storage for new values. It is regularly merged with fixedSizeStorage into a new fixed size instance.

member.summary: Gets the number of elements contained in this .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeDictionary`2.IsEmpty
member.summary: Gets whether this is empty.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeDictionary`2.PreserveMergedKeys
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether keys of entries that have already been merged into the faster lock-free storage are preserved even when their value is removed.
Default value: .

remarks.para: If the possible number of keys in this is known to be a limited value, then this property can be set to , so once the values have been merged into the faster lock-free storage, their entry is not removed anymore even if the corresponding value is deleted. This ensures that removing and re-adding a value with the same key again and again remains a lock-free operation. Do not set this property to , if the number of the possibly added keys is not limited.
This property can be set to even if keys are never removed so it is not checked before a merge operation whether the amount of deleted items exceeds a specific limit.

If this property is , then the already merged keys are not removed even when calling the Clear method. The memory of the deleted entries can be freed by explicitly calling the TrimExcess method, whereas to remove all allocated entries you can call the Reset method.

Even if this property is , the removed keys are not dropped immediately. Unused keys are removed during a merge operation and only when their number exceeds a specific limit. You can call the TrimExcess method to force removing unused keys on demand.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeDictionary`2.MergeInterval
member.summary:
Gets or sets the minimum lifetime for the temporarily created internal locking storage when adding new keys to the .
Default value: 100 milliseconds.

remarks.para: When adding items with new keys, they will be put in a temporary locking storage first. Whenever the locking storage is accessed, it will be checked whether the specified time interval has been expired since its creation. If so, then it will be merged with the previous content of the fast non-locking storage into a new one. If new keys are typically added together, rarely or periodically, then it is recommended to set some small positive value (up to a few seconds).

Even if the value of this property is TimeSpan.Zero, adding new items are not necessarily merged immediately to the fast-accessing storage. Depending on the targeted platform a minimum 15 ms delay is possible. Setting TimeSpan.Zero is not recommended though, unless new items are almost never added at the same time.

When the value of this property is negative (e.g. Timeout.InfiniteTimeSpan), then the locking storage is not merged automatically with the lock-free storage. You still can call the EnsureMerged method to perform a merge explicitly.
This property is ignored if a value is accessed in the fast-accessing storage including removing and adding values of keys that have already been merged to the lock-free storage.
remarks.note: Some operations (such as enumerating the or its and , calling the ToArray or the ICollection.CopyTo implementations) as well as serializing the dictionary may trigger a merging operation regardless the value of this property.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1
member.summary:
Implements a thread-safe hash set, which has similar characteristics to . It can be a good alternative for , , or when one would use a with ignored values.
See the online help for a more detailed description.
member.typeparam: Type of the items stored in the .

remarks.note: If you want to wrap any into a thread-safe wrapper without copying the actual items, then you can also use .
remarks.para: uses a very similar approach to . It uses two separate internal storage: new items are added to a temporary storage using a single lock, which might regularly be merged into a faster lock-free storage, depending on the value of the property. Once the items are merged, their access (both read and write) becomes lock free. Even deleting and re-adding an item becomes faster after it has been merged into the lock-free storage. Therefore, is not always a good alternative of , or even a with ignored values. If new items are continuously added, then always a shared lock is used, in which case might perform better, unless you need to use some members, which are very slow in (see the performance comparison table at the Remarks section of the class). If the newly added elements are regularly removed, make sure the property is ; otherwise, the already merged items are just marked deleted when removed from the or when you call the Clear method. To remove even the merged items you must call the Reset method, or to remove the deleted items only you can explicitly call the TrimExcess method.

example.para: This section contains some comparisons with other thread-safe collections.

When to prefer over :
If you would use only the keys, without any value.
If it is known that a fixed number of items will be used, or Contains will be used much more often than Add, in which case may become mainly lock-free.
If the same set of items are deleted and re-added again and again. In this case consider to set the to , so it is not checked whether a cleanup should be performed due to many deleted items.
If it is needed to access , enumerate the items, or you need to call ToArray, which are particularly slow in case of .
If it is expected that there will be many hash collisions.
If the collection is needed to be serialized.
If is string and it is safe to use a non-randomized string comparer, then you can pass StringSegmentComparer.Ordinal to the constructor for even better performance. Or, you can use StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalRandomized to use a comparer with randomized hash also on platforms where default string hashing is not randomized (e.g. .NET Framework 3.5).

When to prefer over :
If you just need a wrapper for an already existing without copying the actual items.
If you just need a simple thread-safe solution without additional allocations (unless if you enumerate the collection) and it's not a problem if it cannot scale well for high concurrency.

Incompatibilities with :
Some of the constructors have different parameters.
does not implement the interface because most of its members make little sense when the instance is used concurrently.
It has no public CopyTo methods. The ICollection<T>.CopyTo method is implemented explicitly, though it is not recommended to use it because when elements are added or removed during the operation you cannot tell how many elements were actually copied. Use the ToArray method instead, which works in all circumstances.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.fixedSizeStorage
member.summary: Items here are accessed without locking. Once a new item is added, it is never removed anymore even when they are deleted

member.summary: A temporary storage for new values. It is regularly merged with fixedSizeStorage into a new fixed size instance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of elements contained in this .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.IsEmpty
member.summary: Gets whether this is empty.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.PreserveMergedItems
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether items that have already been merged into the faster lock-free storage are preserved even when they are deleted.
Default value: .

remarks.para: If the possible number of items in this is known to be a limited value, then this property can be set to , so once the items have been merged into the faster lock-free storage, their entry is not removed anymore even if they are deleted. This ensures that removing and re-adding an item again and again remains a lock-free operation. Do not set this property to , if the number of the possibly added items is not limited.
This property can be set to even if items are never removed so it is not checked before a merge operation whether the amount of deleted items exceeds a specific limit.

If this property is , then the already merged items are not removed even when calling the Clear method. The memory of the deleted entries can be freed by explicitly calling the TrimExcess method, whereas to remove all allocated entries you can call the Reset method.

Even if this property is , the removed items are not dropped immediately. Unused items are removed during a merge operation and only when their number exceeds a specific limit. You can call the TrimExcess method to force removing unused items on demand.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.MergeInterval
member.summary:
Gets or sets the minimum lifetime for the temporarily created internal locking storage when adding new items to the .
Default value: 100 milliseconds.

remarks.para: When adding new items, they will be put in a temporary locking storage first. Whenever the locking storage is accessed, it will be checked whether the specified time interval has been expired since its creation. If so, then it will be merged with the previous content of the fast non-locking storage into a new one. If new items are typically added together, rarely or periodically, then it is recommended to set some small positive value (up to a few seconds).

Even if the value of this property is TimeSpan.Zero, adding new items are not necessarily merged immediately to the fast-accessing storage. Depending on the targeted platform a minimum 15 ms delay is possible. Setting TimeSpan.Zero is not recommended though, unless new items are almost never added at the same time.

When the value of this property is negative (e.g. Timeout.InfiniteTimeSpan), then the locking storage is not merged automatically with the lock-free storage. You still can call the EnsureMerged method to perform a merge explicitly.
This property is ignored if an item is accessed in the fast-accessing storage including removing and adding items that have already been merged to the lock-free storage.
remarks.note: Some operations (such as enumerating the , calling the ToArray or the ICollection.CopyTo implementations) as well as serialization may trigger a merging operation regardless the value of this property.

member.summary: Checks if the lock free storage is still up-to-date. If returns false, the field must be re-checked. Should be used outside of a lock. If a merge operation is in progress, it blocks the current thread without locking until the merge is finished.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.IsUpToDateInLock(KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet{`0}.FixedSizeStorage)
member.summary: Checks if the lock free storage is still up-to-date. Should be used inside a lock. If returns false, the lock block must be left immediately and the field must be re-checked.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.FixedSizeStorage
member.summary: Represents a lock-free fixed size thread safe collection that supports updating values in a thread-safe manner, though adding new items is not supported. Removing and re-setting items are supported though, which is also thread-safe.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.FixedSizeStorage.Entry.Next
member.summary: Zero-based index of a chained item in the current bucket or -1 if last. In this collection this field is practically read-only. Deleted items are indicated by the field.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.FixedSizeStorage.Entry.IsDeleted
member.summary: Cannot be a bool because there is no Interlocked.Exchange for bool but the size is the same anyway due to the alignment. Not a volatile field because from constructor no volatile write is needed so using Volatile.Read/Write when needed.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.FixedSizeStorage.TryAddInternal(`0,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Tries to insert an item. Returns null if no entry found for item. Adding succeeds only if the item was deleted previously.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.FixedSizeStorage.TryInitialize(KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet{`0}.FixedSizeStorage,KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet{`0}.TempStorage)

member.name: M:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.FixedSizeStorage.GetBucketIndex(System.UInt32)
member.summary: An if in a non-virtual method is still faster than calling an abstract method, a delegate or even a C# 9 function pointer

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.TempStorage
member.summary: When instantiated, always has a preallocated storage. Not thread-safe so the consumer must do the locking when calling the internal members.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.ThreadSafeHashSet`1.TempStorage.Entry.Next
member.summary: Zero-based index of a chained item in the current bucket or -1 if last. Deleted items use negative indices below -1. Last deleted item has index -2.
