member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace contains generic collections. Some of them are fully compatible with already existing collections in the .NET Framework but provide better performance in several cases (such as , or ), while others provide new functionality, such as or .
See also KGySoft.ComponentModel and KGySoft.Collections.ObjectModel namespaces for some further collections such as or .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.CacheBehavior
member.summary: Possible behaviors of when the cache store is full and an element has to be removed.

summary.para: Represents an element removal strategy for a instance, where the oldest (firstly stored) element will be removed when a new element has to be stored and the cache is full (that is, when reaches ).
This is the suggested behavior when loading a non-cached element is very fast, or when firstly added elements are typically not retrieved again, or when cache is never full.
With this strategy element access is slightly faster than in case of because no extra administration is required.
Represents an element removal strategy for a instance, where the least recent used element will be removed when a new element has to be stored and the cache is full (that is, when reaches ).

This is the suggested behavior when loading a non-cached element is slow, the cache is often full, and there are elements that are typically accessed more often than the others. This is the default behavior when a instance is instantiated.
With this strategy element is access is slightly slower than in case of because whenever an element is accessed, it is renewed in the evaluation order. (See also the Touch. method)

member.name: T:KGySoft.Collections.HashingStrategy
member.summary: Represents a hashing strategy for some hash-based dictionaries and caches.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.HashingStrategy.Auto
member.summary: The hashing strategy is determined by the type of the key in the storage. For string keys and sealed classes without an overloaded GetHashCode the hashing strategy will be used, while for any other key types the hashing strategy will be used.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.HashingStrategy.Modulo
member.summary: Represents the modulo division hashing strategy. This is quite robust even for poor GetHashCode implementations but is a bit slower than the bitwise AND hashing strategy.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Collections.HashingStrategy.And
member.summary: Represents the bitwise AND hashing strategy. While the hashing itself is very fast, this solution is quite sensitive for poorer GetHashCode implementations that may cause many key collisions, which may end up in a poorer performance.

member.summary: Removes amount of items from this at the specified , and inserts the specified at the same position. The number of elements in can be different from the amount of removed items.

must not be .

remarks.para: If the length of the is n and the length of the collection to insert is m, then replacement at the first or last position has O(m) cost.
If the elements to remove and to add have the same size, then the cost is O(m) at any position.

If capacity increase is needed (considering actual list size), or when the replacement of different amount of elements to remove and insert is performed in the middle of the , the cost is O(Max(n, m)), and in practice no more than n/2 elements are moved.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.EditableObjectBase
member.summary:
Represents an object with editing capabilities by adding implementation to the class. Starting an edit session saves a snapshot of the stored properties, which can be either applied or reverted. Saving and restoring properties works for properties set through the implementation and the ObservableObjectBase.Set method.
See the online help for the image in the description.

remarks.para: An object derived from is able to save a snapshot of its properties (the ones, which are set through the implementation or the ObservableObjectBase.Set method).
A new snapshot can be saved by the BeginNewEdit method. This can be called by a UI before starting the editing.
Call the CommitLastEdit method to apply the changes since the last BeginNewEdit call.
Call the RevertLastEdit method to discard the changes since the last BeginNewEdit call.

The editing sessions can be nested by calling BeginNewEdit method multiple times. The number of the BeginNewEdit calls without a corresponding CommitLastEdit or RevertLastEdit call is indicated by the property.

By calling the TryCommitAllEdits and TryRevertAllEdits methods all of the previous BeginNewEdit calls can be applied or discarded, respectively. These methods return a bool value indicating whether any action occurred.

para.note: When it is needed to be determined whether a type has editing capabilities use the interface instead the type because other editable types, such as the class are not necessarily derived from the class. See also the class diagram of the business object base classes of the KGySoft.CoreLibraries assembly:

img.alt: Class diagram of business object base classes

remarks.para:
Differences from :
Both and can revert changes; however, the aspects of these classes are different.
An undoable class (which implements or interfaces such as ) is able to undo (or redo) any changes made so far either step-by-step or in a single step.
On the other hand, an editable class (which implements such as ) is able to start editing sessions by saving a snapshot of its current state, which states are committable and revertible.
Undo and editing features are independent from each other and a class is allowed to implement both (like the class).

support:
implements also the System.ComponentModel.IEditableObject interface, which is the standard way in .NET to support editing. Several controls of different UI frameworks automatically call its members if an object, which implements it, is bound to a grid control, for example. However, some frameworks (such as Windows Forms) do not always call the begin/end operations the same times, which can cause problems. To handle this, you can override the property in your class to adjust the editing behavior via the interface. If not overridden, the returns , which works in most cases.
This is how the members are mapped in the class:
IEditableObject.BeginEdit:
If returns , then the call is ignored.
If returns , then BeginNewEdit is called only if returns 0; otherwise, the call is ignored.
If returns , then BeginNewEdit is called.
IEditableObject.EndEdit:
If returns , then the call is ignored.
If returns , then TryCommitAllEdits is called.
If returns , then CommitLastEdit is called.
IEditableObject.CancelEdit:
If returns , then the call is ignored.
If returns , then TryRevertAllEdits is called.
If returns , then RevertLastEdit is called.
remarks.note: For an example see the Remarks section of the class. The same applies also for the class in terms of implementation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ModelBase
member.summary:
Provides a base object for model classes or business objects, which can validate their state, have undo/redo capability and can support committable/revertible editing.
See the online help for the image in the description.

remarks.note: This class unifies the capabilities of , and classes. If you don't need all of these features you can pick one of these classes as a base class for your business objects. If you need none of these features but only raising events about property changes you can use the or classes. See also the class diagram of the business object base classes of the KGySoft.CoreLibraries assembly:

img.alt: Class diagram of business object base classes

remarks.para:
Differences from :
When deriving from , overriding DoValidation method is not mandatory. By default, DoValidation returns an empty instance.
See the Remarks section of the class for an example about how to validate properties by overriding the DoValidation method.
The implements the and interfaces to support undo/redo functionality.
See the Remarks section of the class for details about the undo/redo feature. The same applies also for the class.
The implements the and interfaces to support object editing.
See the Remarks section of the class for details about object editing. The same applies also for the class.
Though undo/redo and object editing are independent features, the undo history is cleared when an editing session is reverted by the RevertLastEdit or TryRevertAllEdits methods to avoid confusion.

note.para: See the Remarks section of the class for an example about how to define properties in a derived class.
See the Remarks section of the class for an example about how to validate properties in a derived class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ObservableObjectBase
member.summary: Provides a base class for component model classes, which can notify their consumer about property changes.

remarks.para: Implementers can use the Get and Set methods in the property accessors to manage event raising automatically.
Consumers can subscribe the event to get notification about the property changes.

Accessing properties can be fine tuned by overriding the CanGetProperty and CanSetProperty methods. By default they allow accessing the instance properties in the implementer class. Do not use CanGetProperty and CanSetProperty methods for property validation. To be able to validate property values consider to use the or classes.

member.name: E:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ObservableObjectBase.PropertyChanged
member.summary: Occurs when a property value changed. The actual type of the event argument is .

remarks.note: The event uses the delegate in order to consumers, which rely on the conventional property changed notifications can use it in a compatible way. To get the old and new values in an event handler you can cast the argument to or call the TryGetOldPropertyValue and TryGetNewPropertyValue extension methods on it.

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ObservableObjectBase.MissingProperty
member.summary: Represents the value of a missing property value. Can be returned in by the event if the stored value of the property has just been created and had no previous value, or when a property has been removed from the inner storage.

remarks.note: Reading the property when it has no value may return a default value or can cause to recreate a value.

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ObservableObjectBase.IsModified
member.summary: Gets whether this instance has been modified. Modified state can be set by the SetModified method.

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ObservableObjectBase.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets whether this instance has already been disposed.

remarks.para: Properties accessed by the Get<T> and Set methods throw an when this property returns (but see also the property).
If the method is overridden and you need to dispose properties accessed by the Get<T> and Set methods check this property first to prevent the .
remarks.note: The change of this property is not observable. When an instance is disposed all subscribers of the event are removed.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.PersistableObjectBase
member.summary:
Provides a base class for component model classes, which provide a public access to their internal property storage located in the base class by implementing also the interface.
For details see the Remarks section.

remarks.para: The class should be cast to to access the property storage and allow to manipulate the properties by name. All of the actually stored values can be read and restored by the GetProperties and SetProperties methods.
The also provides some concurrent-proof operations if the instance is accessed from multiple threads. See the TryGetPropertyValue, GetPropertyOrDefault and TryReplaceProperty methods.
remarks.note: For an example see the Remarks section of the class. The same applies also for the class in terms of implementation.

member.summary: Applying 1 undo/redo step and raising Can... events if necessary.
Applying all undo/redo steps.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.UndoableObjectBase
member.summary:
Represents an object with step-by-step undo/redo capabilities by adding implementation to the class. Undoing and redoing works for properties set through the implementation and the ObservableObjectBase.Set method.
See the online help for the image in the description.

remarks.para: An object derived from continuously tracks the property changes of properties, which are set through the implementation and the ObservableObjectBase.Set method. When it is needed to be determined whether a type has undo/redo capability use the or interfaces instead the type because other undoable types, such as the class are not necessarily derived from the class. See also the class diagram of the business object base classes of the KGySoft.CoreLibraries assembly:

Differences from :
Both and can revert changes; however, the aspects of these classes are different.
An undoable class (which implements or interfaces such as ) is able to undo (or redo) any changes made so far either step-by-step or in a single step.
On the other hand, an editable class (which implements such as ) is able to start editing sessions by saving a snapshot of its current state, which states are committable and revertible.
Undo and editing features are independent from each other and a class is allowed to implement both (like the class).

support:
implements also the System.ComponentModel.IRevertibleChangeTracking interface, which is the standard way in .NET to support undoing.
This is how the members are mapped in the class:
IChangeTracking.IsChanged: Returns .
IChangeTracking.AcceptChanges: Calls ClearUndoHistory.
IRevertibleChangeTracking.RejectChanges: Calls UndoAll.

vs. CanUndo:
The property reflects the object's "dirty" state, meaning, it has been changed since the initialization or last save. The modified state can be cleared by the SetModified method. Clearing the modified state (e.g. on saving the object) does not affect the undo capabilities, though.
The property tells whether there are any steps to undo. On saving an object the modified state can be cleared and still there can be undoable steps. And vice versa, undoing all steps will not clear the modified state.
remarks.note: For an example see the Remarks section of the class. The same applies also for the class in terms of implementation.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ValidatingObjectBase
member.summary: Represents an object with validating capabilities by adding implementation to the class.

remarks.para: In a derived class the DoValidation method must be overridden.
Validation is automatically performed when the or property is accessed or when the object is accessed by the standard interface.
returns if does not contain any entries with severity.

Differences between CanGetProperty/CanSetProperty methods and / properties:
When CanGetProperty and CanSetProperty methods return , then an exception will be thrown when the property is get or set via the and members. Do not use these methods for business validation. Instead, they can be used to prevent accessing an unknown property or when a property is tried to be set by a value of invalid type.
On the other hand, and properties can be used to indicate whether an object contains problematic values. For every issue a severity level (see ) and a corresponding message can be assigned. These can be displayed by a UI, for example.

support:
implements also the System.ComponentModel.IDataErrorInfo interface, which is the oldest standard way in .NET to support validation, therefore it is supported by most frameworks. is able to report errors only, so if warnings and validation infos should also be displayed by a UI, then the object should be accessed via the interface.
remarks.note: For another example see the Remarks section of the class. The same applies also for the class regarding the ways of defining properties in a derived class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.FastBindingList`1
member.summary:
Provides a generic list that is able to notify its consumer about changes and supports data binding.
See the online help for a more detailed description.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the list.

remarks.note: is mainly compatible with but has a better performance than that because element lookup in is an O(1) operation. In contrast, element lookup in is an O(n) operation, which makes BindingList<T>.AddNew and BindingList<T>.ListChanged invocation (when an element is changed) slow because they call the Collection{T}.IndexOf method to determine the position of the added or changed element.

example.para: This section provides some examples for feature comparisons with .

Incompatibility with :
is derived from , whereas is derived from , which is derived from . Both types implement the interface though.
BindingList<T>.AddingNew event has type, which uses , whereas in the event has type where TEventArgs is . The main difference between the two event arguments that the latter is generic.
In the property is initialized to if the wrapped list is read-only.
In contrast, in this property is by default.
In the property is initialized to if the wrapped list is read-only, or when is not a value type and has no parameterless constructor. The return value of does not change when event is subscribed and setting does not reset the list.
In contrast, in this property is if is not a primitive type and has no public parameterless constructor. However, return value of BindingList<T>.AllowNew can change when BindingList<T>.AddingNew event is subscribed, and setting the BindingList<T>.AllowNew property resets the list.
Calling AddNew throws if is .
Calling Remove or Clear throws if is .
AddNewCore returns instead of object.
If AddNewCore is called for a type, which cannot be instantiated automatically and the event is not subscribed or returns , then an will be thrown. In contrast, BindingList<T>.AddNewCore can throw an or .
might not work properly if items can change their hash code while they are added to the collection.
Do not store elements in a that may change their hash code while they are added to the collection. Finding such elements may fail even if is . If hash code is derived from some identifier property or field, you can prepare a instance by overriding the AddNewCore method or by subscribing the event to make IBindingList.AddNew implementation work properly.

New features and improvements compared to :
DisposableThe implements the interface. When an instance is disposed, then both incoming and outgoing event subscriptions (self events and event of the elements) are removed. The property determines how to handle the possibly disposable wrapped collection and the items when disposing this instance. After disposing accessing the public members may throw .
Overridable propertiesIn the , , and properties are virtual.
Find supportIn the IBindingList.Find method is supported. In this throws a .
Public members for finding and sorting offers several public Find and ApplySort overloads. RemoveSort method and / properties are also public instead of explicit interface implementations.
New virtual membersAddIndexCore and RemoveIndexCore methods can be overridden to implement IBindingList.AddIndex and IBindingList.RemoveIndex calls.
example.note: does not implement sorting. See the derived class for an implementation with sorting support.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ObservableBindingList`1
member.summary:
Provides a class that combines the features of an and . Unlike , can raise the event also when a property of a contained element changes.
See the online help for a more detailed description.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the collection.

remarks.note: In NET Framework 3.5 this class is not available because it would require to reference System.WindowsBase.dll.
remarks.para: The can be used in any environment where either or (mainly ) types are supported.
If initialized by another or implementations, the will capture and delegate also the events of the inner collections.
If the is initialized by the default constructor it will use a inside.
remarks.note: In an environment, which supports only the or interface but not the other, can be used as a bridge between the two worlds. For example, by passing an to the constructor, it will be able to be accessed as an implementation, and vice versa: by wrapping an instance (such as or ), it can be used as an implementation by the class.

example.para: This section provides some examples for feature comparisons with and .

Differences to the class:
The event is raised also for a sort of additional properties, such as , , , , and .
If implements , then the event can be raised even for property changes of the contained elements. This behavior can be adjusted by the property.
There is no constructor that accepts an instance. Instead, an instance of must be provided.
When the is initialized by another , then the passed instance will be wrapped rather than just copying the elements. Therefore, the changes performed on the will be reflected also in the wrapped list.
In contrast, passing any collection to an will copy the items in a new to be used inside the .
In the OnCollectionChanged method simply raises the event without calling BlockReentrancy, which is rather called explicitly whenever it is needed.
In the Add, Insert, Remove, RemoveAt, Clear and Move methods, and the setter of the Items property can throw a if the wrapped collection is read-only.

Differences to the class:
In case of multiple subscribers of the and events reentrant changes during the event invocation is protected similarly to the class. However, the BlockReentrancy method is not called from the OnListChanged and OnCollectionChanged methods. Instead, it should be called explicitly when raising any or both of these events.
If the initializer collection that is passed to the constructor is an or implementation, then changes performed directly on the wrapped collection are also captured and delegated to the self events.
Accessing the through the , and interfaces are in some aspects different from a regular . Their implementation is as follows:
AddNew:
If returns , then an will be thrown.
Otherwise, if the underlying list implements , then its AddNew implementation will be called.
Otherwise, if is a value type or has a parameterless constructor, then a new item of is created and added to the list.
Otherwise, an will be thrown.
:
Returns if the underlying list implements , and its returns .
Otherwise, returns the lastly set value. Or, if was never set, returns if is a value type or has a parameterless constructor, and the underlying collection is not read-only.
and :
Both return if the underlying list implements , and its / return .
Otherwise, they return the lastly set value. Or, if they were never set, they return if the underlying collection is not read-only.
: returns always .
, and : If the underlying list implements , then the values of the underlying properties are returned; otherwise, they all return .
: If the underlying list implements , then the value of the underlying property is returned; otherwise, returns .
: If the underlying list implements , then the value of the underlying property is returned; otherwise, returns .
Find, ApplySort and RemoveSort: If the underlying list implements , then their underlying implementation is called; otherwise, they all throw .
AddIndex and RemoveIndex: If the underlying list implements , then their underlying implementation is called; otherwise, they do nothing.
EndNew: If the underlying list implements , then the underlying implementation is called; otherwise, commits the last pending new item added by the AddNew method.
CancelNew: If the underlying list implements , then the underlying implementation is called; otherwise, discards the last pending new item added by the AddNew method.
Returns the value of the , which is a settable property. See the property for more details.

support:
The implements the interface. When an instance is disposed, then both incoming and outgoing event subscriptions (self events and event of the elements) are removed. If the wrapped collection passed to the constructor is disposable, then it will also be disposed. After disposing accessing the public members may throw .

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.SortableBindingList`1
member.summary: Provides a sortable generic list that is able to notify its consumer about changes and supports data binding.
member.typeparam: The type of elements in the list.

remarks.note:
Due to performance reasons the class is derived from and not from .
See also the Remarks section of the class for the differences compared to the class.
remarks.para: The class provides a sortable view for the wrapped list specified in the constructor.

To sort the list the ApplySort overloads can be used. As sorting is supported via the standard interface, binding a instance to UI controls (e.g. to a grid) enables sorting automatically in several GUI frameworks.
remarks.note: Sorting does not change the order of the elements in the wrapped underlying collection. When items are added while returns , then new items are added to the end of the underlying list.

Do not store elements in a that may change their hash code while they are added to the collection. Finding such elements may fail even if is . If hash code is derived from some identifier property or field, you can prepare a instance by overriding the AddNewCore method or by subscribing the event to make IBindingList.AddNew implementation work properly.

remarks.para: If equals , then a binary search is performed, in which case the cost of this method is O(log n) where n is the count of elements in the list.
In any other cases a linear search is performed, in which case the cost of this method is O(n).

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.CommandBindingsCollection
member.summary:
Represents a collection of command bindings. If a component or control uses events, then this class can be used to create and hold the event bindings, regardless of any used technology. When this class is disposed, all the internally subscribed events will be released at once. Removed and replaced bindings will also be disposed.
See the Remarks section of the interface for details and examples about commands.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.NullStateUpdater
member.summary: Provides an updater, which does not synchronize command state changes to any command source. Adding this updater to a ensures that no other updater will be called, which are added after the . You can add this updater to a first to disable any other possibly added updater.

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.NullStateUpdater.Updater
member.summary: Gets a instance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.PropertyCommandStateUpdater
member.summary: Provides an updater for the entries, which treats state entries as properties on the command sources. When a state entry in the changes, this updater tries to set the properties of the same name on the bound sources. For example, if a command represents a UI action bound to a menu item or a button (or both), then changing the property changes the Enabled property of the bound sources as well. You can adjust the text, shortcuts, associated image, checked state, etc. of the sources similarly.

remarks.para: A state updater can be added to a binding by the ICommandBinding.AddStateUpdater method.
If a state entry does not represent an existing property on a source, there will no error occur.
The updater considers both properties and reflection instance properties.

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.PropertyCommandStateUpdater.Updater
member.summary: Gets the instance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommand
member.summary:
Represents a command, which can be used to create a binding between an event of one or more sources and zero or more target objects. Can be used easily to bind events with targets with any technology.
See the online help for examples.

remarks.para: Unlike the System.Windows.Input.ICommand type, this represents a stateless command so the implementations are best to be accessed via static members. The command states (such as Enabled or any other status) belong to the created binding represented by the interface and can be accessed by the ICommandBinding.State property, which returns an instance.

To implement a command by using a delegate you can also choose one of the four pairs of predefined classes: /, /, / and / depending on whether the command is parameterized, targets specific objects and behaves differently based on the source's state or event arguments.

A binding can be created by the Commands.CreateBinding methods or by the class. When a binding or a collection of bindings are disposed all the event subscriptions are released, which makes the cleanup really simple.

list.item: For a more detailed step-by-step guide see the Command Binding section at the Project Site.

member.name: M:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommand.Execute(KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandSource,KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandState,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Executes the command invoked by the specified for the specified .
member.param: An object containing information about the source of the command.
An instance containing the state of the current command binding. The state can be changed during the execution.
The target of the execution. Can be if the binding has no targets. If the command binding has multiple targets the Execute method will be invoked multiple times.

The parameter of the command. Can be if the binding has no parameter. Evaluated once per triggering the command. Even if the binding has multiple targets the Execute method is invoked with the same value for each target.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandBinding
member.summary: Represents a binding for a command.

remarks.para: Whereas an is a static logic without state, the created binding is a dynamic entity: it has a state, which can store variable elements (see ), and has sources and targets, which can be added and removed during the lifetime of the binding.

The binding should be disposed when it is not used anymore so it releases the events it used internally. If more bindings are used it is recommended to create them by a instance so when it is disposed it releases all of the added bindings at once.
remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the interface for details and examples about commands.

member.name: E:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandBinding.Executing
member.summary: Occurs when the associated is about to be executed. Command states, including the state still can be adjusted here.

member.name: E:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandBinding.Executed
member.summary: Occurs when the associated has been executed.

member.name: E:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandBinding.Error
member.summary: Occurs when an exception is thrown during the command execution. The property returns the , which is about to be thrown, and the property gets a hint about the source of the error. You can set the property to to suppress the error, but critical exceptions (, ) cannot be handled by this event.

member.summary:
Gets the managed set of states of this instance. Whenever a new source is added or an entry of the returned is changed, and at least one is added to this , then the entries are applied for all of the sources of the binding.
See the Remarks section of the interface for details.
member.value: An instance that represents the managed states of the binding. Can be also used as a dynamic object to set and get state entries as properties.

member.summary: Adds a source to this instance. For static events pass a as . If state updaters were added to the binding by the AddStateUpdater method, then the entries will be applied to the new source. At least one source has to be added to the binding to be able to invoke the underlying .
member.param: The new source to add. Can be a for static events.
The name of the event on the source, which will trigger the underlying .
member.returns: This instance to provide fluent initialization.

member.summary: Adds the target to this instance. The underlying will be invoked for each added target. If no targets are added the command will be invoked with a target.
member.param: The target of the command to add. If the command is a or , then the type of must match TTarget.
member.returns: This instance to provide fluent initialization.

member.summary: Adds a target getter function to this instance. Whenever the underlying executes it will evaluate the specified getter delegate.
member.param: A function, which returns the target when the underlying is executed.
member.returns: This instance to provide fluent initialization.

member.name: M:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandBinding.AddStateUpdater(KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandStateUpdater,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Adds a state updater to the binding. If at least one updater is added, then changing the entries of the property will be applied on all added sources.
See the Remarks section of the interface for details.
member.param: The updater to add.

to update the sources immediately; otherwise, . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: This instance to provide fluent initialization.

member.name: M:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandBinding.WithParameter(System.Func{System.Object})
member.summary: Specifies a callback to obtain the command parameter value for the underlying . It is evaluated once whenever a source event is triggered. If this has multiple targets, the ICommand.Execute method is invoked with the same parameter value for each target.
member.param: A function, which returns the parameter value before the underlying is executed.
member.returns: This instance to provide fluent initialization.

remarks.note: Calling the WithParameter method multiple times on the same instance just overwrites the lastly set callback function. To use more parameter values the function should return a compound type such as an array or tuple.

It is recommended to specify the parameter callback before adding any sources to avoid the possible issues if there is any chance that the source can be triggered before completing the initialization.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandState
member.summary: Represents the states of a command for a specific command binding. When a state value is set (e.g. ) it can be applied for all of the command sources. By default, no application occurs but this can be overridden if an is added to the binding by the ICommandBinding.AddStateUpdater method. For example, if the command sources are UI elements (e.g. a button and a menu item), then the or any arbitrary state (e.g. text, image, shortcut, etc.) can be applied to the sources as properties.

remarks.para: The state, which is also predefined as a property, has a special function. By setting the property the execution of the command can be disabled or enabled.
If a binding has no updaters, then the states are not synchronized back to the sources.

A state updater can be added to a binding by the ICommandBinding.AddStateUpdater method. Multiple updaters can be added so if the first one cannot apply a state entry, then the second one will be used as a fallback and so on.

If state entries represent properties on the source you can add the to the so changing the Enabled, Text, Image, Shortcut, etc. state entries will change the same properties on the command sources as well.
remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the interface for details and examples about commands.

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandState.Enabled
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the command is enabled in the current binding.
Default value: .
member.value: if the command enabled and can be executed; otherwise, .

member.name: P:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandState.AsDynamic
member.summary: Gets the state as a dynamic object so the states can be set by simple property setting syntax.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandStateUpdater
member.summary: Represents an updater for the entries that apply the state values on the command source instances. For example, if the command source is a UI element such as a button or menu item, then the property or any arbitrary state (e.g. text, image, shortcut, etc.) can be applied to the sources.

remarks.para: If a binding has no updaters, then the states are not synchronized back to the sources.

A state updater can be added to a binding by the ICommandBinding.AddStateUpdater method. Multiple updaters can be added so if the first one cannot apply a state entry, then the second one will be used as a fallback and so on.
If state entries represent properties on the source use can add the to the .

If you want to seal the falling back logic of the updaters you can use the after the last updater you want to allow to work. If the is the first added updater, then synchronization of the states will be completely disabled even if other updaters are chained.
remarks.note: See the Remarks section of the interface for details and examples about commands.

member.name: M:KGySoft.ComponentModel.ICommandStateUpdater.TryUpdateState(System.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Tries to apply the specified state on the command source. If returns , then the possible chained other updaters can try to update the state.
member.param: The command source, whose state should be applied.
Name of the state. The default updater handles it as a property on the .
The new value of the state to be applied.
member.returns: if the state was applied successfully; if other possibly chained updaters or the default updater can try to apply the new state.

member.summary: Provides a type converter to convert any to and from base64 encoded or byte array representations.

remarks.note:
This converter uses the class in safe mode internally. The method may throw a if the serialization stream contains any type name to resolve other than the specified in the constructor. So it can be used for types only that do not use any types internally that are not supported natively by the class.
See the Remarks section of the class for the natively supported types.

member.name: T:KGySoft.ComponentModel.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The namespace contains implementations for several types as well as base classes for different kind of business object models (such as the class), and types for command binding, which provide a technology-agnostic approach for binding events to commands (see interface for details and examples).

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumComparer`1
member.summary: Provides an efficient and implementation for types. Can be used for example in , or instances with key, or as a comparer for List<T>.Sort(IComparer<T>) method to sort elements.
member.typeparam: The type of the enumeration. Must be an type.
member.remarks:
Using dictionaries with key and finding elements in an array works without using , too. But unlike or the other possible underlying types, types does not implement the generic and interfaces. This causes that using an as key in a dictionary, for example, can be very ineffective (depends on the used framework, see the note below) due to heavy boxing and unboxing to and from type. This comparer generates the type specific IEqualityComparer<TEnum>.Equals, IEqualityComparer<T>.GetHashCode and IComparer<T>.Compare methods for any type.
The optimization of and instances for types may differ in different target frameworks.
In .NET Framework 3.5 and earlier versions they are not optimized at all.
In .NET 4.0 Framework was optimized for -based s. (Every .NET 4.0 assembly is executed on the latest 4.x runtime though, so this might be relevant only on Windows XP where no newer than the 4.0 runtime can be installed.)
In latest .NET 4.x Framework versions is optimized for any type but is not.
In .NET Core both and are optimized for any types so the performance benefit of using in .NET Core is negligible.
In .NET Standard 2.0 building dynamic assembly is not supported so the .NET Standard 2.0 version falls back to use and classes.
member.example:
Example for initializing of a with :
Dictionary<MyEnum, string> myDict = new Dictionary<MyEnum, string>(EnumComparer<MyEnum>.Comparer);

member.summary: Returns a random can have any value.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer that is greater than or equal to Int32.MinValue and less or equal to Int32.MaxValue.

remarks.para: Similarly to the Next and NextInt32 methods this one returns an value; however, the result can be negative and the maximum possible value can be Int32.MaxValue.
The RandomExtensions.SampleInt32(Random) extension method has the same functionality but it is faster to call this one directly.

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer
member.summary: Represents a high resolution timer that allows precise timing even with sub-milliseconds intervals. The timer executes on a separate high priority thread.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.tickFrequency
member.summary: The number of ticks per one millisecond.

member.name: E:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.Elapsed
member.summary: Occurs when the elapses.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.Interval
member.summary:
Gets or sets the interval, in milliseconds, before event is triggered. Fractional values are allowed, too. When zero, the event is triggered as often as possible.
Default value: 1.0, if initialized by the default constructor; otherwise, as specified in the constructor.
member.value: The interval in milliseconds. For example, 1000 represents one second and 0.001 represents one microsecond.
member.exception: is negative or .

remarks.note: Please note that if is smaller than the value of the property, then the timer may consume much CPU when running.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.IgnoreElapsedThreshold
member.summary:
Gets or sets a threshold value, in milliseconds, to ignore an event (and thus trying to catch up the timer) if the next invoke is late by the given value. Value must not be zero but fractions are allowed.
Default value: +.

remarks.note: If the value of this property is too low (smaller than the execution time of the event), it may cause that the event is never triggered again.

member.exception: is zero or negative or .

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.Enabled
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the event should be triggered.
Default value: .
member.value: if enabled; otherwise, .

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.SpinWaitThreshold
member.summary:
Gets or sets the threshold value, in milliseconds, determining when to transition from sleeping to spinning while waiting for the next event.
Default value: 16.

remarks.note: For advanced users only. When the value of this property is too high, the timer thread may never sleep, causing high CPU usage unnecessarily. When the value is too low, the timer may not be able to achieve high precision. On Windows, Thread.Sleep lasts at least about 15.5 ms by default, unless configured otherwise by WinMM or other means. The default value of this property is adjusted to this behavior.
remarks.para: On non-Windows platforms it's usually safe to lower the value of this property to 2.

On Windows you can use the native timeBeginPeriod Windows API function to set the system timer resolution. Please note though, that this setting may affect the whole system and may increase power consumption. Even when running on Windows 10 20H1 or later, where the function is a process-wide setting rather than a system-wide setting, it may affect the timers of the whole application.

member.exception: is zero or negative.

member.summary: Starts raising the event by enabling the timer.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.Stop
member.summary: Stops raising the event by disabling the timer.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.HiResTimer.ExecuteTimer
member.summary: The timer loop on a dedicated thread. Works like an inverse SpinWait in terms of sleeping/spinning strategy: while SpinWait spins for short periods in the beginning and then starts to sleep, this timer sleeps more often in the beginning (if there is enough time), and starts to spin just before triggering the next event.

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegment
member.summary:
Represents a segment of a string. This type is similar to ReadOnlyMemory<char>/ReadOnlySpan<char> but can be used on all platforms in the same way and is optimized for some dedicated string operations.
To create an instance use the AsSegment extension method overloads or just cast a string instance to .
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.

remarks.para: To create a instance from a string you can use the implicit conversion, or the AsSegment extension methods.
To convert a instance to string use an explicit cast or the ToString method.
remarks.note:
The type may outperform string in scenarios when usual string splitting/trimming operations would allocate long strings.
See a live example with performance test here.
remarks.para:
When targeting older platforms, some members of the type may allocate a new string. The affected members are:
: if comparison is not or .
IndexOf overloads with and parameter: if comparison is not .
LastIndexOf overloads with parameter: affects all comparisons.
On .NET Core 3.0 and newer platforms none of the members above allocate a new string. On .NET Standard 2.1/.NET Core 2.1 and newer platforms the IndexOf overloads are not affected.
As opposed to the class, the default comparison strategy in members is .

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer
member.summary:
Represents a string comparison operation that uses specific case and culture-based or ordinal comparison rules allowing comparing strings by string, and ReadOnlySpan<char> instances.
See the static properties for more details.

remarks.para: This class exists to support lookup operations by and ReadOnlySpan<char> instances for and implementations, such as the class.
Actually you can use this comparer anywhere where you would just use a . Some members may provide bette performance or improved functionality than the regular members, especially on older platforms.
remarks.note: Starting with .NET 9.0 this class implements the interface, supporting both and ReadOnlySpan<char> types. This makes possible to use a regular class with lookup if you initialize it with a instance (see the static members) and use the GetAlternateLookup method, specifying for the TAlternateKey generic argument. Such a method exists for the class, too.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.Ordinal
member.summary:
Gets a object that performs a case-sensitive ordinal string comparison.
The methods of the returned instance can be called with string, and ReadOnlySpan<char> parameter values, which will not allocate new strings on any platform.

remarks.note: The comparer returned by this property does not generate randomized hash codes for strings no longer than 32 characters (and for longer strings it is platform-dependent). Use the property to get a comparer with randomized hash for any lengths on all platforms, or the property to never use randomized hash codes.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase
member.summary:
Gets a object that performs a case-insensitive ordinal string comparison.
The methods of the returned instance can be called with string, and ReadOnlySpan<char> parameter values, which will not allocate new strings on any platform.

remarks.note: The comparer returned by this property does not generate randomized hash codes for strings no longer than 32 characters (and for longer strings it is platform-dependent). Use the property to get a comparer with randomized hash for any lengths on all platforms, or the property to never use randomized hash codes.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.InvariantCulture
member.summary:
Gets a object that performs a case-sensitive string comparison using the word comparison rules of the invariant culture.
Depending on the targeted platform, the method might allocate a new string. In .NET Core 3.0 and above none of the members of the returned will allocate new strings.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.InvariantCultureIgnoreCase
member.summary:
Gets a object that performs a case-insensitive string comparison using the word comparison rules of the invariant culture.
Depending on the targeted platform, the method might allocate a new string. In .NET Core 3.0 and above none of the members of the returned will allocate new strings.

Depending on the targeted platform, the method might allocate a new string. In .NET Core 3.0 and above none of the members of the returned will allocate new strings.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.CurrentCultureIgnoreCase
member.summary:
Gets a object that performs case-insensitive string comparisons using the word comparison rules of the current culture.
Depending on the targeted platform, the method might allocate a new string. In .NET Core 3.0 and above none of the members of the returned will allocate new strings.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalRandomized
member.summary: Gets a object that performs a case-sensitive ordinal string comparison. The returned comparer is functionally equivalent with but it ensures that the hash code of a specific string is stable only within the same process and .

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCaseRandomized
member.summary: Gets a object that performs a case-insensitive ordinal string comparison. The returned comparer is functionally equivalent with but it ensures that the hash code of a specific string is stable only within the same process and .

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalNonRandomized
member.summary: Gets a object that performs a case-sensitive ordinal string comparison. The returned comparer is functionally equivalent with but it ensures that the hash code of a specific string is always the same, regardless of the targeted platform or the length of the string.

remarks.note: Never use this comparer for a collection that can be populated by a publicly available service because it can be a target of hash collision attacks, which may radically degrade the performance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.StringSegmentComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCaseNonRandomized

remarks.note: Never use this comparer for a collection that can be populated by a publicly available service because it can be a target of hash collision attacks, which may radically degrade the performance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ThreadSafeRandom
member.summary: Represents a thread-safe wrapper for random number generators. You can use the static Create methods to create a customized instance or just use the static property for a fast shared instance (which uses internally).

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ThreadSafeRandom.Instance
member.summary: Gets a instance that can be used from any threads concurrently.

remarks.note: This property returns a instance, which generates pseudo random numbers using internally. To produce cryptographically secure random numbers use the SecureRandom.Instance property instead.
Starting with .NET 6.0 the base class has a property, which is accessible also from the class, though it uses a somewhat slower algorithm internally.

member.param: A number used to calculate a starting value for the pseudo-random number sequence.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ThreadSafeRandom.Create(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a instance using the specified value.
member.param: A number used to calculate a starting value for the pseudo-random number sequence.
member.returns: A instance using the specified value.

remarks.para: Make sure the created instance is disposed if it is not used anymore.
remarks.note: Please note that two generated sequences can be different even with the same starting if the created instance is accessed from different threads.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ThreadSafeRandom.Create(System.Func{System.Random})
member.summary: Creates a instance using the specified in each thread the result is accessed from.
member.param: A delegate that will be invoked once in each thread the created instance is used from.
member.returns: A instance using the specified in each thread the result is accessed from.

remarks.para: Make sure the created instance is disposed if it is not used anymore even if the created instances are not disposable.
Disposing the created instance disposes also the instances created by the if the created instances are disposable.
remarks.note: If creates a pseudo random number generator, then in order not to produce the same sequence from the different threads make sure the method creates instances with different seeds.

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The namespace contains general library classes. Some of them are just additions to the standard .NET classes providing better performance, such as the generic and classes. Some others provide new functionality, such as the class. Additionally, contains extensions to numerous types including , , , and many other.

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions
member.summary: Formatting options for the Enum<TEnum>.ToString(TEnum, EnumFormattingOptions, string) method.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions.Auto
member.summary: Provides a similar formatting to the Enum.ToString method, though result is not guaranteed to be exactly the same if there are more defined names for the same value. The produced result will always be parseable by the System.Enum.Parse(Type, string) method as long as used separator is the comma character.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions.NonFlags
member.summary: The value is forced to be treated as a non-flags value. If there is no defined name for the current value, then a number is returned. This result is always parseable by the System.Enum.Parse(Type, string) method.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions.DistinctFlags
member.summary: The result will contain only names of single bit values. Missing names will be substituted by integers. Result will not be parseable by the System.Enum.Parse(Type, string) method if the string contains a non-standalone number. To parse such a result the Enum<TEnum>.Parse and Enum<TEnum>.TryParse overloads can be used.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions.CompoundFlagsOrNumber
member.summary: The result can contain either defined names (including compound ones, which do not represent single bits) or a single numeric value. This behavior is similar to the Enum.ToString method for a Flags and the result is always parseable by the System.Enum.Parse(Type, string) method as long as the separator is the comma character.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions.CompoundFlagsAndNumber
member.summary: The result can contain defined names (including compound ones, which do not represent single bits) and optionally also a numeric value if the result cannot be covered only by names. The result will not be parseable by the System.Enum.Parse(Type, string) method if a number was applied to the names. To parse such a result the Enum<TEnum>.Parse and Enum<TEnum>.TryParse overloads can be used.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.EnumFormattingOptions.Number
member.summary: The result is always a number, even if the value or flags has a named alternative.

member.name: T:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.TypeNameKind
member.summary: Represents name formatting options for the TypeExtensions.GetName methods.

summary.para:
Represents the short name of a without namespaces, eg.:
SomeGenericType`2[String,SomeType]

Differences from Type.Name:
Type.Name does not dump the generic type arguments for constructed generic types.

Represents the long name of a along with namespaces, eg.:
SomeNamespace.SomeGenericType`2[System.String,SomeNamespace.SomeType]
If this name is unique in the loaded assemblies, then the name can be successfully parsed by the Reflector.ResolveType method.

Differences from Type.ToString:
Type.ToString dumps generic argument names for generic type definitions.
Type.ToString returns Type.Name for generic parameter types.
Type.ToString dumps open generic types in a non parseable way.

Represents the full name of a with assembly qualified names for generic arguments of non-core types, eg.:
SomeNamespace.SomeGenericType`2[System.String,[SomeNamespace.SomeType, SomeAssembly, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]]
If this name is unique in the loaded assemblies, then the name can be successfully parsed by the Reflector.ResolveType method.

Differences from Type.FullName:
Type.FullName dumps the assembly names for every generic type argument.
Type.FullName returns for generic parameter types.
Type.FullName does not dump the generic arguments for constructed open generic types.

Represents the full name of a with assembly qualified names for all generic arguments, eg.:
SomeNamespace.SomeGenericType`2[[System.String, mscorlib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089],[SomeNamespace.SomeType, SomeAssembly, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]]
If this name is unique in the loaded assemblies, then the name can be successfully parsed by the Reflector.ResolveType method.

Differences from Type.FullName:
Type.FullName returns for generic parameter types.
Type.FullName does not dump the generic arguments for constructed open generic types.

Represents the assembly qualified name of a omitting assembly names for core types, eg.:
SomeNamespace.SomeGenericType`2[System.String,[SomeNamespace.SomeType, SomeAssembly, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]], SomeAssembly, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null
If all needed assemblies are available, then the name can be successfully parsed by the Reflector.ResolveType method.
If the type does not contain generic parameter types, then the name can be parsed even by the Type.GetType method.

Differences from Type.AssemblyQualifiedName:
Type.AssemblyQualifiedName dumps assembly names even for core library types. For a similar result use the option. This is not needed for Type.GetType though.
Type.AssemblyQualifiedName returns for generic parameter types.
Type.AssemblyQualifiedName returns the name of the generic type definition only for constructed open generic types.

Represents the assembly qualified name of a forcing assembly names for core types, eg.:
SomeNamespace.SomeGenericType`2[[System.String, mscorlib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089],[SomeNamespace.SomeType, SomeAssembly, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null]], SomeAssembly, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null
If all needed assemblies are available, then the name can be successfully parsed by the Reflector.ResolveType method.
If the type does not contain generic parameter types, then the name can be parsed even by the Type.GetType method.

Differences from Type.AssemblyQualifiedName:
Type.AssemblyQualifiedName returns for generic parameter types.
Type.AssemblyQualifiedName returns the name of the generic type definition only for constructed open generic types.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.DictionaryExtensions.AsThreadSafe``2(System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{``0,``1})
member.summary:
Returns a , which provides a thread-safe wrapper for the specified . This only means that if the members are accessed through the returned , then the inner state of the wrapped dictionary remains always consistent and not that all the multi-threading concerns can be ignored.
See the Remarks section of the class for details and some examples.
member.typeparam: The type of the keys in the .
The type of the values in the .
member.param: The dictionary to create a thread-safe wrapper for.
member.returns: A , which provides a thread-safe wrapper for the specified .

remarks.para: To use a thread-safe dictionary without wrapping any instance consider to use the class instead.
For a instance consider to use the GetThreadSafeAccessor method instead, which does not necessarily lock the item loader delegate.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ObjectExtensions.DeepClone``1(``0,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clones an object by deep cloning.
member.typeparam: Type of the object
member.param: The object to clone.
to ignore and implementations as well as serialization constructors and serializing methods; to consider all of these techniques instead of performing a forced field-based serialization.
member.returns: The functionally equivalent clone of the object.

remarks.note: Obsolete Note: This overload uses the internally, which is not always applicable. It is recommended to use the overload instead.
remarks.para: This method makes possible to clone objects even if their type is not marked by the ; however, in such case it is not guaranteed that the result is functionally equivalent to the input object.
remarks.note: In .NET Core there are some types that implement the interface, though they are not serializable. In such cases the cloning attempt typically throws a . To clone such objects the parameter should be .
remarks.para: If is , then it is not guaranteed that the object can be cloned in all circumstances (see the note above).

On the other hand, if is , then it can happen that even singleton types will be deep cloned. The cloning is performed by the class, which supports some singleton types natively (such as and ), which will always be cloned correctly.
In .NET Framework remote objects are cloned in a special way and the result is always a local object. The parameter is ignored for remote objects.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ObjectExtensions.DeepClone``1(``0,System.Func{System.Object,System.Object})
member.summary: Clones an object by deep cloning.
member.typeparam: Type of the object
member.param: The object to clone.

An optional delegate that can be used to customize the cloning of individual instances. If specified, then it is always called with a non- instance. If it returns , then the input object will be cloned by using the default logic. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: The clone of the object.

remarks.para: If is , then this method returns a functionally equivalent clone of the original object.
, and runtime instances are not cloned but their original reference is returned in the result. This can be overridden by handling these types in .

remarks.para: The method firstly tries to use registered direct conversions between source and target types, then attempts to perform the conversion via types and registered s. If these attempts fail, then the registered conversions tried to be used for intermediate steps, if possible. As an ultimate fallback, the type is attempted to be used as intermediate conversion.
New conversions can be registered by the RegisterConversion extension methods.

remarks.note: The registered conversions are tried to be used for intermediate conversion steps if possible. For example, if a conversion is registered from to , then conversions from to becomes automatically available using the type as an intermediate conversion step.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.RandomExtensions.NextObject``1(System.Random,KGySoft.CoreLibraries.GenerateObjectSettings)
member.summary: Returns a random object of type or the default value of if cannot be instantiated with the provided .
member.param: The instance to use.

The settings to use or to use the default settings.
Default value: .
member.returns: An instance of or if the type cannot be instantiated with the provided See the Remarks section for details.
member.exception: is .

para.note: The generated object is not guaranteed to be in a consistent format, especially if property is or property is in .

remarks.para: can be basically any type as long as it has a default constructor or (in case of collections) a constructor with a parameter that can accept a collection.

If is an interface or an abstract class you can set the property to use a random implementation of . If no implementation is found among the loaded assemblies with a proper constructor, then the result will be .
If is a non-sealed class you can set the property to allow to use a random derived class of .

All types, which can be generated by the Next... methods of the class, are supported. Some other types have some special handling for better support:
The same behavior as for strings.
The result will match the following pattern: http://<lowercase word-like string of length between 4 and 10>.<3 lower case letters>
The same behavior as for 32 or 64 bit signed integers, based on the used platform.
The same behavior as for 32 or 64 bit unsigned integers, based on the used platform.
Using its parameterized constructor to create an instance.
A random loaded assembly will be picked.
A random type will be picked from one of the loaded assemblies.
typesA random member will be picked from one of the types of the loaded assemblies.
typesA dynamic method will be created for the specified delegate, which returns random objects both by return value and by the possible out parameters.
The generated delegates do not use the specified instance because in that case the instance could never be reclaimed by the garbage collector. To avoid leaking memory generated delegates use an internal static instance.
remarks.note: See the Examples section of the class for some examples.

member.name: F:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.TypeExtensions.registeredConversions
member.summary: The conversions used in and methods. Main key is the target type, the inner one is the source type. The inner value is practically a stack so always the last item is active. It is a list because any conversion can be removed by the UnregisterConversion method. It is always locked manually but race conditions are practically not expected for it, especially at that deep level.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.TypeExtensions.RegisterTypeConverter``1(System.Type)
member.summary: Registers a type converter for a type.
member.typeparam: The to be registered.
member.param: The to be associated with the new .

remarks.para: After calling this method the TypeDescriptor.GetConverter method will return the converter defined in .
To remove the registered converter and restore the previous one call the UnregisterTypeConverter method.
remarks.note: If you want to permanently set a custom converter for a type, then it is recommended to register it at the start of your application or service. It is also possible to register a converter temporarily, and then restore the previous converter by calling the UnregisterTypeConverter method but then you must make sure there is no running concurrent operation on a different thread that expects to use an other converter for the same type.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.TypeExtensions.UnregisterTypeConverter``1(System.Type)

member.typeparam: The to be unregistered.
member.param: The to be associated with the to unregister.
member.returns: if the type converter was successfully unregistered; if was not registered by the RegisterTypeConverter method.

remarks.para: After calling this method the original type converter will be restored for the specified .
If RegisterTypeConverter was called multiple times for the same and , then this method should be also called the same number of times to restore the original converter.

member.name: M:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.TypeExtensions.RegisterConversion(System.Type,System.Type,KGySoft.CoreLibraries.ConversionAttempt)
member.summary: Registers a from the specified to .
member.param: The source for which the can be called.
The result that produces.
A delegate, which is able to perform the conversion.

remarks.para: After calling this method the Convert/TryConvert extension methods and Parse/TryParse extension methods will be able to use the registered between and .
Calling the RegisterConversion methods for the same source and target types multiple times will override the old registered conversion with the new one.

and can be interface, abstract or even a generic type definition. Preregistered conversions: The registered conversions are tried to be used for intermediate conversion steps if possible. For example, if a conversion is registered from to , then conversions from other convertible types become automatically available using the type as an intermediate conversion step.
The UnregisterConversion methods can be used to remove a registered conversion. Registered conversions can be removed in any order but always the lastly set will be the active one. If you want to permanently set a custom conversion, then it is recommended to register it at the start of your application or service. It is also possible to register a conversion temporarily, and then restore the previous one by calling the UnregisterConversion methods but then you must make sure there is no running concurrent operation on a different thread that suppose to use different conversion for the same type.

member.value:
: Use past date and time values only.
: Use future date and time values only.
: Allow both past and future date and time values.

member.summary:
Gets or sets whether a random implementation should be picked for interfaces and abstract types.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.GenerateObjectSettings.AllowDerivedTypesForNonSealedClasses
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether a random derived type is allowed to be picked for non-sealed classes.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.GenerateObjectSettings.AllowCreateObjectWithoutConstructor
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether non-value type objects are allowed to be created without using the default constructor or (in case of collections) a constructor with a collection parameter.
Default value: .

remarks.note: If the value of this property is , then it cannot be guaranteed that a generated object will be in a consistent state.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.GenerateObjectSettings.SubstitutionForObjectType
member.summary:
Gets or sets the type to be used when a type of has to be generated.
Default value: .
member.value: The to be used to generate instances or for not using a substitution.

remarks.para: Specifying a substitution for the type can be useful for non-generic collections or when it is known that type has to be always replaced by a more specific type.
If this property is not , then whenever an instance of has to be generated the specified type will be used.
The value of this property can be also an interface or abstract type. If property is , then a random implementation of the specified type will be used for every generated instance.
If the value of this property is a non-sealed class and property is , then a random derived type can be used for every generated instance.

member.name: P:KGySoft.CoreLibraries.GenerateObjectSettings.MaxRecursionLevel
member.summary:
Gets or sets the maximum level of allowed recursion when generating objects, which contain members or elements of assignable types from their container types.
Default value: 1.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Diagnostics.Profiler
member.summary:
Provides members for performance monitoring.
See the online help for an example with images.

remarks.para: The class can be used to place measurement sections into the code. The results can be accessed either directly by the GetMeasurementResults method or when the property is , then the results will be dumped into an .XML file into a folder designated by the property.
The profiling can be turned on and off globally by the property.
remarks.note: It is recommended to measure performance with Release builds.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Diagnostics.Profiler.Enabled
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether profiling is enabled.
Default value:

member.name: P:KGySoft.Diagnostics.Profiler.AutoSaveResults
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether results are automatically saved into the directory determined by the property.
Default value:
member.remarks: If the value of this property is , the profiler results are dumped automatically when the current is unloaded. This happens typically when the application is closed.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Diagnostics.Profiler.ProfilerDirectory
member.summary: Gets or sets the output folder of the profiler. When or empty value is assigned, sets the Profiler subdirectory of the executing assembly.

remarks.para: Results are dumped only if property is .
By default, the value of this property is the Profiler subdirectory of the executing assembly. When or empty value is assigned, this default value is reset.
When the directory does not exist, it will be created automatically. The profiler results are dumped when the current is unloaded. This happens typically when the application is closed.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Diagnostics.Profiler.GetMeasurementResults
member.summary: Gets the measurement results so far.
member.returns: The measurement results collected so far.

remarks.para: If is , the measurement results are automatically dumped in XML files on application exit, so accessing this property is required only when measurements are needed to be accessed programmatically.
Getting this property is an O(1) operation. The returned value is a lazy enumerator. If method is called during the enumeration an exception might be thrown.
remarks.note: The enumerator of the returned collection does not support the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.summary: Gets the measurement results of the given so far.
member.param: The category of the measurement results to obtain.
member.returns: The measurement results of the given collected so far.

remarks.para: If is , the measurement results are automatically dumped in XML files on application exit, so accessing this property is required only when measurements are needed to be accessed programmatically.
Getting this property is an O(1) operation. The returned value is a lazy enumerator. If method is called during the enumeration an exception might be thrown.
remarks.note: The enumerator of the returned collection does not support the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.summary: Gets a measurement result as an instance, or , if the measurement result is not found with the given and .

Name of the operation.
member.returns: An instance that contains the measurement results of the required operation, or , if the measurement result is not found with the given and .
member.remarks: Unless is called, there is no need to retrieve the measurement result of the same and again and again because the returned instance reflects the changes of the measurement operation.

member.summary: Dumps the results by the specified by using predefined localizable resources.

to dump the test configuration; otherwise, . This parameter is optional.

to dump also the return value (or the call stack of the thrown exception) of the test cases. Ignored, when the delegate type of the test has a return value and the test case did not throw an exception. This parameter is optional.

remarks.para: If is , then please note that the configuration properties are taken from the instance at the moment the results are dumped. If you change the configuration after retrieving a result the new values will be reflected in the dumped values.

If is , then the lastly returned value will also be dumped. Can be useful for tests, which measure size instead of execution time. In this case it can make sense to set to . If the test case has thrown an exception, then the call stack of the exception will be dumped.
