member.name: T:KGySoft.LanguageSettings
member.summary:
Represents the language settings of the current thread. Use this class also when you want to be notified on language changes and to control the behavior of those instances, which are configured to use centralized settings.
See the online help for examples.

remarks.para: If you use KGySoft.CoreLibraries in a class library, then you do not really need to use this class. Just use the publicly available resources via the class and let the consumers of your library adjusting the language settings by this class in their applications.

If you use KGySoft.CoreLibraries or other class libraries dependent on KGySoft.CoreLibraries in an application, then use this class to set the language of your application and the behavior of centralized resource managers. The KGySoft.CoreLibraries contains one centralized resource manager for the string resources used in the library. Some of these strings can be publicly accessed via the members.

member.name: E:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.FormattingLanguageChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the formatting language (Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentCulture) has been changed by setting the property. Only the subscriptions from the same thread are invoked.
member.remarks: Use this event if you want to be notified of changing the formatting culture of the current thread. When this event is triggered only the subscribers from the thread of the language change are notified.

member.name: E:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.FormattingLanguageChangedGlobal
member.summary: Occurs when the formatting language (Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentCulture) has been changed in any by setting property. The subscribers are invoked from all threads.
member.remarks: The property reflects the formatting culture of the current thread (Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentCulture). This event triggers all subscribers regardless of their source thread in the current . When the event is triggered, the subscribers are invoked in the thread of the changed formatting language. You might want to check if the thread of the invocation is the same as the thread of the subscription. To notify subscribers from the affected thread only use the event instead.

member.name: E:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DisplayLanguageChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the display language (Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture) has been changed by setting the property. Only the subscriptions from the same thread are invoked.
member.remarks: Use this event if you want to be notified of changing the display culture of the current thread. When this event is triggered only the subscribers from the thread of the language change are notified.

member.name: E:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DisplayLanguageChangedGlobal
member.summary: Occurs when the display language (Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture) has been changed in any by setting property. The subscribers are invoked from all threads.
member.remarks: The property reflects the display culture of the current thread (Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture). This event triggers all subscribers regardless of their source thread in the current . When the event is triggered, the subscribers are invoked in the thread of the changed display language. You might want to check if the thread of the invocation is the same as the thread of the subscription. To notify subscribers from the affected thread only use the event instead.

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.FormattingLanguage
member.summary: Gets or sets the formatting language of the current , which is used for formatting and parsing numbers, date and time values, currency, etc. When set, and events are triggered.

remarks.para: Formatting language represents the regional setting of formatting and parsing numbers, date and time values, currency, etc.
Use this property instead of Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentCulture to keep language changes synchronized in your application.
When this property is set, and events are triggered, which makes possible for example refreshing UI components displaying culture-specific formatted values.

member.value: The formatting language of the current . By default equals to the language of formats of system regional settings.
member.exception: is .

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DisplayLanguage
member.summary:
Gets or sets the display language of the current , which is used for looking up localizable resources. When set, and events are triggered.
Default value: The display culture of the operating system.

remarks.para: Display language represents the language of the user interface of the application. This value is used when looking up localizable resources.
Use this property instead of Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture to keep language changes synchronized in your application.
When this property is set, and events are triggered, which makes possible for example to refresh the language of the UI on the fly on language change.

member.exception: is .

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.CaptureSystemLocaleChange
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether changes of system regional settings should be captured. When , is updated on regional changes, and and events are triggered.
Default value: .
member.value: if system regional settings should be captured; otherwise, .

remarks.note: This property is available only for the .NET Framework packages. However, if you use .NET Core 2.1 or newer you can reference the Microsoft.Win32.SystemEvents package to use event.

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersSource
member.summary:
Gets or sets the source, from which the instances of the current application domain should take the resources when their is .
Default value:
member.remarks: Considering that the default value is , all instances, which use property with value, will work fully compatible with the class by default. Therefore, an application, which uses instances with centralized settings (maybe indirectly via class libraries), must opt-in the dynamic behavior of creating .resx resource files on the fly by setting this property either to or .

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersAutoSave
member.summary:
Gets or sets the auto saving options for the instances of the current application domain when their is .
Default value: , ,
member.remarks: Considering that the default value of the property is , none of the , whose property is will auto save their content by default. Therefore, an application, which uses instances with centralized settings (maybe indirectly via class libraries), must opt-in the dynamic behavior of creating .resx resource files on the fly by setting the property either to or .

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersAutoAppend
member.summary:
Gets or sets the auto append options for the instances of the current application domain when their is .
Default value: ,
member.remarks: Considering that the default value of the property is , none of the , whose property is will auto append their content by default. Therefore, an application, which uses instances with centralized settings (maybe indirectly via class libraries), must opt-in the dynamic behavior of creating .resx resource files on the fly by setting the property either to or .

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersResXResourcesDir
member.summary:
Gets or sets the path of the .resx resource files for the instances of the current application domain when their is . If , then even the centralized instances may use individual path settings.
Default value:

remarks.para: Due to compatibility reasons the .resx resources path can be handled individually for all instances, even if their is . To opt-in using a centralized path, set this property to a non- value.
Setting this property to a non- value overwrites the property of all centralized instances so setting it to again will not make them switch back to their previous value.
remarks.note: Changing this property does not trigger any auto save or release operation. To save the possible changes to the original path you need to call the SavePendingResources method before changing this property. After changing this property it is recommended to call the ReleaseAllResources method to drop all possibly loaded/created resources that are related to the original path.

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prefix of an untranslated resource. Used by the instances if or property is configured to use auto appending.
Default value: [T]

member.name: P:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.UnknownResourcePrefix
member.summary:
Gets or sets the prefix of an unknown (non-existing) resource. Used by the instances if or property is configured to add non existing resources to the invariant resource set.
Default value: [U]

member.name: M:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.EnsureResourcesGenerated
member.summary: Ensures that instances with centralized settings load or generate the resource sets for the current . This method affects all instances in the current application domain, whose is .

remarks.note: This method is similar to EnsureInvariantResourcesMerged but it skips merging of resources for already existing resource sets (either in memory or in a loadable file). Use the EnsureInvariantResourcesMerged method to force a new merge even for possibly existing resource sets.
remarks.para: This method makes all centralized instances in the current (a instance uses centralized settings when its is ) load or generate the resource set for the current in memory. This makes possible that for the next auto save event (see also the property) all such instances will have a saved resource set for the current .
You can call also the SavePendingResources method to save the generated resource sets immediately.
When generating resources, the value of the is be respected.
remarks.note: This method has no effect if is , or when there are no append options enabled in the property.

member.name: M:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.EnsureInvariantResourcesMerged
member.summary: Ensures that all invariant resource entries in all instances with centralized settings are merged for the current . This method affects all instances in the current application domain, whose is .

remarks.para: If there are no existing resources for the current yet, then this method is functionally equivalent with the EnsureResourcesGenerated method, though it can be significantly slower than that.
You can call also the SavePendingResources method to save the generated or updated resource sets immediately.
Merging is performed using the rules specified by the property.
remarks.note: This method has no effect if is , or when there are no append options enabled in the property.

member.name: M:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.SavePendingResources(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ensures that instances with centralized settings save all pending changes. This method affects all instances in the current application domain, whose is .
member.param: If set to , the result .resx files can be read by a System.Resources.ResXResourceReader instance and the Visual Studio Resource Editor. If set to , the result .resx files are often shorter, and the values can be deserialized with better accuracy (see the remarks at ), but the result can be read only by the class.

remarks.para: This method forces all instances with centralized settings to save possibly changed or generated resources independently of the value of the property.
If this method is called right after the EnsureResourcesGenerated method, then we can ensure that resource files are generated for the currently set .
remarks.note: This method has no effect if is .

member.name: M:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.SavePendingResources
member.summary: Ensures that instances with centralized settings save all pending changes. This method affects all instances in the current application domain, whose is .

remarks.para: When using this overload, the format of the saved .resx files is determined by the property of each instance. To force a specific format for all instances, use the overload instead.
This method forces all instances with centralized settings to save possibly changed or generated resources independently of the value of the property.
If this method is called right after the EnsureResourcesGenerated method, then we can ensure that resource files are generated for the currently set .
remarks.note: This method has no effect if is .

member.name: M:KGySoft.LanguageSettings.ReleaseAllResources
member.summary: Ensures that instances with centralized settings release all loaded resource sets without saving. This method affects all instances in the current application domain, whose is .

remarks.para: This method forces all instances with centralized settings to drop all currently loaded resource sets.
It can be useful if we saved new .resx files and we want to ensure that all centralized instances reload or regenerate the resource sets when they attempt to access a resource for the next time.
remarks.note: When calling this method all possible unsaved resource changes will be lost.

member.name: T:KGySoft.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The root namespace contains two public classes: the , by which you can configure how the language resources should be handled in your library or application; and the class, which contains some public string resources that can be used in any project.

remarks.para: To see how to configure the language resources of your application see the Remarks section of the class.
To see how to add a dynamic resource manager to your own class library see the Recommended usage for string resources in a class library section in the description of the class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.CreateInstanceAccessor
member.summary:
Provides an efficient way for creating objects via dynamically created delegates.
See the online help for an example.

remarks.para: You can obtain a instance by the static GetAccessor methods. There are two overloads of them: can be used for types with parameterless constructors and for creating value types without a constructor, and the overload is for creating an instance by a specified constructor (with or without parameters).

The method can be used to create an instance of an object in general cases. It can be used even for constructors with parameters passed by reference. To obtain the result of possible / parameters, pass a preallocated array to the method. The parameters passed by reference will be assigned back to the corresponding array elements.

The other non-generic CreateInstance overloads can be used for constructors with no more than four parameters. They provide a better performance than the general method but the result of parameters passed reference will not be assigned back.

If you know the type of the created instance and the parameter types at compile time, then you can use the generic CreateInstance methods for even better performance. These strongly typed methods can be used as long as the constructors to invoke have no more than four parameters. Parameters passed by reference are also supported but only as input parameters as they are not assigned back to the caller.
The first call of these methods is slower because the delegate is generated on the first access, but further calls are much faster.
The already obtained accessors are cached so subsequent GetAccessor calls return the already created accessors unless they were dropped out from the cache, which can store about 8000 elements.
remarks.note: If you want to create an instance just by enlisting the constructor parameters of a rather than specifying a , then you can use the CreateInstance methods in the class, which have some overloads for that purpose.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Reflection.CreateInstanceAccessor.CreateInstance(System.Object[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance by the associated or . For types and parameterless constructors the parameter is omitted.
member.param: The parameters for parameterized constructors.
member.returns: The created instance.

remarks.para: Invoking the constructor for the first time is slower than the System.Reflection.MethodBase.Invoke method but further calls are much faster.
If the constructor has / parameters pass a preallocated array to . The parameters passed by reference will be assigned back to the corresponding array elements.
remarks.note: If the constructor has no more than four parameters, then you can use the generic CreateInstance overloads for better performance if the types are known at compile time.

If the constructor has / or pointer parameters, then the .NET Standard 2.0 version of this method defaults to use regular reflection to be able to assign the parameter values back to the array. To experience the best performance try to target .NET Standard 2.1 or any .NET Framework or .NET Core/.NET platforms instead.

member.overloads: The overload can be used for any number of parameters or for constructors with / parameters. The other non-generic overloads can be used for constructors with no more than four parameters. And if you know the type of the created instance and the parameter types at compile time, then you can use the generic overloads for the best performance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.FieldAccessor
member.summary:
Provides an efficient way for setting and getting field values via dynamically created delegates.
See the online help for an example.

remarks.para: You can obtain a instance by the static GetAccessor method.
The non-generic Get and Set methods can be used to get and set the field in general cases.

If you know the field type at compile time, then you can use the generic GetStaticValue/SetStaticValue methods for static fields. If you know also the instance type, then the GetInstanceValue/SetInstanceValue methods can be used to access instance fields with better performance.
The first call of these methods are slower because the delegates are generated on the first access, but further calls are much faster.
The already obtained accessors are cached so subsequent GetAccessor calls return the already created accessors unless they were dropped out from the cache, which can store about 8000 elements.
remarks.note: If you want to access a field by name rather than by a , then you can use the SetField and GetField methods in the class, which have some overloads with a fieldName parameter.

The generic setter methods of this class in the .NET Standard 2.0 build throw a for read-only and pointer instance fields of value types. Use the non-generic Set method or reference the .NET Standard 2.1 build or any .NET Framework or .NET Core/.NET builds to setting support setting read-only fields by the generic setters.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.MethodAccessor
member.summary:
Provides an efficient way for invoking methods via dynamically created delegates.
See the online help for an example.

remarks.para: You can obtain a instance by the static GetAccessor method.

The method can be used to invoke the method in general cases. It can be used even for methods with parameters passed by reference. To obtain the result of possible / parameters, pass a preallocated array to the method. The parameters passed by reference will be assigned back to the corresponding array elements.

The other non-generic Invoke overloads can be used for methods with no more than four parameters. They provide a better performance than the general method but the result of parameters passed reference will not be assigned back.

If you know the parameter types at compile time (and the return type for function methods), then you can use the InvokeStaticAction/InvokeStaticFunction methods to invoke static methods. If you know also the instance type, then the InvokeInstanceAction/InvokeInstanceFunction methods can be used to invoke instance methods with better performance. These strongly typed methods can be used as long as the methods to invoke have no more than four parameters. Parameters passed by reference are also supported but only as input parameters as they are not assigned back to the caller.
The first call of these methods are slower because the delegates are generated on the first access, but further calls are much faster.
The already obtained accessors are cached so subsequent GetAccessor calls return the already created accessors unless they were dropped out from the cache, which can store about 8000 elements.
remarks.note: If you want to invoke a method by name rather than by a , then you can use the InvokeMethod methods in the class, which have some overloads with a methodName parameter.

The invoker methods of this class in the .NET Standard 2.0 version throw a on attempting to access a -returning method. You need to reference the .NET Standard 2.1 build or any .NET Framework or .NET Core/.NET builds to support methods with -returns.

member.summary: Creates an accessor for a method without caching.
member.param: The method for which the accessor should be retrieved.
member.returns: A instance that can be used to invoke the method.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Reflection.MethodAccessor.Invoke(System.Object,System.Object[])
member.summary: Invokes the method. The return value of methods is always . For static methods the parameter is omitted (can be ).
member.param: The instance that the method belongs to. Can be for static methods.
The parameters to be used for invoking the method. If the method has ref/out parameters the corresponding array elements are assigned back with the results.
member.returns: The return value of the method, or for methods.

remarks.para: Invoking the method for the first time is slower than the System.Reflection.MethodBase.Invoke method but further calls are much faster.
If the method has / parameters pass a preallocated array to . The parameters passed by reference will be assigned back to the corresponding array elements.
remarks.note: If the method has no more than four parameters, then you can use the strongly typed InvokeStaticAction, InvokeStaticFunction, InvokeInstanceAction or InvokeInstanceFunction methods for better performance if the types are known at compile time.

If the method is a non- instance method of a value type or has / or pointer parameters/return value, then the .NET Standard 2.0 version of this method defaults to use regular reflection to preserve possible mutations and be able to assign the parameter values back to the array. To experience the best performance try to target .NET Standard 2.1 or any .NET Framework or .NET Core/.NET platforms instead.

If you know also the instance type, then the InvokeInstanceAction/InvokeInstanceFunction methods can be used for the best performance to invoke instance methods.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.PropertyAccessor
member.summary:
Provides an efficient way for setting and getting property values via dynamically created delegates.
See the online help for an example.

remarks.para: You can obtain a instance by the static GetAccessor method.
The and methods can be used to get or set the property in general cases. These methods can be used for any properties, including indexed ones.
The other non-generic Get and Set overloads can be used for simple properties or for indexers with one index parameter.

If you know the property type at compile time, then you can use the generic GetStaticValue/SetStaticValue methods for static properties. If you know also the instance type (and the index parameter for indexers), then the GetInstanceValue/SetInstanceValue methods can be used to access instance properties with better performance. These generic methods can be used for properties with no more than one index parameter.
The first call of these methods are slower because the delegates are generated on the first access, but further calls are much faster.
The already obtained accessors are cached so subsequent GetAccessor calls return the already created accessors unless they were dropped out from the cache, which can store about 8000 elements.
remarks.note: If you want to access a property by name rather than by a , then you can use the SetProperty and GetProperty methods in the class, which have some overloads with a propertyName parameter.

The getter/setter methods of this class in the .NET Standard 2.0 version throw a for properties. You need to reference the .NET Standard 2.1 build or any .NET Framework or .NET Core/.NET builds to support properties.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Reflection.PropertyAccessor.Set(System.Object,System.Object,System.Object[])
member.summary: Sets the property. For static properties the parameter is omitted (can be ). If the property is not an indexer, then parameter is omitted.
member.param: The instance that the property belongs to. Can be for static properties.
The value to set.
The parameters if the property is an indexer.

remarks.para: Setting the property for the first time is slower than the System.Reflection.PropertyInfo.SetValue method but further calls are much faster.
The method can be use also for properties.
remarks.note: If the property has no more than one index parameters and you know the type of the property at compile time (and also the declaring type for instance properties), then you can use the generic SetStaticValue or SetInstanceValue methods for better performance.

If the property is an instance property of a value type or has a pointer type or pointer index parameter, then the .NET Standard 2.0 version of this method defaults to use regular reflection to preserve mutations. To experience the best performance try to target .NET Standard 2.1 or any .NET Framework or .NET Core/.NET platforms instead.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Reflection.Reflector.MemberOf``1(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{``0}})
member.summary: Gets the returned member of an expression providing a refactoring-safe way for referencing a field, property, constructor or function method.
member.typeparam: Type of the returned member in the expression.
member.param: An expression returning a member.
member.returns: A instance that represents the returned member of the

remarks.para:
Similarly to the operator, which provides a refactoring-safe reference to a , this method provides a non-string access to a field, property, constructor or function method:
MemberInfo ctorList = Reflector.MemberOf(() => new List<int>()); // ConstructorInfo: List<int>().ctor() MemberInfo methodIndexOf = Reflector.MemberOf(() => default(List<int>).IndexOf(default(int))); // MethodInfo: List<int>.IndexOf(int) - works without a reference to a List MemberInfo fieldEmpty = Reflector.MemberOf(() => string.Empty); // FieldInfo: String.Empty MemberInfo propertyLength = Reflector.MemberOf(() => default(string).Length); // PropertyInfo: String.Length - works without a reference to a string
Constant fields cannot be reflected by this method because the C# compiler emits the value of the constant into the expression instead of the access of the constant field.
To reflect an action method, you can use the method.

To reflect methods, you can actually cast the method to a delegate and get its property:
MemberInfo methodIndexOf = ((Action<int>)new List<int>().IndexOf).Method; // MethodInfo: List<int>.IndexOf(int) - a reference to a List is required
Accessing a method by the delegate cast is usually faster than using this method. However, you must have an instance to access instance methods. That means that you cannot use the operator for reference types to access their instance methods. If the constructor of such a type is slow, then using this method can be more effective to access an instance method.

member.exception: is .
does not return a member.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Reflection.Reflector.MemberOf(System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Action})
member.summary: Gets the action method of an expression by a refactoring-safe way.
member.param: An expression accessing an action method.
member.returns: The instance of the .

remarks.para:
Similarly to the operator, which provides a refactoring-safe reference to a , this method provides a non-string access to an action method:
MethodInfo methodAdd = Reflector.MemberOf(() => default(List<int>).Add(default(int))); // MethodInfo: List<int>.Add() - works without a reference to a List
To reflect a function method, constructor, property or a field, you can use the method.

To reflect methods, you can actually cast the method to a delegate and get its property:
MethodInfo methodAdd = ((Action<int>)new List<int>().Add).Method; // MethodInfo: List<int>.Add() - a reference to a List is required
Accessing a method by the delegate cast is usually faster than using this method. However, you must have an instance to access instance methods. That means that you cannot use the operator for reference types to access their instance methods. If the constructor of such a type is slow, then using this method can be more effective to access an instance method.

member.exception: is .
does not access an action method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The namespace contains the static class that provides most of the needed reflection tasks. Additionally, contains several classes derived from that can dynamically reflect objects, their members and type information by on-the-fly generated delegates.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions
member.summary: Options for the MemberAccessor.CreateMethodInvokerAsDynamicMethod method.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions.None
member.summary: No special handling. The dynamic method will have object return value, object instance parameter (for non-constructors) and an object[] parameter for method parameters. Possible ref/out parameters are handled automatically, the results are assigned back to the object array.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions.ExactParameters
member.summary: Does not emit the object[] parameter but the exact number of object parameters (0..4) for method arguments. Also for simple property getters or indexers. Possible ref parameters are handled only as input parameters. Can be used together with .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions.StronglyTyped
member.summary: Must be used with . It uses strongly typed parameters and return type. For value types the instance parameter is passed by reference.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions.TreatAsPropertySetter
member.summary: By default, generates an object value parameter and also an object[] arguments parameter in case of indexers. If is set, then there will be one value parameter first and then the index (if any), which is a reversed order compared to indexer setter methods. If is also set, then value and index (if any) will be strongly typed.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions.TreatCtorAsMethod
member.summary: Treats a ConstructorInfo as a regular method, ie. instead of returning a new object adds the instance parameter and executes the constructor for it.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.DynamicMethodOptions.ReturnNullForVoid
member.summary: Generates object-returning methods with null return value for void methods. Cannot be used with .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.ReflectionWays
member.summary: Represents the possible ways of reflection for the methods of the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.ReflectionWays.Auto
member.summary: Auto decision. In most cases it uses the way.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.ReflectionWays.DynamicDelegate
member.summary: Dynamic delegate way. This option uses cached instances for reflection. In this case first access of a member is slower than accessing it via system reflection but further accesses are much more fast.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.ReflectionWays.SystemReflection
member.summary: Uses the standard system reflection way.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Reflection.ReflectionWays.TypeDescriptor
member.summary: Uses the type descriptor way. If there is no implementation for an instance, then this can be the slowest way as it internally falls back to use system reflection. Not applicable in all cases.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.ResolveAssemblyOptions
member.summary: Provides options for the Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods.

summary.para: Represents no enabled options.

If this flag is enabled, then the Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods try to load the assembly if it is not loaded yet. Otherwise, the assembly is tried to be located among the already loaded assemblies.
Default state at Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods: Enabled

If this flag is enabled, then the Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods allow to return an already loaded assembly of any version, culture and public key token, or, if the assembly is not loaded, this flag allows to load it by partial identity if possible. If this flag is disabled, then the provided assembly information must match (which still can be a partial name).
summary.note: Depending on the type system of the current platform it can happen that a new assembly of an unmatching identity is loaded even if this flag is disabled. In such case the loaded assembly is not returned though.
summary.para: Default state at Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods: Enabled
If this flag is enabled and the assembly cannot be resolved, then a will be thrown from the Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods.
Default state at Reflector.ResolveAssembly methods: Disabled

member.name: T:KGySoft.Reflection.ResolveTypeOptions
member.summary: Provides options for the Reflector.ResolveType methods.

summary.para: Represents no enabled options.

If this flag is enabled, then the Reflector.ResolveType methods try to load the assemblies optionally present in the type name if they are not loaded yet. Otherwise, the assemblies are tried to be located among the already loaded assemblies.
Default state at Reflector.ResolveType methods: Enabled

If this flag is enabled, then the Reflector.ResolveType methods allow to resolve assembly names optionally present in the type name by partial name. If this flag is disabled, then the provided assembly information must match (which still can be partially specified).
If a type name is specified without an assembly, then this flag is ignored (as if the was set).
summary.note: Depending on the type system of the current platform it can happen that new assemblies of unmatching identity are loaded even if this flag is disabled. In such case the loaded assemblies are ignored.

Forwarded types can be loaded even if this flag is disabled but only if the old assembly of the exact identity can be resolved. So for example, to allow a type, which was forwarded from the mscorlib 4.0 assembly, to be resolved by an mscorlib 2.0 identity, this flag should be enabled.
summary.para: Default state at Reflector.ResolveType methods: Enabled

If a type is specified with an assembly name, which cannot be resolved at all, then this flag makes possible to completely ignore the assembly information and that the Reflector.ResolveType methods can return a type by its full name from any loaded assembly.
If a type name is specified without an assembly, then it will be tried to be resolved from the loaded assemblies as if this flag was enabled.
If this flag is enabled, then the flag is ignored.
Default state at Reflector.ResolveType methods: Disabled
If this flag is enabled, then the type name is identified in a case-insensitive manner.
summary.note: Assembly name is always resolved in a case-insensitive manner.
summary.para: Default state at Reflector.ResolveType methods: Disabled
If this flag is enabled and the type cannot be resolved, then a will be thrown from the Reflector.ResolveType methods.
Default state at Reflector.ResolveType methods: Disabled

member.name: P:KGySoft.Res.ReflectionSecuritySettingsConflict
member.summary: This operation is not supported if the executing assembly specifies both the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute and the SecurityRulesAttribute with SecurityRuleSet.Level2 (which is the default if not defined). You can try the following options: - Use the SecurityRulesAttribute with SecurityRuleSet.Level1. This is the recommended solution. - Grant SecurityPermission with the SecurityPermissionFlag.SkipVerification flag when creating the restricted AppDomain. - Use the SecurityRulesAttribute with SkipVerificationInFullTrust = true. If used with SecurityRuleSet.Level2 this will not solve the problem from a partially trusted domain though. - Remove the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute. This will not allow partially trusted callers to use your assembly though.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager
member.summary:
Represents a resource manager that provides convenient access to culture-specific resources at run time. As it is derived from , it can handle both compiled resources from .dll and .exe files, and XML resources from .resx files at the same time. Based on the selected strategies when a resource is not found in a language it can automatically add the missing resource from a base culture or even create completely new resource sets and save them into .resx files. For text entries the untranslated elements will be marked so they can be found easily for translation.
See the online help for examples with images.

remarks.para: class is derived from and adds the functionality of automatic appending the resources with the non-translated and/or unknown entries as well as auto-saving the changes. This makes possible to automatically create the .resx files if the language of the application is changed to a language, which has no translation yet. See also the static class. The strategy of auto appending and saving can be chosen by the and properties (see and enumerations).
remarks.note: To see when to use the , , , , and classes see the documentation of the KGySoft.Resources namespace.
remarks.para: combines the functionality of , , and extends these with the feature of auto expansion. It can be an ideal choice to use it as a resource manager of an application or a class library because it gives you freedom (or to the consumer of your library) to choose the strategy. If and functionalities are completely disabled, then it is equivalent to a , which can handle resources both from compiled and XML sources but you must explicitly add new content and save it (see the example of the base class). If you restrict even the source of the resources, then you can get the functionality of the class ( is ), or the class ( is ).

example.para: The following section highlights the additional features compared to :

Centralized vs. individual settings:
The behavior of instances can be controlled in two ways, which can be configured by the property.
Individual control If is , which is the default value, then the behavior is simply determined by its own properties. This can be alright for short-living instances (for example, in a block), or when you are sure you don't want let the consumers of your library to customize the settings of resource managers.
Centralized control If you use the class as the resource manager of a class library, you might want to let the consumers of your library to control how instances should behave. For example, maybe one consumer wants to allow generating new .resx language files by using custom , and another one does not want to let generating .resx files at all. If is , then , and properties will be taken from the static class (see LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersAutoAppend, LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersAutoSave and LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersSource properties, respectively). This makes possible to control the behavior of instances, which enable centralized settings, without exposing these manager instances of our class library to the public. See also the example at the Recommended usage for string resources in a class library section.
Unlike the property, LanguageSettings.DynamicResourceManagersSource property is by default, ensuring that centralized instances work the same way as regular classes by default, so the application can opt-in dynamic creation of .resx files, for example in its Main method.
Turning on the property makes the to subscribe multiple events. If such a is used in a non-static or short-living context make sure to dispose it to prevent leaking resources.

Considering SaveAllResources is indirectly called on auto save, you cannot set its parameters directly. However, by setting the property, you can tell whether the result .resx files should be able to be read by a System.Resources.ResXResourceReader instance and the Visual Studio Resource Editor. If it is the result .resx files are often shorter, and the values can be deserialized with better accuracy (see the remarks at ), but the result can be read only by the class.
Normally, if you save the changes by the SaveAllResources method, you can handle the possible exceptions locally. To handle errors occurred during auto save you can subscribe the event.
example.h2: Recommended usage for string resources in a class library

list.item: You can use the EnsureResourcesGenerated method to create possible non-existing resources for a language.

You can use the EnsureInvariantResourcesMerged method to forcibly merge all resource entries in the invariant resource set for a language. This can be useful if new resources have been introduced since a previous version and the newly introduced entries also have to be added to the localized resource sets.
To see how to use dynamically created resources for any language in a live application with editing support see the KGySoft.Drawing.Tools GitHub repository.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager.mergedCultures
member.summary: If contains flag, contains the up-to-date cultures. Value is if that culture is merged so it can be taken as a base for merge.

member.name: E:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager.AutoSaveError
member.summary: Occurs when an exception is thrown on auto saving. If this event is not subscribed, the following exception types are automatically suppressed, as they can occur on save: , , . If such an exception is suppressed some resources might remain unsaved. Though the event is a static one, the sender of the handler is the corresponding instance. Thus the save failures of the non public instances (e.g. resource managers of an assembly) can be tracked, too.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager.CompatibleFormat
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the .resx files should use a compatible format when the resources are automatically saved.
Default value:

remarks.para: The changes can be always saved by the SaveAllResources method, where compatible format can be explicitly requested. This property affects the result of auto saving controlled by the property.

If is the result .resx files can be read by a System.Resources.ResXResourceReader instance and the Visual Studio Resource Editor. If it is , the result .resx files are often shorter, and the values can be deserialized with better accuracy (see the remarks at ), but the result can be read only by the class.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager.GetObject(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Gets the value of the specified resource localized for the specified .
member.param: The name of the resource to get.

The culture for which the resource is localized. If the resource is not localized for this culture, the resource manager uses fallback rules to locate an appropriate resource. If this value is , the object is obtained by using the property.
member.returns: If is , and the resource is from a .resx content, then the method returns a instance instead of the actual deserialized value. Otherwise, returns the value of the resource localized for the specified , or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetObject methods return either a full copy of the specified resource, or always the same instance. For memory streams and byte arrays none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetStream methods can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
values are not duplicated in memory, regardless the value of the property.
Depending on the value of the property, dynamic expansion of the resource sets of different cultures may occur when calling this method.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager.GetObject(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the value of the specified resource.
member.param: The name of the resource to get.
member.returns: If is , and the resource is from a .resx content, then the method returns a instance instead of the actual deserialized value. Otherwise, returns the value of the resource localized for the caller's current UI culture, or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetObject methods return either a full copy of the specified resource, or always the same instance. For memory streams and byte arrays none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetStream methods can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.DynamicResourceManager.GetStream(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Returns a instance from the resource of the specified and .
member.param: The name of the resource to retrieve.

An object that represents the culture for which the resource is localized. If the resource is not localized for this culture, the resource manager uses fallback rules to locate an appropriate resource. If this value is , the object is obtained by using the CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture property.
member.returns: A object from the specified resource localized for the specified , or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetObject methods return either a full copy of the specified resource, or always the same instance. For memory streams none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetStream methods can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
GetStream can be used also for byte array resources. However, if the value is returned from compiled resources, then always a new copy of the byte array will be wrapped.

If is and is neither a nor a byte array resource, then instead of throwing an the method returns a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString method, which will be the raw XML content for non-string resources.
remarks.note: The internal buffer is tried to be obtained by reflection in the first place. On platforms, which have possibly unknown non-public member names the public APIs are used, which may copy the content in memory.

is and the type of the resource is neither nor byte[].

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.HybridResourceManager
member.summary:
Represents a resource manager that provides convenient access to culture-specific resources at run time. It can handle both compiled resources from .dll and .exe files, and .resx files at the same time. New elements can be added as well, which can be saved into .resx files.
See the online help for examples with images.

remarks.para: class is derived from and uses a internally. The combines the functionality of the regular and the classes. The source of the resources can be chosen by the property (see enumeration). Enabling both binary and .resx resources makes possible to expand or override the resources originally come from binary resources. Just like the it is an implementation. The replacement and newly added content can be saved into .resx files.
See the Comparison with ResourceManager section to see all of the differences.
remarks.note: To see when to use the , , , , and classes see the documentation of the KGySoft.Resources namespace.

example.para:
You can create compiled resources by Visual Studio and you can dynamically expand them by . The new and overridden content will be saved as .resx files. See the following example for a step-by-step guide.
Create a new project (Console Application)
In Solution Explorer right click on ConsoleApp1, Add, New Folder, name it Resources.
In Solution Explorer right click on Resources, Add, New Item, Resources File.
In Solution Explorer right click on the new resource file (Resource1.resx if not named otherwise) and select Properties
The default value of Build Action is Embedded Resource, which means that the resource will be compiled into the assembly. The will be able to read these compiled resources if its property is or . We can clear the default Custom Tool value because the generated file uses a class internally, which cannot handle the dynamic expansions.
To use purely the .resx files you can use the class. To provide dynamic creation and expansion of new .resx files with the untranslated items for any language use the class.
Now we can either use the built-on resource editor of Visual Studio or just edit the .resx file by the XML Editor. If we add new or existing files to the resources, they will be automatically added to the project's Resources folder.
To add culture-specific resources you can add further resource files with the same base name, extended by culture names. For example, if the invariant resource is called Resource1.resx, then a region neutral English resource can be called Resource1.en.resx and the American English resource can be called Resource1.en-US.resx.
If we now compile the project, the ConsoleApp1.exe will contain an embedded resource named ConsoleApp1.Resources.Resource1.resources. If we created language-specific resources they will be compiled into so-called satellite assemblies. For example, if we have a resource file named Resource1.en.resx, then building the project will create an en folder containing a ConsoleApp1.resources.dll, which will contain an embedded resource named ConsoleApp1.Resources.Resource1.en.resources. In both cases the base name is ConsoleApp1.Resources.Resource1, this must be the baseName parameter in the constructors of the . The automatically generated base name can be changed in the .csproj file. If you want to change the base name to MyResources, then follow the steps below:
In Solution Explorer right click on ConsoleApp1, Unload Project
In Solution Explorer right click on ConsoleApp1 (unavailable), Edit ConsoleApp1.csproj
Search for the EmbeddedResource nodes and edit them as follows:
<EmbeddedResource Include="Resources\Resource1.resx" > <LogicalName>MyResources.resources</LogicalName> </EmbeddedResource> <EmbeddedResource Include="Resources\Resource1.en.resx" > <LogicalName>MyResources.en.resources</LogicalName> </EmbeddedResource>
In Solution Explorer right click on ConsoleApp1 (unavailable), Reload ConsoleApp1.csproj
Reference KGySoft.CoreLibraries.dll and paste the following code in Program.cs:

Considering there are .resx files in the background not just and other resources can be obtained by GetString and GetObject methods but metadata as well by GetMetaString and GetMetaObject methods. Please note that accessing aliases are not exposed by the class, but you can still access them via the type returned by the GetExpandoResourceSet method. Please note that unlike in case of GetString and GetObject methods, there is no falling back to the parent cultures (as seen in the example above) for metadata accessed by the GetMetaString and GetMetaObject methods.

Similarly to , and , the class also has a property, which changes the behavior of GetString/GetMetaString and GetObject/GetMetaObject methods:
If the property is , and the result is from a .resx resource, then the return value of GetObject and GetMetaObject methods is a rather than the resource or metadata value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. The actual value can be obtained by the ResXDataNode.GetValue or ResXDataNode.GetValueSafe methods. See also the third example at the class.
If the property is , then GetString and GetMetaString methods will not throw an even for non-string entries. For non-string values the raw XML string value will be returned for resources from a .resx source and the result of the ToString method for resources from a compiled source.
If the property is , then GetStream and GetMetaStream methods will not throw an . For values, which are neither nor byte[] instances, they return a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString/GetMetaString methods.
Even if is , loading a .resx content with corrupt or malicious entry will have no effect until we try to obtain the corresponding value. See the last example at for the demonstration and the example at to see what members can be checked in safe mode.
While is read-only and works on binary resources, supports expansion (see ) and works both on binary and XML resources (.resx files).

Incompatibility with :
There is no constructor where the type of the resource sets can be specified. As works with multiple resource types you must not rely on the value of the property.
If ResourceManager.GetResourceSet method is called with createIfNotExists = false for a culture, which has a corresponding but not loaded resource file, then a resource set for a parent culture might be cached and on successive calls that cached parent set will be returned even if the createIfNotExists argument is . In the corresponding argument of the GetResourceSet method has been renamed to loadIfExists and works as expected.
The GetStream methods have return type instead of and they can be used also for byte[] values.

New features and improvements compared to :
Write support The stored content can be expanded or existing entries can be replaced (see SetObject/SetMetaObject), the entries can be removed (see RemoveObject/RemoveMetaObject), and the new content can be saved (see SaveAllResources/SaveResourceSet). You can start even with pure compiled resources, add new content during runtime and save the changes (see the example above).
Security During the initialization of and loading of a resource set from a .resx file no object is deserialized even if property is . Objects are deserialized only when they are accessed (see GetObject/GetMetaObject). If is , then security is even more increased because the GetObject and GetMetaObject methods return a instance instead of a deserialized object so you can check whether the resource or metadata can be treated as a safe object before actually deserializing it. See the Safety section above for more details.
Disposal As implementations are disposable objects, itself implements the interface as well.

Therefore the GetStream methods can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
GetStream can be used also for byte array resources. However, if the value is returned from compiled resources, then always a new copy of the byte array will be wrapped.

If is and is neither a nor a byte array resource, then instead of throwing an the method returns a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString method, which will be the raw XML content for non-string resources.
remarks.note: The internal buffer is tried to be obtained by reflection in the first place. On platforms, which have possibly unknown non-public member names the public APIs are used, which may copy the content in memory.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.HybridResourceManager.GetStream(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Returns a instance from the resource of the specified and .
member.param: The name of the resource to retrieve.

An object that represents the culture for which the resource is localized. If the resource is not localized for this culture, the resource manager uses fallback rules to locate an appropriate resource. If this value is , the object is obtained by using the CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture property.
member.returns: A object from the specified resource localized for the specified , or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetObject methods return either a full copy of the specified resource, or always the same instance. For memory streams none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetStream methods can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
GetStream can be used also for byte array resources. However, if the value is returned from compiled resources, then always a new copy of the byte array will be wrapped.

If is and is neither a nor a byte array resource, then instead of throwing an the method returns a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString method, which will be the raw XML content for non-string resources.
remarks.note: The internal buffer is tried to be obtained by reflection in the first place. On platforms, which have possibly unknown non-public member names the public APIs are used, which may copy the content in memory.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXDataNode
member.summary:
Represents a resource or metadata element in an XML resource (.resx) file.
See the online help for a more detailed description with an example.

remarks.note: This class is similar to System.Resources.ResXDataNode in System.Windows.Forms.dll. See the Comparison with System.Resources.ResXDataNode section for the differences.
remarks.para: The class supports the representation of rich data types within a resource file. It can support the storage of any object in a resource file.

You can create a object by calling one of its overloaded class constructors. You can then add the resource item or element to a resource file by one of the following options:
Call the ResXResourceWriter.AddResource(ResXDataNode) or ResXResourceWriter.AddMetadata(ResXDataNode) method.
Call the ResXResourceSet.SetObject(string, object) or ResXResourceSet.SetMetaObject(string, object) method and then call the Save method on it.
Call the SetObject or SetMetaObject method on any implementation (such as , , ) and then call the SaveResourceSet or SaveAllResources methods on them.
If you call any of the SetObject methods of the list above by any , then a instance will be implicitly created. A instance should be explicitly created only if you want to set the property.

To retrieve a object from a resource you have the following options:
Enumerate the objects in an XML (.resx file) by instantiating a object, setting the ResXResourceReader.SafeMode property to , and calling the ResXResourceReader.GetEnumerator or ResXResourceReader.GetMetadataEnumerator method to get an enumerator. See also the example below.
Instantiate a new from a .resx file, set ResXResourceSet.SafeMode to , and call the ResXResourceSet.GetObject or ResXResourceSet.GetMetaObject methods with a key, which exists in the .resx file. You can use the ResXResourceSet.GetEnumerator and ResXResourceSet.GetMetadataEnumerator methods in a similar way as in case of the class.
Instantiate a new / or class, set to , and call the GetObject or GetMetaObject methods with a key, which exists in the .resx file.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXFileRef
member.summary: Represents a link to an external resource.

remarks.note: This class is similar to System.Resources.ResXFileRef in System.Windows.Forms.dll. See the Comparison with System.Resources.ResXFileRef section for the differences.
remarks.para:
The class is used to include references to files in an XML resource (.resx) file. A object represents a link to an external resource in an XML resource (.resx) file. You can add a object to a .resx file programmatically by one of the following options:
Call the ResXResourceWriter.AddResource(string, object) method where the second parameter is a instance.
Call the ResXResourceSet.SetObject(string, object) method where the second parameter is a instance and then save the instance.
Call the ResXResourceManager.SetObject(string, object, CultureInfo) method where the second parameter is a instance and then save the instance.
Call the HybridResourceManager.SetObject(string, object, CultureInfo) method where the second parameter is a instance and then save the instance.
Call the HybridResourceManager.SetObject(string, object, CultureInfo) method where the second parameter is a instance and then save the instance.
remarks.note: The compatibility with System.Resources.ResXFileRef is provided without any reference to System.Windows.Forms.dll, where that type is located.

When serialized in compatibility mode (see ResXResourceWriter.CompatibleFormat, ResXResourceSet.Save, ResXResourceManager.SaveResourceSet and ResXResourceManager.SaveAllResources), the result will be able to be parsed by the System.Resources.ResXFileRef type, too.
remarks.para:
Incompatibility with System.Resources.ResXFileRef:
The constructor is incompatible with System.Resources.ResXFileRef implementation. Unlike in system version you must specify the type by a instance instead of a string.

New features and improvements compared to System.Resources.ResXFileRef:
ParsingA string can be parsed to a instance by and methods.
remarks.note: The that is assigned to the type may load assemblies when its ConvertFrom method is called. The recommended way to retrieve a file resource is via the class. Its GetValueSafe methods guarantees that no assembly is loaded during the deserialization, including retrieving resources from file references.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceManager
member.summary:
Represents a resource manager that provides convenient access to culture-specific XML resources (.resx files) at run time. New elements can be added as well, which can be saved into the .resx files.
See the online help for examples with images.

remarks.para: class is derived from so it can be used the same way. The main difference is that instead of working with binary compiled resources the class uses XML resources (.resx files) directly. As an implementation it is able to add/replace/remove entries in the resource sets belonging to specified cultures and it can save the changed contents.
See the Comparison with ResourceManager section to see all of the differences.
remarks.note: To see when to use the , , , , and classes see the documentation of the KGySoft.Resources namespace.

example.h4: Example 1: Using XML resources created by Visual Studio
example.para:
You can create XML resource files by Visual Studio and you can use them by . See the following example for a step-by-step guide.
Create a new project (Console Application)
In Solution Explorer right click on ConsoleApp1, Add, New Folder, name it Resources.
In Solution Explorer right click on Resources, Add, New Item, Resources File.
In Solution Explorer right click on the new resource file (Resource1.resx if not named otherwise) and select Properties
The default value of Build Action is Embedded Resource, which means that the resource will be compiled into the assembly and will be able to be read by the class. To be able to handle it by the we might want to deploy the .resx file with the application. To do so, select Copy if newer at Copy to Output directory. If we want to use purely the .resx file, then we can change the Build Action to None and we can clear the default Custom Tool value because we do not need the generated file.
To use both the compiled binary resources and the .resx file you can use the and classes.
Now we can either use the built-on resource editor of Visual Studio or just edit the .resx file by the XML Editor. If we add new or existing files to the resources, they will be automatically added to the project's Resources folder. Do not forget to set Copy if newer for the linked resources as well so they will be copied to the output directory along with the .resx file. Now add some string resources and files if you wish.
To add culture-specific resources you can add further resource files with the same base name, extended by culture names. For example, if the invariant resource is called Resource1.resx, then a region neutral English resource can be called Resource1.en.resx and the American English resource can be called Resource1.en-US.resx.
Reference KGySoft.CoreLibraries.dll and paste the following code in Program.cs:

Considering there are .resx files in the background not just and other resources can be obtained by GetString and GetObject methods but metadata as well by GetMetaString and GetMetaObject methods. Please note that accessing aliases are not exposed by the class, but you can still access them via the type returned by the GetExpandoResourceSet method. Please note that unlike in case of GetString and GetObject methods, there is no falling back to the parent cultures (as seen in the example above) for metadata accessed by the GetMetaString and GetMetaObject methods.
example.h4: Example 2: Adding and saving new resources at runtime
example.para: As maintains instances for each culture, it also supports adding new resources at runtime. By the SetObject method you can add a resource to a specific culture. You can add metadata as well by the SetMetaObject method. The resources and metadata can be removed, too (see RemoveObject and RemoveMetaObject methods).

The changes in the resource sets can be saved by calling the SaveAllResources method. A single resource set can be saved by calling the SaveResourceSet method. The always saves the resources into files and never embeds the resources if they are file references (see ). If you need more control over saving you can call the GetExpandoResourceSet method to access the various Save overloads)

You instantiate a object that retrieves resources from .resx files by calling one of its class constructor overloads. This tightly couples a object with a particular set of .resx files (see the previous example as well).

para.note: If a instance is created with a baseName without a corresponding .resx file for the default culture, then accessing a non-existing resource will throw a , unless property is , in which case only a value will be returned. The exception can be avoided, if a resource set is created for the default culture either by adding a new resource (see next section) or by creating the resource set explicitly by calling the GetExpandoResourceSet method with behavior.

example.para:
Similarly to and , the class also has a which changes the behavior of GetString/GetMetaString and GetObject/GetMetaObject methods:
If the property is the return value of GetObject and GetMetaObject methods is a rather than the resource or metadata value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. The actual value can be obtained by the ResXDataNode.GetValue or ResXDataNode.GetValueSafe methods. See also the third example at the class.
If the property is , then GetString and GetMetaString methods will not throw an even for non-string entries; they return the raw XML value instead.
If the property is , then GetStream and GetMetaStream methods will not throw an . For values, which are neither nor byte[] instances, they return a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString/GetMetaString methods.
Even if is , loading a .resx content with corrupt or malicious entry will have no effect until we try to obtain the corresponding value. See the last example at for the demonstration and the example at to see what members can be checked in safe mode.
While is read-only and works on binary resources, supports expansion (see ) and works on XML resource (.resx) files.

Incompatibility with :
There is no constructor where the type of the resource sets can be specified. The property returns always the type of .
If ResourceManager.GetResourceSet method is called with createIfNotExists = false for a culture, which has a corresponding but not loaded resource file, then a resource set for a parent culture might be cached and on successive calls that cached parent set will be returned even if the createIfNotExists argument is . In the corresponding argument of the GetResourceSet method has been renamed to loadIfExists and works as expected.
The GetStream methods have return type instead of and they can be used also for byte[] values.

New features and improvements compared to :
Write support The stored content can be expanded or existing entries can be replaced (see SetObject/SetMetaObject), the entries can be removed (see RemoveObject/RemoveMetaObject), and the new content can be saved (see SaveAllResources/SaveResourceSet). You can start even with a completely empty manager, add content dynamically and save the new resources (see the example above).
Security During the initialization of and loading of a resource set no object is deserialized even if property is . Objects are deserialized only when they are accessed (see GetObject/GetMetaObject). If is , then security is even more increased because GetObject and GetMetaObject methods return a instance instead of a deserialized object so you can check whether the resource or metadata can be treated as a safe object before actually deserializing it. See the Safety section above for more details.
Disposal As implementations are disposable objects, itself implements the interface as well.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceManager.GetStream(System.String)
member.summary: Returns a instance from the resource of the specified .
member.param: The name of the resource to retrieve.
member.returns: A object from the specified resource localized for the caller's current UI culture, or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetObject methods return either a full copy of the specified resource, or always the same instance. For memory streams none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetStream methods can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
GetStream can be used also for byte array resources. However, if the value is returned from compiled resources, then always a new copy of the byte array will be wrapped.

If is and is neither a nor a byte array resource, then instead of throwing an the method returns a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString method, which will be the raw XML content for non-string resources.
remarks.note: The internal buffer is tried to be obtained by reflection in the first place. On platforms, which have possibly unknown non-public member names the public APIs are used, which may copy the content in memory.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceManager.GetMetaStream(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Returns a instance from the metadata of the specified and .
member.param: The name of the metadata to retrieve.

An object that represents the culture for which the metadata should be returned. If this value is , the object is obtained by using the CultureInfo.InvariantCulture property. Unlike in case of GetStream methods, no fallback is used if the metadata is not found in the specified culture. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A object from the specified metadata, or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetMetaObject method returns either a full copy of the specified metadata, or always the same instance. For memory streams none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetMetaStream method can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
GetMetaStream can be used also for byte array metadata.

If is and is neither a nor a byte array metadata, then instead of throwing an the method returns a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString methods, which will be the raw XML content for non-string metadata.

member.exception: is .
The is already disposed.
is and the type of the metadata is neither nor byte[].

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceReader
member.summary:
Enumerates XML resource (.resx) files and streams, and reads the sequential resource name and value pairs.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.

remarks.note: This class is similar to System.Resources.ResXResourceReader in System.Windows.Forms.dll. See the Comparison with System.Resources.ResXResourceReader section for the differences.
To see when to use the , , , , and classes see the documentation of the KGySoft.Resources namespace.
remarks.para:
You can use the class to enumerate resources in .resx files by traversing the dictionary enumerator () that is returned by the GetEnumerator method. You call the methods provided by to advance to the next resource and to read the name and value of each resource in the .resx file. The class provides more enumerators.
The GetEnumerator method returns an object, which enumerates the resources. The IDictionaryEnumerator.Key property returns the resource names, while IDictionaryEnumerator.Value returns either instances, if property is ; or returns deserialized instances if property is .
The GetMetadataEnumerator method returns an object, which enumerates the metadata entries. The IDictionaryEnumerator.Key property returns the metadata names, while IDictionaryEnumerator.Value returns either instances, if property is ; or returns deserialized instances if property is .
The GetAliasEnumerator method returns an object, which enumerates the aliases in the .resx file. The IDictionaryEnumerator.Key property returns the alias names, while IDictionaryEnumerator.Value returns the corresponding assembly names for the alias names.
As an explicit interface implementation, implements IEnumerable.GetEnumerator method, which returns the same enumerator as the GetEnumerator method as an instance. The IEnumerator.Current property will return instances.

If the property is , the value of the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property is a instance rather than the resource value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the example at .

If you want to retrieve named resources from a .resx file rather than enumerating its resources, then you can instantiate a object and call its GetString/GetObject, GetMetaString/GetMetaObject and GetAliasValue methods. Also supports .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceReader.LazyEnumerator
member.summary: An enumerator that reads the underlying .resx on-demand. Returns the duplicated elements, too.

member.summary: Hasting the enumeration and reading all of the elements into a buffer. Occurs on a second GetEnumerator call while the first enumeration has not been finished.

When is , then objects returned by the GetEnumerator and GetMetadataEnumerator methods return instances instead of deserialized objects. You can retrieve the deserialized objects on demand by calling the ResXDataNode.GetValue method on the instance.

member.summary:
Gets or sets whether "resheader" entries are checked in the .resx file. When , a can be thrown during the enumeration when "resheader" entries contain invalid values. When header entries are missing, no exception is thrown.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceReader.AllowDuplicatedKeys
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether all entries of same name of the .resx file should be returned.
Default value: .

remarks.para: If an element is defined more than once and is , then the enumeration returns every occurrence of the entries with identical names. If is the enumeration returns always the last occurrence of the entries with identical names.

If duplicated keys are allowed, the enumeration of the .resx file is lazy for the first time. A lazy enumeration means that the underlying .resx file is read only on demand. It is possible that not the whole .resx is read if enumeration is canceled. After the first enumeration elements are cached.
remarks.note: To be compatible with the System.Resources.ResXResourceReader class set the value of this property to .
