member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceReader.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an instance for the current object that enumerates the resources in the source XML resource file or stream.
member.returns: An for that can be used to iterate through the resources from the current XML resource file or stream.

remarks.para: In System.Resources.ResXResourceReader if property is , the resource and metadata entries are mixed in the returned enumerator, while when it is , then only the resources are returned. In this implementation the GetEnumerator method always returns only the resources and GetMetadataEnumerator returns the metadata regardless of the value of the or properties.

If the property is , the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is a instance rather than the resource value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the example at .

If property is , then this method returns a lazy enumerator for the first time meaning the .resx file is parsed only during the enumeration. When any of the enumerators are obtained for the second time, a cached enumerator is returned with the whole parsed .resx content. If duplicates are disabled, the lastly defined value will be returned of a redefined name.
See also the Remarks section of the class for examples.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceReader.GetMetadataEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an instance for the current object that enumerates the design-time properties (<metadata> elements) in the source XML resource file or stream.
member.returns: An for that can be used to iterate through the design-time properties (<metadata>; elements) from the current XML resource file or stream.

remarks.para: If the property is , the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is a instance rather than the resource value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the example at .

If property is , then this method returns a lazy enumerator for the first time meaning the .resx file is parsed only during the enumeration. When any of the enumerators are obtained for the second time, a cached enumerator is returned with the whole parsed .resx content. If duplicates are disabled, the lastly defined value will be returned of a redefined name.
See also the Remarks section of the class for examples.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceReader.GetAliasEnumerator
member.summary: Provides an instance that can retrieve the aliases from the current XML resource file or stream.
member.returns: An for that can be used to iterate through the aliases from the current XML resource file or stream.

remarks.para: The IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is always a regardless of the value of the property.
The IDictionaryEnumerator.Key property of the returned enumerator is the alias name, whereas IDictionaryEnumerator.Value is the corresponding assembly name.

If property is , then this method returns a lazy enumerator for the first time meaning the .resx file is parsed only during the enumeration. When any of the enumerators are obtained for the second time, a cached enumerator is returned with the whole parsed .resx content. If duplicates are disabled, the lastly defined value will be returned of a redefined alias.
See also the Remarks section of the class for examples.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceSet
member.summary:
Represents the complete content of an XML resource (.resx) file including resources, metadata and aliases.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.

remarks.note: This class is similar to System.Resources.ResXResourceSet in System.Windows.Forms.dll. See the Comparison with System.Resources.ResXResourceSet section for the differences.
To see when to use the , , , , and classes see the documentation of the KGySoft.Resources namespace.
remarks.para: The class represents a single XML resource file (.resx file) in memory. It uses internally to read the .resx content and to save it.

A instance can contain resources, metadata and aliases (unlike the System.Resources.ResXResourceSet class, which contains only the resources). These contents are available either by enumerators (GetEnumerator, GetMetadataEnumerator and GetAliasEnumerator methods) or directly by key (GetString and GetObject methods for resources, GetMetaString and GetMetaObject for metadata, and GetAliasValue for aliases).

example.h4: Example 1: Enumerating resources, metadata and aliases
example.para: The class supports adding new resources (SetObject), metadata (SetMetaObject) and aliases (SetAliasValue). Existing entries can be removed by RemoveObject, RemoveMetaObject and RemoveAliasValue methods. The changed set can be saved by the Save overloads.
example.h4: Example 2: Populating and saving a new resource set
example.para: If a .resx content contains the same resource name multiple times, will contain the lastly defined key. To obtain redefined values use explicitly and set to .

If the property is the value of the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property returned by the enumerator methods is a instance rather than the resource value. The same applies for the return value of GetObject and GetMetaObject methods. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the example at . Even if is , loading a .resx content with corrupt or malicious entry will have no effect until we try to obtain the corresponding value. See the example below for the demonstration.
If property is the GetString and GetMetaString methods will not throw an even for non-string values; they return the raw XML value instead.

can load .resx files produced both by and System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter. When reading a .resx file written by the System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter class, the System.Windows.Forms.dll is not loaded during resolving System.Resources.ResXFileRef and System.Resources.ResXNullRef types.

Incompatibility with System.Resources.ResXResourceSet:
There are no constructors with single and arguments; though if using pure C# (without reflection) this is a compatible change as the second parameter of the constructors is optional.
The constructors of System.Resources.ResXResourceSet throw an on any kind of error, including when an object cannot be deserialized. This implementation does not deserialize anything on construction just parses the raw XML content. If there is a syntax error in the .resx content an will be thrown from the constructors. If an entry cannot be deserialized, the GetObject, GetMetaObject, ResXDataNode.GetValue and ResXDataNode.GetValueSafe methods will throw an , , or based on the nature of the error.
This is a sealed class.

New features and improvements compared to System.Resources.ResXResourceSet:
Supporting file references If the .resx file contains file references with relative paths, then a base path can be defined in the constructors so the file references can be resolved successfully. See also the class.
Full .resx support A .resx file can contain also metadata and assembly alias entries in addition to resources and this implementation handles them.
Performance Load time is much faster because the constructors just simply parse the raw XML content. The actual deserialization occurs on demand only for the really accessed resources and metadata. Memory footprint is tried to be kept minimal as well. If is , then raw XML data is freed after deserializing and caching an entry.
Security This is much more safe, even if is , because no object is deserialized at load time. If is , then security is even more increased as GetObject and GetMetaObject methods, and the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the enumerators returned by GetEnumerator and GetMetadataEnumerator methods return a instance instead of a deserialized object so you can check whether the resource or metadata can be treated as a safe object before actually deserializing it. See the example above for more details.
Write support The .resx file content can be expanded, existing entries can be replaced or removed and the new content can be saved by the Save methods. You can start even with a completely empty set, add content dynamically and save the new resource set.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceSet.FileName
member.summary: If this has been created from a file, returns the name of the original file. This property will not change if the is saved into another file.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceSet.SafeMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the works in safe mode. In safe mode the retrieved objects are not deserialized automatically.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When is , then GetObject and GetMetaObject methods return instances instead of deserialized objects. You can retrieve the deserialized objects by calling the ResXDataNode.GetValue or ResXDataNode.GetValueSafe methods.
When is , then GetString and GetMetaString methods will return a also for non-string objects. For non-string elements the raw XML string value will be returned.
If is , then property is ignored. The raw XML data of a node can be freed when calling the ResXDataNode.GetValue method.
For examples see the documentation of the class.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceSet.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an that can iterate through the resources of the .
member.returns: An for the resources of this .

remarks.para: The returned enumerator iterates through the resources of the . To obtain a specific resource by name, use the GetObject or GetString methods. To obtain an enumerator for the metadata entries instead, use the GetMetadataEnumerator method instead.

If the property is , the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is a instance rather than the resource value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the examples at and classes.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceSet.GetMetadataEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an that can iterate through the metadata of the .
member.returns: An for the metadata of this .

remarks.para: The returned enumerator iterates through the metadata entries of the . To obtain a specific metadata by name, use the GetMetaObject or GetMetaString methods. To obtain an enumerator for the resources use the GetEnumerator method instead.

If the property is , the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is a instance rather than the resource value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the examples at and classes.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceSet.GetAliasEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an that can iterate through the aliases of the .
member.returns: An for the aliases of this .

remarks.para: The returned enumerator iterates through the assembly aliases of the . To obtain a specific alias value by assembly name, use the GetAliasValue method. To obtain an enumerator for the resources use the GetEnumerator method instead.
The IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is always a regardless of the value of the property.
The IDictionaryEnumerator.Key property of the returned enumerator is the alias name, whereas IDictionaryEnumerator.Value is the corresponding assembly name.
remarks.note: The returned enumerator supports the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceWriter
member.summary:
Writes resources in an XML resource (.resx) file or an output stream.
See the online help for a more detailed description with an example.

remarks.note: This class is similar to System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter in System.Windows.Forms.dll. See the Comparison with System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter section for the differences.
To see when to use the , , , , and classes see the documentation of the KGySoft.Resources namespace.
remarks.para: Resources are specified as name/value pairs using the AddResource method.
If property is , emits .resx files, which can be then read not just by but by the original System.Resources.ResXResourceReader class, too.

example.para: The following example shows how to create a resource file by and add different kind of resource objects to it. At the end it displays the resulting .resx file content.
example.note: When writing a .resx file in , the System.Windows.Forms.dll is not loaded when referencing System.Resources.ResXFileRef and System.Resources.ResXNullRef types.
example.para:
Incompatibility with System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter:
The System version has several public string fields, which are not intended to be accessed by a consumer code. Therefore, the following fields are missing (they are not public) in this version:
BinSerializedObjectMimeType
ByteArraySerializedObjectMimeType
DefaultSerializedObjectMimeType
ResMimeType
ResourceSchema
SoapSerializedObjectMimeType
Version
In this version there are no one parameter constructors. Instead, the second parameter (typeNameConverter) is optional. If used purely from C# (no reflection or whatsoever), this change is a compatible one.
This is a sealed class.
After disposing the instance or calling the Close method, calling the Generate method will throw an .
The System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter.AddAlias method just populates an inner alias list causing that the alias will be recognized on further processing but will never be dumped into the output stream. In this implementation the AddAlias method is somewhat different: not just registers the alias as a known one but also dumps that into the output stream. It can be specified though, whether the dump should be deferred until the alias is actually referenced for the first time.

New features and improvements compared to System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter:
Compatibility If is , the resulting .resx file can be read by System.Resources.ResXResourceReader.
Compactness The more compact output is achieved in multiple ways:
If is , the header and the schema are not dumped into the resulting .resx file. If is , then only the header comment can be omitted.
Whitespace preserving to string values is applied only if it is really necessary (even if is ).
If an object can only be binary serialized, then instead of using it is serialized by , which produces a much more compact result (only if is ). A new MIME type has been introduced to identify binary data serialized this new way.
New overloads:
AddAlias method now can be called with a assembly name and not just by an instance. Both overloads have now an optional argument for specifying whether the alias must be dumped immediately.
New AddMetadata(ResXDataNode) overload, working similarly to the existing AddResource(ResXDataNode) method.
property If , alias names for assemblies will be automatically generated without calling AddAlias method. If , the assembly qualified names will be used for non-mscorlib types, unless an alias name was explicitly added by the AddAlias method or the to dump already contains an alias name.
Better support of several types:
TypeImprovementHow it is handled by the System version
value Invalid .resx representations of value is fixed when re-written by . When the System version rewrites such an invalid node, it turns into empty string.
of Serializing sbyte[] type works properly. The System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter changes the sbyte[] types to byte[].
Support of unpaired surrogate characters. System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter cannot serialize unpaired surrogates, though System.Resources.ResXResourceReader can read them successfully if they are serialized by and is .
and any type serialized by a . Strings containing unpaired surrogates and invalid Unicode characters can be written without any error. System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter cannot serialize such strings, though System.Resources.ResXResourceReader can read them successfully if they are serialized by and is .
and Serialized in a different way so even the milliseconds part is preserved. The fixed form can be deserialized by System.Resources.ResXResourceReader, too; however, the DateTime.Kind will be always .
, and -0 (negative zero) value is handled correctly. The fixed form can be deserialized by System.Resources.ResXResourceReader, too; however, in case of and -0 will always turn to +0.
, , and instances containing a runtime type. These types are supported natively (without a mimetype attribute). Only if is . System.Resources.ResXResourceWriter can serialize these type only by . Though in .NET Core and .NET Standard is not serializable even by .
Generic types Generic types with a are handled correctly. Parsing generic type names may fail with System.Resources.ResXResourceReader. The problem does not occur on binary serialization because in that case the type name is not dumped into the .resx file but is encoded in the binary stream.
Any non-serializable type As long as the can serialize the non-serializable type, this implementation supports non-serializable types as well. This works even if is . If is during serialization, deserialization works even with System.Resources.ResXResourceReader as long as KGySoft.CoreLibraries assembly can be loaded and can find the class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceWriter.ResXWriter
member.summary: Required because a writer created by XmlWriter.Create preserves \r chars only if they are entitized; however, to keep things readable (and compatible), entitization should be omitted on new lines and base64 wrapping, but entitization cannot be changed once the writing has been started. So this writer: - Entitizes \r \n chars only if they are not used together - Can write strings containing unpaired surrogates and invalid Unicode characters. This result can be read correctly even by system ResXResourceReader.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Resources.ResXResourceWriter.CompatibleFormat
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether the instance should create a System compatible .resx file, which can be used by the built-in resource editor of Visual Studio.
Default value: .
member.remarks:
The value of the property affects the following differences:
The reader and writer attributes in resheader elements.
Type of file references.
The placeholder type of references.
If CompatibleFormat is , some additional types are supported natively (without a mimetype attribute): , , , , , , , , and .
If CompatibleFormat is , unpaired surrogate values are supported.
The mimetype and content of binary serialized elements. If CompatibleFormat is , these objects are serialized by , which provides a much more compact result than the default .
When the value of this property is , then adding non-natively supported entries may cause a on .NET 8.0 and above where is no longer supported.
member.exception: In a set operation, a value cannot be specified because the creation of the .resx file content has already been started.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: The namespace contains classes for resource management, which support read-write access directly to .resx files () or even combined access to compiled and .resx resources (, ).
member.remarks:
There are numerous classes in the that can handle resources from XML sources (.resx files). The table below can help you to choose the best one for your needs.
ClassWhen to choose this one; added functionality compared to previous levels.
Using is the most low-level option to read the content of a .resx file. It provides enumerators to retrieve the resources, metadata and aliases of a .resx content. In most cases you can use the more specialized classes, such as but there are some cases when you need to use :
The is able to read the .resx content in a lazy manner if ResXResourceReader.AllowDuplicatedKeys is . That means the .resx content is read on demand as you enumerate the contents (the contents are cached so if you retrieve an enumerator for the second time it will not process the .resx file again). It can be useful if you are looking for one specific key, after which you break the enumeration or if you want to process an incomplete or corrupted .resx file up to the point it can be parsed correctly.
A .resx file may contain a key more than once (though it is somewhat incorrect). If ResXResourceReader.AllowDuplicatedKeys is , you can retrieve all of the redefined values.
allows you to handle type names in a customized way (how names are mapped to a ). To use custom name resolution pass an instance to one of the constructors.
Using is the most low-level option to write the content of a .resx file. Use this if at least one of the following points are applicable for you:
You want to have full control over the order of the dumped resources, metadata and aliases or you want to re-use a key or redefine an alias during the dump (though it is not recommended).
You want to dump the full .resx header including the comments dumped also by Visual Studio when you create a resource file (see ResXResourceWriter.OmitHeader property).
You want to use customized type names when non-string resources are added. You can achieve this by passing a Func<Type, string> delegate to one of the constructors.
The class represents the full content of a single .resx file in memory. It provides both enumerators and dictionary-like direct key access to the resources, metadata and aliases. It uses and internally to load/save .resx content. As an implementation it is able to add/replace/remove entries and save the content. Use this class in the following cases:
You want to access the resources/metadata/aliases of a single .resx file directly by name just like in a dictionary.
You want to load the .resx content not just from a file but also a / or to save it to a /.
Specialization compared to /:
Default type name handling and type resolution is used.
When loading a .resx file, duplications are not allowed. For redefined names the last value will be stored.
When saving a .resx file, header comment is always omitted. If content is saved in non-compatible format, the .resx schema header is omitted, too.
When saving a .resx file, assembly aliases are auto generated for assemblies, which are not explicitly defined.
The handles resources in the same manner as does but instead of working with binary compiled resources it uses XML resources (.resx files) directly. It takes the culture hierarchy into account so querying a resource by a specific may end up loading multiple resource files. It stores instances internally to store the resources of the different cultures. As an implementation it is able to add/replace/remove entries in the resource sets belonging to specified cultures and it can save the changed contents.
Specialization compared to :
The loads/saves the resource sets always from/into files. (Though you can call the GetExpandoResourceSet method to access the various Save overloads)
The does not contain methods to manipulate the aliases directly. (Though you can call the GetExpandoResourceSet method to access the aliases directly)
The combines the functionality of the regular and the classes. The source of the resources can be chosen by the property (see enumeration). Enabling both binary and .resx resources makes possible to expand or override the resources originally come from binary resources. Just like the it is an implementation. The replacement and newly added content is saved into .resx files.
The is derived from and adds the functionality of automatically appending the resources with the non-translated and/or unknown entries as well as auto-saving the changes. This makes possible to automatically create the .resx files if the language of the application is changed to a language, which has no translation yet. See also the static class. The strategy of auto appending and saving can be chosen by the and properties (see and enumerations).

member.name: T:KGySoft.Resources.AutoAppendOptions
member.summary: Represents the resource auto append options of a instance. These options are ignored if is .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Resources.AutoAppendOptions.None
member.summary: Represents no auto appending.

summary.para: If a resource with an unknown key is requested, a new resource is automatically added to the invariant resource set.

If the resource is requested as a , the newly added value will be initialized by the requested key, prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UnknownResourcePrefix property. This new entry can be then merged into other resource sets, too.

If the resource is requested as an , a value will be added to the resource. The value is never merged into the other resource sets because it has a special meaning: if a resource has a null value, the parent resources are checked for a non-null resource value.
Enabling this flag causes that will never be thrown for non-existing resources.
This option is disabled by default.

If a resource is found in a parent resource set of the requested culture, and the traversal of the culture hierarchy hits a neutral culture, then the resource set of the first (most derived) neutral culture will be automatically appended by the found resource.
Let's consider the following hypothetical culture hierarchy:
en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire (specific) -> en-Runic-GB (specific) -> en-Runic (neutral) -> en (neutral) -> Invariant
If the requested culture is en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and the resource is found in the invariant resource set, then with this option the found resource will be added to the en-Runic resource set.
If the found resource is a , the newly added value will be prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix property.
If the found non- resource is not a , the found value will be simply copied.
This option is enabled by default.

If a resource is found in the resource set of the invariant culture, then the resource set of the last neutral culture (whose parent is the invariant culture) will be automatically appended by the found resource.
Let's consider the following hypothetical culture hierarchy:
en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire (specific) -> en-Runic-GB (specific) -> en-Runic (neutral) -> en (neutral) -> Invariant
If the requested culture is en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and the resource is found in the invariant resource set, then with this option the found resource will be added to the en resource set.
If the found resource is a , the newly added value will be prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix property.
If the found non- resource is not a , the found value will be simply copied.
This option is disabled by default.

If a resource is found in a parent resource set of the requested culture, and the traversal of the culture hierarchy hits neutral cultures, then the resource sets of the neutral cultures will be automatically appended by the found resource.
Let's consider the following hypothetical culture hierarchy:
en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire (specific) -> en-Runic-GB (specific) -> en-Runic (neutral) -> en (neutral) -> Invariant
If the requested culture is en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and the resource is found in the invariant resource set, then with this option the found resource will be added to the en and en-Runic resource sets.
If the found resource is a , the newly added value will be prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix property.
If the found non- resource is not a , the found value will be simply copied.
This option includes and options.
This option is disabled by default.

If a resource is found in a parent resource set of the requested specific culture, then the resource set of the requested culture will be automatically appended by the found resource.
Let's consider the following hypothetical culture hierarchy:
en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire (specific) -> en-Runic-GB (specific) -> en-Runic (neutral) -> en (neutral) -> Invariant
If the requested culture is en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and the resource is found in one of its parents, then with this option the found resource will be added to the requested en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire resource set.
If the found resource is a , the newly added value will be prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix property.
If the found non- resource is not a , the found value will be simply copied.
This option is disabled by default.

If a resource is found in a parent resource set of the requested specific culture, then the resource set of the last specific culture in the traversal hierarchy (whose parent is a non-specific culture) will be automatically appended by the found resource.
Let's consider the following hypothetical culture hierarchy:
en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire (specific) -> en-Runic-GB (specific) -> en-Runic (neutral) -> en (neutral) -> Invariant
If the requested culture is en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and the resource is found in the invariant resource set, then with this option the found resource will be added to the en-Runic-GB resource set.
If the found resource is a , the newly added value will be prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix property.
If the found non- resource is not a , the found value will be simply copied.
This option is disabled by default.

If a resource is found in a parent resource set of the requested specific culture, then the resource sets of the visited specific cultures will be automatically appended by the found resource.
Let's consider the following hypothetical culture hierarchy:
en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire (specific) -> en-Runic-GB (specific) -> en-Runic (neutral) -> en (neutral) -> Invariant
If the requested culture is en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and the resource is found in the invariant resource set, then with this option the found resource will be added to the en-Runic-GB-Yorkshire and en-Runic-GB resource sets.
If the found resource is a , the newly added value will be prefixed by the LanguageSettings.UntranslatedResourcePrefix property.
If the found non- resource is not a , the found value will be simply copied.
This option includes and options.
This option is disabled by default.
If a resource set is being loaded, and rules are automatically applied for all resources.
This flag is enabled by default.

Gets or sets whether the works in safe mode. In safe mode the retrieved objects returned from .resx sources are not deserialized automatically.
Default value: .

remarks.para: When is , then GetObject and GetMetaObject methods return instances instead of deserialized objects, if they are returned from .resx resource. You can retrieve the deserialized objects by calling the ResXDataNode.GetValue or ResXDataNode.GetValueSafe methods.

When is , then GetString and GetMetaString methods will return a also for non-string objects. For non-string values the raw XML string value will be returned for resources from a .resx source and the result of the ToString method for resources from a compiled source.

When is , then GetStream and GetMetaStream methods will return a for any object. For values, which are neither , nor byte[] instances these methods return a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString/GetMetaString methods.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Resources.IExpandoResourceManager.CloneValues
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether GetObject and GetMetaObject methods return always a new copy of the stored values.
Default value: .

remarks.para: To be compatible with System.Resources.ResourceManager this property is by default. If this instance contains no mutable values or it is known that modifying values is not an issue, then this property can be set to for better performance.
String values are not cloned.
The value of this property affects only the objects returned from .resx sources. Non-string values from compiled sources are always cloned.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.IExpandoResourceManager.GetStream(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Returns a instance from the resource of the specified and .
member.param: The name of the resource to retrieve.

An object that represents the culture for which the resource is localized. If the resource is not localized for this culture, the resource manager uses fallback rules to locate an appropriate resource. If this value is , the object is obtained by using the CultureInfo.CurrentUICulture property. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A object from the specified resource localized for the specified , or if cannot be found in a resource set.

remarks.para: Depending on the value of the property, the GetObject method returns either a full copy of the specified resource, or always the same instance. For memory streams none of them are ideal because a full copy duplicates the inner buffer of a possibly large array of bytes, whereas returning the same stream instance can cause issues with conflicting positions or disposed state. Therefore the GetStream method can be used to obtain a new read-only wrapper around the same internal buffer, regardless the current value of the property.
GetStream can be used also for byte array resources. However, if the value is returned from compiled resources, then always a new copy of the byte array will be wrapped.

If is and is neither a nor a byte array resource, then instead of throwing an the method returns a stream wrapper for the same string value that is returned by the GetString method, which will be the raw XML content for non-string resources.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Resources.IExpandoResourceSet.GetEnumerator
member.summary: Returns an that can iterate through the resources of the .
member.returns: An for the resources of this .

remarks.para: The returned enumerator iterates through the resources of the . To obtain a specific resource by name, use the GetObject or GetString methods. To obtain an enumerator for the metadata entries instead, use the GetMetadataEnumerator method instead.

If the property is , the IDictionaryEnumerator.Value property of the returned enumerator is a instance rather than the resource value. This makes possible to check the raw .resx content before deserialization if the .resx file is from an untrusted source. See also the examples at and classes.
The returned enumerators in this assembly support the IEnumerator.Reset method.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.AnyObjectSerializerWrapper
member.summary: Provides a wrapper class for serializing any kind of object, including the ones that are not marked by the , or which are not supported by . Can be useful when a payload cannot be used, so a -compatible stream must be produced. When this object is deserialized, the clone of the wrapped original object is returned.

note.para: This type has been made obsolete because just from the stream to deserialize it cannot be determined whether the consumer formatter is used in a safe context. Therefore deserialization uses safe mode, which denies deserializing non-serializable types. It renders this type practically useless, but it was meant for anyway, which is also being obsoleted in upcoming .NET versions. To serialize non-serializable types you still can use , which now supports , which should be enabled when deserializing anything from an untrusted source.

When deserializing a stream that has an reference, it is ensured that no assemblies are loaded while unwrapping its content (it may not be true for other entries in the serialization stream, if the formatter is a , for example). Therefore, all the assemblies that are involved by the types wrapped into an must be preloaded before deserializing such a stream.
See the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

remarks.para: Since supports serialization of any class, this object is not necessarily needed when is used.
In .NET Framework this class supports serialization of remote objects, too.

note.para: This class cannot guarantee that an object serialized in one platform can be deserialized in another one. For such cases some text-based serialization might be better (see also the ).
In .NET Core and above the implementation of some types throw a . For such cases setting the forceSerializationByFields in the constructor can be a solution.
For a more flexible customization use the class instead.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.AnyObjectSerializerWrapper.#ctor(System.Object,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of with the provided object to be serialized.
member.param: The to serialize. Non-serializable, remote objects, and instances are supported, too.
When , the assembly versions of types do not need to match on deserialization. This makes possible to deserialize objects stored in different versions of the original assembly.

to ignore and implementations as well as serialization constructors and serializing methods; to consider all of these techniques instead performing a forced field-based serialization. Can be useful for types that implement but the implementation throws a (on .NET Core, for example). It still does not guarantee that the object will be deserializable on another platform. This parameter is optional.
Default value: .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter
member.summary:
Serializes and deserializes objects in binary format.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.

remarks.note: The fundamental goal of binary serialization is to store the bitwise content of an object, hence in general case (when custom types are involved) it relies on field values, including private ones that can change from version to version. Therefore, binary serialization is recommended only if your serialized objects purely consist of natively supported types (see them below). If you need to serialize custom types, then it is recommended to do it for in-process purposes only, such as deep cloning or undo/redo, etc. If it is known that a type will be deserialized in another environment and it can be completely restored by its public members, then a text-based serialization (see also ) can be a better choice.

note.para: If the serialization stream may come from an untrusted source (e.g. remote service, file or database) make sure you enable the option. It prevents loading assemblies during the deserialization, denies resolving unexpected natively not supported types by name, does not allow instantiating natively not supported types that are not serializable, and guards against some attacks that may cause . When using all of the natively not supported types, whose assembly qualified names are stored in the serialization stream must be explicitly declared as expected types in the deserialization methods, including apparently innocent types such as s.

Please also note that in safe mode some system types are forbidden to use even if they are serializable and are specified as expected types. In the .NET Framework there are some serializable types in the fundamental core assemblies that can be exploited for several attacks (causing unresponsiveness, or even files to be deleted). Starting with .NET Core these types are not serializable anymore and some of them have been moved to separate NuGet packages anyway, but the class in the .NET Framework is still vulnerable against such attacks. When using the flag, the is protected against the known security issues on all platforms but of course it cannot guard you against every potentially harmful type if you explicitly specify them as expected types in the deserialization methods.

Please also note that the infrastructure has other security flaws as well but some of these can be reduced by the serializable types themselves. Most serializable types do not validate the incoming data. All serializable types that can have an invalid state regarding the field values should implement and should throw a from their serialization constructor if validation fails. The wraps every other exception thrown by the constructor into a . Not even the core .NET types have such validation, which is one reason why this library supports so many types natively. And for custom types see the example at the Example: How to implement a custom serializable type section.

Starting with version 8.0.0 in safe mode the property can only be or a instance if you set its to . Furthermore, in safe mode it is not allowed to set any surrogate selectors in the property. Please note that this library also contains a sort of serialization binders and surrogates, most of them have their own SafeMode property (e.g. , or ), still, not even they are allowed to be used when the option is enabled. It's because their safe mode just provide some not too strict general protection, instead of being able to filter a specific set of predefined types.
If you must disable for some reason, then use binary serialization in-process only, or apply some cryptographically secure encryption to the serialization stream.

remarks.para: aims to serialize objects effectively where the serialized data is almost always more compact than the results produced by the class.
natively supports all the primitive types and a sort of other simple types, arrays, generic and non-generic collections.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo
member.summary: Static descriptor for collection types. Instance-specific descriptor is in .

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.ctorCache
member.summary: Can contain more elements only for generic collections. Will be instantiated only on deserialization. Thread safe accessor because the serialization info is stored in a static shared dictionary.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.CtorArguments
member.summary: Specifies the constructor arguments to be used. Order matters! Can be used also to specify the arguments for .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.GetSpecificAddMethod
member.summary: Should be specified only when target collection is not , or implementation, or when defining it results faster access than resolving the generic Add method for each access. It can also be used for special cases, such as inserting the final resolved items into an ordered dictionary whereas in normal case the members are used.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.GetBackingArray
member.summary: Should be specified if the collection is a value type, and it has a publicly exposed backing array that can have more elements than the wrapper type (e.g. ArraySegment), or, if it does not expose or wrap any array, but it can be represented as a (fixed size) array (e.g. Vector128). If the collection does not actually wrap the array, then it must not contain any direct circular reference to the object itself because it makes proper deserialization impossible (e.g. object element type must not be supported by the collection)

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.WriteSpecificPropertiesCallback
member.summary: Should be specified for any custom data for array backed collections. Can be specified also for collections, in which case has to be specified, too. If the object represents an array backed collection that has no constructor from array, then should also be specified.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.RestoreSpecificPropertiesCallback
member.summary: Can be used to restore properties that were saved by . Should be used for read-write properties that can be set after creating the collection. A possible value type result must not be unboxed.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.CreateArrayBackedCollectionInstanceFromArray
member.summary: Should be specified to instantiate an array backed collection. Should also read specific properties written by .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.CreateInstanceCallback
member.summary: Gets a delegate that can instantiate the (possibly proxy) collection instance to populate. The parameters depend on . If this is not the final instance the should be also set.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.CreateFinalCollectionCallback
member.summary: If returns a proxy type, then this delegate can return the final result from the builder collection. NOTE: Using this property may prevent deserialization of circular references.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.ReferenceAbstractGenericType
member.summary: Should be set if the supported public type is an abstract generic type, and we need to support its non-public derived instances (e.g. comparers, frozen collections). Required only for generic types if the possible derived instances may have different type arguments (if any).

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionSerializationInfo.WriteSpecificProperties(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Collections.IEnumerable,KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager)
member.summary: Writes specific properties of a collection that are needed for deserialization
member.returns: true if the whole write is finished (e.g. default instance); otherwise, false

member.summary: Creates collection and reads all serialized specific properties that were written by .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DataTypes
member.summary: Represents possible types. One of the simple types can be combined with one of the collection types and the flags. Nested generic collections can be encoded by multiple consecutive values.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo
member.summary: Special serialization info for collections

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasCapacity
member.summary: Indicates that the collection has a Capacity property that has to be (re)stored. If this flag is disabled but there is a constructor with capacity parameter, then the size (Count) will be used at constructor

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasEqualityComparer
member.summary: Indicates that the collection has an EqualityComparer that can be passed to a constructor

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasComparer
member.summary: Indicates that the collection has a Comparer that can be passed to a constructor

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsDictionary
member.summary: Indicates that the collection is a dictionary.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsGeneric
member.summary: Should be enabled for generic types to process embedded non-simple elements.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.ReverseElements
member.summary: Should be set for stack-like collections

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasCaseInsensitivity
member.summary: Only in HybridDictionary

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasReadOnly
member.summary: For types that can be both read-only and read-write (only in non-generic OrderedDictionary)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsSingleElement
member.summary: Indicates that the "collection" is a single element (now for StrongBox, DictionaryEntry, KeyValuePair: special "collections" with exactly one (pair of) elements, whose type arguments are easy to encode along with collection types)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.UsesComparerHelper
member.summary: Indicates that the default comparer is determined by . The result can be different for enums on different platforms.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.NonNullDefaultComparer
member.summary: Indicates that even default comparer cannot be null (only for ConcurrentDictionary in .NET Framework)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsBackingArrayActuallyStored
member.summary: Indicates that the backing array is an actually wrapped reference, so it is stored in the id cache and can be even null (e.g. ArraySegment).

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.BackingArrayHasKnownSize
member.summary: Indicates that the backing array has a known size (e.g. Vector*)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsTuple
member.summary: Indicates that the collection is a tuple

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasBitwiseAndHash
member.summary: Indicates that the collection has a bool field that tells whether the collection uses bitwise AND hash (ThreadSafeHashSet/ThreadSafeDictionary)

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasStringSegmentComparer
member.summary: Indicates that the collection has a StringSegmentComparer that can be passed to the constructor

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasStringItemsOrKeys
member.summary: Indicates that the non-generic collection has string items or keys-values, or that a generic dictionary with only one generic argument has string keys.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.CreateResultFromByteArray
member.summary: Indicates that the backing array is always a byte array, regardless of the actual element type.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.HasValueComparer
member.summary: Indicates that the dictionary has an additional EqualityComparer for TValue that can be passed to a constructor or factory method

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsComparer
member.summary: Indicates that the generic type is a known comparer rather than an actual collection, thus it has no actual elements, it's just it can be encoded like a collection.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsOrdered
member.summary: Indicates that the collection is ordered. As lists are naturally ordered, this is needed for ordered dictionaries only.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionInfo.IsMemory
member.summary: Indicates that the collection is a [ReadOnly]Memory struct.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.CollectionCtorArguments
member.summary: Possible arguments of a collection constructor or factory method

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.TypeAttributes
T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.ComparerType
member.summary: Gets the possibly known singleton identity of a comparer. Used for non-generic comparers whose instances can be either singletons or regular instances to be serialized.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.Compressible`1
member.summary: A wrapper type for 7-bit encoded types if they are encoded by index rather than DataTypes.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.GenericMethodDefinitionPlaceholder
member.summary: An indicator type for generic method parameters.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.primitiveTypes
member.summary: Types that cannot be serialized recursively even by a surrogate, including string and void

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.supportedNonPrimitiveElementTypes
member.summary: Natively supported non-primitive simple types.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.supportedCollections
member.summary: Supported collection types, including some types that are not collections but their elements can be encoded similar to collections.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.Options
member.summary:
Options used for serialization and deserialization.
See the enumeration for details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.Binder
member.summary: Gets or sets the that performs type conversions to and from string.

remarks.para: By default, the binder is not called for natively supported types.
If the flag is set in , then the binder is called for the non-primitive natively supported types.

This formatter does not call the binder types that have element types, for constructed generic types and generic parameter types. Instead, the binder is called only for the element types, the generic type definition and the generic arguments separately.
remarks.note: In .NET Framework 3.5 setting this property has no effect during serialization unless the binder implements the interface.

If you serialize forwarded types that have no defined forwarding by the and attributes, then to ensure emitting compatible assembly identities on different .NET platforms use the , define the missing mappings by the AddType method and set its property to . Alternatively, you can use the or you can just serialize the object without assembly information by setting the flag in the .

note.para: If the flag is set in the property, then it is not allowed to use any binders other than the with its enabled.
See the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.Context
member.summary: Gets or sets the used for serialization and deserialization.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SurrogateSelector
member.summary: Gets or sets an can be used to customize serialization and deserialization.

note.para: If the flag is set in the property, then it is not allowed to use any surrogate selectors.
See the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.Deserialize``1(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Type[])
member.summary: Deserializes the specified part of a byte array into an instance of .
member.typeparam: The expected type of the result.
member.param: Contains the raw data representation of the object to deserialize.
Points to the starting position of the object data in .
The types that are expected to present in by name. If is not enabled in or does not contain any types by name, then this parameter is optional.
member.returns: The deserialized instance of .

remarks.para: must be specified if is enabled in and contains types encoded by their names. Natively supported types are not needed to be included unless the original object was serialized with the option enabled.
is allowed to be an interface or abstract type but if it's different from the actual type of the result, then the actual type also might needed to be included in .

You can specify even if is not enabled in as it may improve the performance of type resolving and can help avoiding possible ambiguities if types were not serialized with full assembly identity (e.g. if was enabled on serialization).

If a type in has a different assembly identity in the deserialization stream, and it is not indicated by a declared on the type, then you should set the property to a instance to specify the expected types.

For arrays it is enough to specify the element type and for generic types you can specify the natively not supported generic type definition and generic type arguments separately. If contains constructed generic types, then the generic type definition and the type arguments will be treated as expected types in any combination.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DeserializationManager.ReadObject(System.IO.BinaryReader,System.Nullable{System.Boolean},KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DataTypeDescriptor)
member.summary: Reads a non-collection object from the stream.
member.param: The reader

When , the result must be added to the ID cache. Otherwise, only reference types in a collection might be added to cache. False: Root level objects except recursive object graphs; Value type fields or collection elements On non-root level this parameter is for every reference type (including boxed value types); only for non-root value element types. Can be null for collection element types in which case will be evaluated lazily: will be false for value element types.
The descriptor of the data type to be deserialized.
member.returns: The deserialized object.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager
member.summary: A manager class that provides that stored types will be built up in the same order both at serialization and deserialization for complex types.

members.member: The entry point of writing an object. Here the type is encoded by DataTypes. The basic philosophy is that we write type index everywhere else (which will be at least 1 byte longer for supported types for the first time). (Impure objects are written by index at root level, too.) >
Writing a child object. Here the type is encoded by index. is the possible element type of a parent collection. We don't do the same for parent fields because we don't write the field types at all. >

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.GetDataType(System.Type)
member.summary: Gets the representation of .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.WriteTypeNamesAndRanks(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Type,KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DataTypesEnumerator,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Writes additional info after a [series of] DataType stream needed to completely describe an exact type.

member.summary: Encodes the type as a series of elements.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.WriteType(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Type,KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DataTypesEnumerator,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Writes a type into the serialization stream by using assembly and type index. If there is no name override from Binder it can use a special index to fallback to encoding. can be only when a RuntimeType instance is serialized.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.TryWriteTypeByDataType(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Type,System.Boolean,KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DataTypesEnumerator)
member.summary: Trying to write type completely or partially by pure . Returning even for partial success (array, generics) because then the beginning of the type is encoded by DataTypes.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.WriteNewType(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Type,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes a new non-pure type if a binder did not handle it. Assembly part is already written. If open types are allowed a generic type definition is followed by a specifier; otherwise, by type arguments.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.WriteTypeWithName(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Type,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Writes the type using explicit names. Occurs when changes the type to an unknown one. The Binder is not queried this time because there is no known type to query. Instead, we handle the names as bound type names.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.WriteId(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Object)
member.summary: Writes an ID and returns if it was already known.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManager.MarkAttributes(System.IO.BinaryWriter,System.Type,KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.DataTypes)
member.summary: Marks the type attributes in the stream. This ensures a successful deserialization even if a type changed its sealed or class/struct attributes.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManagerBase.KnownTypes
member.summary: These types are always dumped by index and are never passed to a binder.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationFormatter.SerializationManagerBase.SpecialSupportCache
member.summary: A cache for types that have special support on the current platform and it has some cost to determine this. The result is if the type is ignored or the special support is disabled for it so it must be determined by the regular ways if it can be serialized.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializer.Deserialize``1(System.Byte[],System.Int32,KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationOptions,System.Type[])
member.summary: Deserializes the specified part of a byte array into an instance of .
member.typeparam: The expected type of the result.
member.param: Contains the raw data representation of the object to deserialize.
Points to the starting position of the object data in .
Options of the deserialization.
The types that are expected to present in by name. If is not enabled in or does not contain any types by name, then this parameter is optional.
member.returns: The deserialized instance of .

remarks.para: must be specified if is enabled in and contains types encoded by their names. Natively supported types are not needed to be included unless the original object was serialized with the option enabled.
is allowed to be an interface or abstract type but if it's different from the actual type of the result, then the actual type also might needed to be included in .

You can specify even if is not enabled in as it may improve the performance of type resolving and can help avoiding possible ambiguities if types were not serialized with full assembly identity (e.g. if was enabled on serialization).

If a type in has a different assembly identity in the deserialization stream, and it is not indicated by a declared on the type, then you should instantiate a class manually and set its property to a instance to specify the expected types.

For arrays it is enough to specify the element type and for generic types you can specify the natively not supported generic type definition and generic type arguments separately. If contains constructed generic types, then the generic type definition and the type arguments will be treated as expected types in any combination.
remarks.note: If is a custom type using default recursive serialization, and it contains further custom types you can use the ExtractExpectedTypes overloads to auto-detect the expected types.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializer.SerializeValueType(System.ValueType)
member.summary: Serializes a into a byte array. If the type of the specified instance contains any references, then it is tried to be serialized by marshaling as a fallback option.
member.param: The object to serialize.
member.returns: The byte array representation of the object.

remarks.para: If the specified instance does not have any references, then its actual raw data is returned. In this case this method is very fast.

If the specified instance has reference types, then as a fallback option, it is attempted to be serialized by using the class. To work properly the string and array fields must be decorated by the using or values, and the must be defined on referenced classes. The annotations are ignored if the type does not contain any references and hence it is serialized by its actual raw content. Serializing by the class as a fallback option is maintained only for compatibility reasons. If a value type contains references, then it is recommended to use the Serialize method instead. You can use the method to serialize only pure value types without any references.
If the instance cannot be serialized even by the class, then an is thrown.
remarks.note: If packing is not defined on the type of the instance by StructLayoutAttribute.Pack, or the type contains pointer fields, then the length of the result might be different on 32 and 64 bit systems. The serialized content depends also on the endianness of the executing architecture.

member.exception: is .
contains references and it cannot be serialized even by the class.
The method is called from a restricted with insufficient permissions.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializer.TrySerializeValueType(System.ValueType,System.Byte[]@)
member.summary:
Tries to serialize a into a byte array. The operation will succeed if the type of the specified instance does not contain any references.
See also the Remarks section of the method for details.
member.param: The object to serialize.
When this method returns, the byte array representation of the instance. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializer.ExtractExpectedTypes``1(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Extracts a flattened collection of expected types from for deserialization. Can be useful for deserialization methods in safe mode when is a custom type directly referencing other custom types using default serialization.
member.typeparam: The root custom type that may reference further custom types.
member.param:
to extract all types, even if may not necessary or helpful; otherwise, . This parameter is optional.
Default value: .
member.returns: A collection of types extracted from .

remarks.para: This method can be useful for Deserialize, DeserializeFromStream and DeserializeByReader methods when is enabled and the root type to deserialize is not supported natively but uses default serialization and wraps other custom types directly.

list.item: Please note that this method may not able to detect every type if the types of the serialized fields are interfaces or non-sealed classes and the serialization stream contains implementations or derived types of them. In such cases you may need to append further types to the result before passing it to the deserialization methods.

Please also note that if or some of its nested types use custom serialization (ie. implement or ), then their fields are not checked recursively by default, because they are not serialized by fields, and it's impossible to tell what types should be included in the result. You can force to extract their types by passing to the parameter though.

remarks.para: If is , then natively supported types, as well as fields of and implementations and non-serializable types will not be included in the result. Fields annotated by the will also be skipped.

Passing to can be helpful to include the fields of non-serializable types (when was enabled on serialization), the fields of types (see ), the fields of types (see ), and also natively supported types (see ).
When is enabled on serialization, this method may unnecessarily return the referenced custom types of unmanaged structs.
remarks.note: The result of this method is not cached. If performance matters either do the caching explicitly or try to manually enlist the expected types instead.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.CustomSerializationBinder
member.summary: Provides a very simple customizable that can convert to and from string by using assignable delegate properties.

remarks.para: When serializing, you can assign the and properties to customize the assembly and type names of a to be written into the serialization stream.
When deserializing, you can assign the properties to return a type from an assembly-type name pair.
If the properties above are not assigned or when they return , then the consumer instance will use its internal resolve logic.

note.para: If is not assigned or can return , then the consumer instance may load assemblies during the deserialization. If the deserialization stream is not from a trusted source, then you should never return from the assigned delegate of the property. Instead, throw an exception if a type could not be resolved.
See the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

example.note: If the inner structure of the type has also been changed, then you can use the class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.CustomSerializerSurrogateSelector
member.summary:
An implementation that makes possible to serialize and deserialize any objects, including non-serializable ones by an such as or the legacy .
When targeting .NET 8 or later this class is marked as obsolete.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.

note.para: See also the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

remarks.para: By using the you can serialize and deserialize any types. The is also able to serialize non-serializable types by itself by using the option. But the provides more control and can be used also for other formatters. Please note though that you cannot use this class for when the flag is enabled in its property, even if the property is set to .

example.h2: Solving compatibility issues between different platforms
example.note: Some types that are serializable in .NET Framework are not serializable in .NET Core/.NET Standard. This class can be a solution also for this problem. However, the solution is not always as simple as assigning a instance to the property. See some cases and their solution in the list below.

item.description:
In .NET Core there are several types that still implement , though their ISerializable.GetObjectData method throws a (e.g. , and in .NET Core 2.0). On the other hand, in .NET Core 3.0 is serializable again, remained the same and from the implementation has also been removed along with the . For such cases there are more possible solutions:
In best cases it is enough to use the both for serializing and deserializing without any surrogate selector. It natively supports instances on all platforms.
When serializing by you can set the property to force serializing the object by fields. If the fields are the same on the deserializing side, then the object will be deserializable by using the on both sides with the same settings.
If fields have also changed you can customize the serializing and deserializing process by handling the events (see below).

The Basic case might not work the other way around: serializing an object in .NET Core might not be deserializable in .NET Framework, for example. It can be avoided if:
You use instead of . It supports many types natively, including many core collections and simple types. These types are always encoded in a platform-independent way, which is also very compact.
You can serialize the types using the with setting the property to to use assembly identities of the .NET Framework for most public types. These types can be resolved on all platforms. This solution works even with .
Alternatively, you can use the with the , or the (works also with ) to allow to omit assembly identities in the serialized stream. Such a stream can be deserialized if all the assemblies that contain the types to be deserialized are already loaded and the full names of the types are unambiguous in the loaded assemblies.

example.note: Some of the solutions above are more workarounds for situations arose rather than recommended practices. If it is known that a type will be deserialized in another environment and it can be completely restored by its public members, then a text-based serialization (see also ) can be a better choice.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.ForwardedTypesSerializationBinder
member.summary:
Provides a that makes possible to serialize and deserialize types with custom assembly identity.
See the online help for examples.

note.para: If a deserialization stream may come from an untrusted source, then make sure to set the property to to prevent loading assemblies and resolving any types but the explicitly specified ones.
See the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

remarks.para: Without specifying any expected types the does nothing special. Resolving types from legacy assemblies works automatically if at least a chunk version of the assembly exists on the current platform containing nothing but a bunch of attributes (this is the case for the original .NET Framework assemblies on .NET Core and .NET Standard).

To resolve types that are not forwarded by the from an existing assembly with the given identity you can use this binder for deserialization. Add the types to be handled by the AddType or AddTypes methods.

If is set to , then mapping works also on serialization. For types without an explicitly set mapping the value of the attribute will be written if it is defined. By default, both and dumps legacy identities on serialization for types decorated by the . If you use this binder on serialization without adding any type just after setting the to , then the only difference will be that even the mscorlib assembly name will be dumped to the output stream, which would be omitted otherwise.

To serialize types with arbitrary assembly identity, use this binder both for serialization and deserialization. Add the type to be handled by the AddType method and specify at least one for each added .

example.note: The is also able to ignore assembly information but if there are two different types of the same name in the same namespace, then the behavior of is not deterministic.
If not only the assembly name but also the inner content of a type (ie. field names) changed, then you can use the class.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.ForwardedTypesSerializationBinder.mapping
member.summary: Key: Type.FullName for root types. Value.Key: Different types of the same full name Value.Value: AssemblyName.FullName, or empty string, if any assemblies are allowed. Not AssemblyNames because they have no overridden Equals.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.ForwardedTypesSerializationBinder.WriteLegacyIdentity
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether a legacy assembly identity is tried to be written on serializing.
Default value: .

remarks.note: In Framework .NET 3.5 and most implementations ignore the value of this property. is able to use the as an implementation and consider the value of this property even in .NET 3.5.
remarks.para: If the value of this property is , then on serialization a legacy identity is tried to be written for the serialized type. That is, the first that was specified for the type by the AddType method, or the value of the TypeForwardedFromAttribute.AssemblyFullName property if it is specified for the type.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.ForwardedTypesSerializationBinder.SafeMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether all of the type names that occur in the serialization stream must have a defined mapping to a type.
Default value: .

remarks.para: If is , and there is no rule specified for a type, then a will be thrown when BindToType is called.
If is , then BindToType is allowed to resolve the type automatically and can even load assemblies during the deserialization.
To prevent the consumer from loading assemblies the BindToType method never returns ; instead, it throws a if a type could not be resolved.
remarks.note: See also the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

member.summary: Adds the to this binder. If no are defined, then any with the same full name will be resolved to ; otherwise, only the ones, whose identities match.
member.param: The type to be added to the handled types by this binder.
The legacy assembly identities to be recognized. Can contain also partial names. If empty or contains a element, then any type of the same full name will be resolved to .

remarks.para: If no assembly identities are specified, then any that has the same full name as , will be resolved to the specified .
If at least one assembly identity is specified and is , then on serialization the first specified name will be returned as the assembly name of the .
For generic types you should specify the generic type definition only.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.ForwardedTypesSerializationBinder.AddTypes(System.Type[])
member.summary: Adds the to this binder without any specific assembly identity. Each that have the same full name as one of the given types, will be able to be resolved from any assembly.
member.param: The types to be added to the handled types by this binder.

remarks.para: To resolve types from specific assemblies only use the AddType method.
If is , then on serialization a legacy assembly name will be used only for those types, which are decorated by the attribute.
For generic types it is enough to specify the generic type definition only.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.ForwardedTypesSerializationBinder.BindToName(System.Type,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: When is , then tries to return a legacy assembly identity for the specified .
member.param: The type of the object that is being serialized.

If is , then tries to return an old assembly identity for . If at least one was specified for the type by the AddType method, then the firstly specified name will be used. Otherwise, if the type has a is specified for the type, its value will be used. Otherwise, returns so the formatter will emit a default identity.
If is not when this method returns, then contains the full name of the , otherwise, returns .

remarks.note: In .NET Framework 3.5 this method does not exist in the base and is called only if the consumer serializer handles the interface or calls it directly.

Specifies the name of the serialized object.
