member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.NameInvariantSurrogateSelector
member.summary: An implementation that makes possible to serialize and deserialize objects by s without storing field names. This provides compatibility for obfuscated and non-obfuscated versions of an assembly.

note.para: If you deserialize a stream from an untrusted source make sure that you set the property, which prevents supporting non-serializable types. Please note though that you cannot use this class for when the flag is enabled in its property, even if the property is set to .
See also the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

remarks.para: You can use this surrogate selector for any non-primitive types that do not implement interface.
remarks.note: Versioning by this surrogate selector can be accomplished only if new fields are always defined after the old ones on every level of the hierarchy. You might want to use also the class to ignore version information of assemblies on deserialization.
Please note that this surrogate selector does not identify field names on deserialization so reordering members may corrupt or fail deserialization.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.WeakAssemblySerializationBinder
member.summary: Provides a instance for implementations that can ignore version and token information of stored assembly name. This makes possible to deserialize objects stored in different version of the original assembly. It also can make any safe in terms of prohibiting loading assemblies during the deserialization if the property is .

note.para: If a deserialization stream may come from an untrusted source, then make sure to set the property to to prevent loading assemblies when resolving types. Please note though that you cannot use this class for when the flag is enabled in its property, even if the property is set to .
See the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

remarks.note: This binder does not use exact type mapping just tries to resolve type information automatically. To customize type mapping or use a custom resolve logic you can use the or classes, respectively.
remarks.para: The class allows resolving type information by weak assembly identity, or by completely ignoring assembly information (if property is .)
It also makes possible to prevent loading assembles during deserialization if the property is .
If is used on serialization, then it can omit assembly information from the serialization stream if the property is .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.WeakAssemblySerializationBinder.OmitAssemblyNameOnSerialize
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether assembly name should be completely omitted on serialization.
Default value: .
member.value: to omit assembly name on serialize; otherwise, .

remarks.note: In .NET Framework 3.5 and most implementations ignore the value of this property. is able to use the as an implementation and consider the value of this property even in .NET 3.5.

The value of this property is used only on serialization; however, it affects deserialization as well: when assembly name is omitted, deserialization will find the first matching type from any assembly.
remarks.para: Using with option enabled has a similar effect. However, using with this property set to , assembly names can be omitted even when using or other implementations.

When the value of this property is , the serialized stream will be shorter; however, deserialization might be slower, and type will be searched only in already loaded assemblies. When multiple assemblies have types with the same name the retrieved type cannot determined.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.WeakAssemblySerializationBinder.IgnoreAssemblyNameOnResolve
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether an existing assembly name is allowed to be completely ignored on deserialization.
Default value: .

remarks.para: If the value of this property is and the type cannot be resolved from an assembly on deserialization, then the type is tried to be resolved from any loaded assemblies. The effect is similar as if the property was used on serialization, except that the type is tried to be resolved from the provided assembly in the first place.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.WeakAssemblySerializationBinder.SafeMode
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether loading assemblies is prohibited on deserialization.
Default value: .

remarks.para: If is , then no assembly loading will occur on deserialization.
If is , then BindToType may load assemblies during the deserialization.
To prevent the consumer from loading assemblies the BindToType method never returns ; instead, it throws a if a type could not be resolved.
remarks.note: See also the security notes at the Remarks section of the class for more details.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.WeakAssemblySerializationBinder.BindToName(System.Type,System.String@,System.String@)
member.summary: When is , suppresses the assembly name on serialization. Otherwise, returns for both assembly and type names, indicating that the original names should be used.
member.param: The type of the object that is being serialized.
If is , then returns * to indicate an omitted assembly; otherwise, returns .
If is , then returns the full name of the type without assembly information; otherwise, returns .

member.summary: Options for serialization methods in and classes.

member.name: F:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.BinarySerializationOptions.None
member.summary: All options are disabled.

summary.para: Apart from primitive types, strings and arrays forces to serialize every type recursively. If is set, then the surrogate selectors will be tried to used even for the supported types (as if was also enabled). Even if this flag is enabled, non-serializable types will not be serialized automatically. Use the to enable serialization of such types.
This flag is considered on serialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled

This option makes possible to serialize s () that are not marked by .
Using this flag allows serializing value types with reference (non-value type) fields by marshaling. Deserializing such value may fail if the flag if enabled. To be able to serialize string and array reference fields they must be decorated by using or , respectively.
summary.note: This option is obsolete. Use the flag instead.
summary.para: This flag is considered on serialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
Makes possible to serialize any non-natively supported types if they are not marked by .

This flag is considered on serialization. Though this flag makes possible to serialize non-serializable types, deserializing such stream will not work when the flag is enabled (unless the option is also set).
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
If a type has methods decorated by , , or , or the type implements , then these methods are called during the process. By setting this flag these methods can be ignored.
This flag is considered both on serialization and deserialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
This flag ignores implementations.
This flag is considered on serialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled

If enabled, type references will be stored without assembly identification. This can make possible to restore a type even if the version of the assembly has been modified since last serialization while makes serialized data more compact; however, it cannot be guaranteed that the correct type will be even found on deserialization without specifying the expected types. If there are types with the same name in the same namespace in different assemblies, then by using this flag, these types cannot be distinguished. If the expected types are not specified on deserialization, then any of the types with identical full names might be picked. If you want to deserialize a type that was stored with strong assembly identity (without this flag) from a different version of an assembly, then use the or classes instead (the latter cannot be used in ).
This flag is considered on serialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled

This option makes possible to deserialize an object, which has been changed since last serialization. When this option is enabled, names of the base classes, and fields that have been serialized but have been since then removed, will be ignored. When this flag is enabled, an erroneous deserialization may silently succeed. When a field has been renamed or relocated into another base class, use an implementation to apply mappings instead (but note that surrogate selectors cannot be used in safe mode).
This flag is considered on deserialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
When this flag is enabled, every type will be serialized with its actual assembly identity rather than considering the value of an existing .
This flag is ignored if is enabled.
This flag is considered on serialization. Enabling this flag may cause that the type will not be able to be deserialized on a different platform, or at least not without using a .
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
This flag ignores implementations for natively not supported types, forcing to serialize a default object graph (unless an applicable surrogate selector is defined).
This flag is considered both on serialization and deserialization. Usually this flag must have the same value at serialization and deserialization; otherwise, the deserialization may fail.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
This flag ignores implementations. Using this flag may cause that the deserialized object or its elements will have the wrong type, or the deserialization will fail.
This flag is considered on deserialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled
If a () contains no references, then by enabling this option the instance will be serialized in a compact way form if possible.
This flag is considered on serialization.
summary.note: Note: This option has higher priority than flag, except for natively supported structures. This option affects only instances that have no references at all.
summary.para: Default state at serialization methods in : Enabled
If this flag is enabled while is set, then the selector is tried to be used even for natively supported types.
This flag is considered on serialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled

If this flag is enabled, then it is ensured that no assembly loading is allowed during deserialization. All of the assemblies that are referred by the serialization stream must be preloaded before starting the deserialization. Non-natively supported types, whose assembly qualified names are stored in the serialization stream must be explicitly declared as expected types in the deserialization methods, including s.

Additionally, safe mode ensures that during the deserialization natively supported collections are allocated with limited capacity to prevent possible attacks that can cause . Deserializing an invalid stream still may cause to throw a .
It also disallows deserializing the natively not supported non-serializable types, though this can be relaxed by enabling the flag.
summary.note: In safe mode no version mismatch is tolerated even for system assemblies. If you want to deserialize a stream in safe mode that contains different assembly identities from the loaded ones, then use , and set its property to .
In safe mode it is not allowed to set the or properties (except for using the when its is set to ) because they could be used to weaken the security actions described above.
summary.para: This flag is considered on deserialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Enabled
Indicates that recursively serialized types that are indicated as expected types at the deserialization methods should be able to be deserialized in even if they are not marked by the .
This flag is considered on deserialization.
Default state at serialization methods in : Disabled

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Binary.IBinarySerializable
member.summary:
Makes possible quick and compact custom serialization of a class by and .
See the online help for examples.

remarks.para: By this interface a class can be serialized into a compact byte array. Unlike in case of system serialization and implementations, saved data does not have to contain a name based mapping. Thus the saved content can be more compact but this solution can be discouraged on very large object graphs because the whole object has to be written into memory. In case of very large object hierarchies you might consider to implement interface instead, which is also supported by and .

Methods decorated by , , and as well as calling IDeserializationCallback.OnDeserialization method of implementers are fully supported also for implementers. Attributes should be used on methods that have a single parameter.

Without such constructor parameterless constructor will be called if any (otherwise, no constructors will be executed). The special constructor should be used if the class has read-only fields to be restored.
member.param: Serialized raw data of the object created by the Serialize method.
Options used for the deserialization.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Xml.XmlSerializer
member.summary:
makes possible serializing and deserializing objects into/from XML content. The class contains various overloads to support serializing directly into file or by , , any and any implementations.
See the online help for a more detailed description with examples.

remarks.note: The supports polymorphism and stores type information whenever the type of a member or collection element differs from the type of the member or collection element type. If the XML content to deserialize is from an untrusted source (e.g. remote service, file or database) make sure to use the DeserializeSafe or DeserializeContentSafe methods to prevent resolving any type names during the deserialization. They require to specify every natively not supported type that can occur in the serialized data whose names then will be mapped to the specified expected types.
remarks.para: supports serialization of any simple types and complex objects with their public properties and fields as well as several collection types. Unlike the System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer class, this is not designed for customizing output format (though implementations are considered). Not even Xml...Attributes are supported (except for the root element of implementations). Instead, this class is designed to support XML serialization of any type as long as they have a default constructor and their state can be fully restored by their public fields and properties.

Several System.ComponentModel techniques are supported, which also makes possible to use the for types that can be edited in a property grid, such as components, configurations or any types in a custom designer. The supported component model attributes and techniques:
Use value for public field or property to prevent its serialization and use value to explicitly express that the property value can be serialized recursively (see also ) option.
If the value of a public property or field equals to the value specified by this attribute, then its value will not be serialized (see also and options).
ShouldSerialize... methodsIf the type being serialized has an instance method with no parameters and a return type (can be private as well) named ShouldSerializeMemberName where MemberName is the name of a property or field, then its return value determines whether the member should be serialized. This technique is used in some designers and property grid controls (see also option).
This attribute is supported both for types and property/field members. If a supports serialization to and from type, then it will be used for serializing its value (see also the RegisterTypeConverter extension method).

Basically types with default constructors are supported. However, if a field or property value is not after creating its parent object and the type has no parameterless constructor, then the returned instance is tried to be re-used on deserialization. Objects without a default constructor can be serialized at root level also by the SerializeContent methods into an already existing node or by an , which already opened and XML element before calling the SerializeContent method. When deserializing, the result object should be created by the caller, and the content can be deserialized by the DeserializeContent methods.

example.para: By specifying the argument in the Serialize and SerializeContent methods you can override the default behavior of serialization. The option and the default options parameter value of the serialization methods ensure that only those types are serialized, which are guaranteed to be able to deserialized perfectly. For details see the description of the option.
If a type cannot be serialized with the currently used options a will be thrown.

You can use option to enable recursive serialization of every type of objects and collections. A collection type can be serialized if it implements the , or interfaces, and it can be deserialized if it has a default constructor, or an initializer constructor with a single parameter that can accept an or instance (non-dictionaries) or a instance (dictionary collections). Non-collection types must have a parameterless constructor to be able to be deserialized. Enabling the option does not guarantee that the deserialized instances will be the same as the original ones. The can only instantiate objects by using their default constructor and is able to set the public fields and properties. It can also create collections by special initializer constructors and can populate them by the standard interface implementations.

If option is enabled, then types without a native support and appropriate will be serialized into a binary stream, which will be stored in the result XML. Though this provides the best compatibility of any type, it hides the whole inner structure of the serialized object. If a root level object without native support is serialized by the Serialize methods using the option, then the whole XML result will be a single node with the binary content. The binary serialization is performed by the class. In safe mode deserialization the specified expected types must include the types present in the embedded binary stream(s) by name. To use binary serialization only for some types or properties you can specify the by the for a property, field or type but please note that it will always perform a safe deserialization specifying only the type of the element as expected type so you cannot use it if the corresponding type uses nested custom types that are not supported by the natively. You can use also the RegisterTypeConverter extension method to specify a type converter for types.
See the enumeration for further options.
The names of natively supported types are recognized during deserialization so they are not needed to be declared as expected custom types in safe mode.
When serializing, a wider range of types are supported without specifying any fallback options than the specified lists below. For the specific conditions see the description of the option.
When deserializing in safe mode, refer to the following couple of lists to see which types are recognized without specifying them as expected custom types.

Natively supported simple types:
, though the serialization/deserialization itself is performed by its type converter
types if type parameter is any of the supported types.
if and are any of the supported types.
(in .NET Framework 4.0 and above)
(in .NET Core 3.0 and above)

Natively supported collections:
(in .NET Framework 4.0 and above)

(in .NET 9.0 and above)
Please note that if a collection uses a custom or culture-aware comparer, some fallback option might be needed to be able to serialize it. will omit the custom comparers so it is not guaranteed that such a collection can be deserialized perfectly, whereas may successfully serialize also the comparer but for safe mode deserialization it may be needed to specify also the comparer as an expected custom type.

New features and improvements compared to System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer:
StringsIf a string contains only white spaces, then system cannot deserialize it properly. instances containing invalid UTF-16 code points cannot be serialized either. This implementation handles them correctly.
Collections with base element typeIf the element type of a collection is a base type or an interface, then the system serializer throws an exception for derived element types suggesting that should be defined for all possible derived types. Unfortunately this attribute is applicable only for possible types of properties/fields but not for collection elements. And in many cases it simply cannot be predefined in advance what derived types will be used at run-time.
Collections with read-only propertiesUsually collection properties can be read-only. But to be able to use the system serializer we need to define a setter for such properties; otherwise, serialization may fail. This does not require setter accessor for a collection property if the property is not after initialization and can be populated by using the usual collection interfaces.
Objects without default constructorsThe system serializer requires that the deserialized types have default constructors. On deserializing fields and properties, this implementation is able to use the returned value of the members. If they are not after creating their container object, then the returned instances can be reused instead of creating a new instance.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Serialization.Xml.XmlSerializationOptions
member.summary: Options for serializer methods of class.

summary.para: Represents no enabled options.

With every options disabled only those types are serialized, which are guaranteed to be able to deserialized perfectly. Such types are:
Natively supported typesPrimitive types along with their counterpart and the most common framework types. See the complete list of the natively supported types at the Remarks section of the class.
typesPlease note that in safe mode deserialization they must be specified as expected custom types.
instancesOnly if they are runtime types. And in safe mode deserialization the natively not supported types must be included in expected custom types.
instancesTypes that implement the interface can be serialized.
Types with If the converter supports serializing to and from type.
Simple objectsA type can be serialized with the default options if it meets the following criteria:
The type has a parameterless constructor, or is a value type
It has only public instance fields and properties. For properties, both accessors are public. Static members are ignored. Compiler-generated backing fields are ignored so types with public auto properties are considered simple.
All fields and properties can be set, or, all read-only fields and properties are either implementations or natively supported collections.
None of the fields and properties are delegates.
The type has no instance events.
A type can be serialized if these criteria are true for the serialized properties and fields recursively.
CollectionsArrays, a sort of known lists and dictionaries are supported natively as long as they use a supported comparer. See the complete list of the natively supported collections at the Remarks section of the class. To support other collections you can use fallback options, for example .

If enabled, collection elements and non binary-serialized complex objects will be identified by the assembly qualified type name; otherwise, only by full type name. Using fully qualified names makes possible to automatically load the assembly of a referenced type (unless safe mode is used on deserialization). Partial identity match is allowed, so type resolving tolerates assembly version change. When resolving non-fully qualified type names, their assembly must be loaded before the deserialization; otherwise, the type resolving will fail, even in non-safe mode.
summary.note: When using DeserializeSafe and DeserializeContentSafe methods, no assemblies will be loaded during the deserialization, even when types use fully qualified names.
summary.para: Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
If a type cannot be parsed natively and has no with support, then enabling this option makes possible to store its content in binary format (using the class) within the XML.

Though trusted collections and objects with only public read-write properties and fields can be serialized with the options as well, using this option will cause to serialize them in binary format, too.
If both and options are enabled, then binary serialization has higher priority, except for properties that are marked by visibility, which causes the property to be serialized recursively.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
summary.note: When using DeserializeSafe and DeserializeContentSafe methods, then types that occur in the binary serialization stream by name must be included in the specified expected custom types as well.

summary.para: If a type cannot be parsed natively, has no with support or binary serialization is disabled, then enabling this option makes possible to serialize the object by serializing its public properties, fields and collection items recursively. If a property or collection element cannot be serialized, then a will be thrown.

Properties can be marked by with value to indicate that they should be serialized recursively without using this fallback option. Enabling this option will not guarantee that deserialization of the object will be the same as the original instance. Use this option only when serialized types can be restored by setting public properties and fields, and the type has a default constructor. To avoid circular references use with value on back-referencing properties.
If both and options are enabled, then binary serialization has higher priority, except for properties that are marked by visibility, which causes the property to be serialized recursively.
Key and Value properties of and instances are always serialized recursively because those are natively supported types.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled

If a () has no and contains no references, then by enabling this option the instance will be serialized in a compact binary form. This option has higher priority than fallback options ( and ), except for and instances, which are always serialized recursively. This option affects only instances, which have no reference fields at all.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled

If enabled, then members without defined, will be treated as if they were decorated by with the default value of the property type ( for reference types and bitwise zero value of value types). This causes to skip serializing members, whose value equals to the default value of their type.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
Ignores the originally defined definitions for all of the properties. This causes that all members will be serialized regardless of their values.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
Ignores the presence of ShouldSerialize<PropertyName> methods for all of the members.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
If enabled, ignores implementations.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
If enabled, then array of primitive types are serialized in a single XML node instead of creating XML nodes for each element in the array.
Default state at serialization methods: Enabled

Unless a well configured is used, newline characters of string or char values can be lost or changed during deserialization. This flag ensures that newline characters can be always deserialized regardless of the used value of an .
Default state at serialization methods: Enabled
When this flag is enabled, binary contents will not be protected by a CRC value. Affects , and flags.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
By default includes public fields in serialization, similarly to System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer. By enabling this option, only public properties will be serialized.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled

By default, read-only properties and fields are serialized only if they are implementations or collections that can be populated. This option forces to serialize read-only fields and properties, as well as collections that are read-only and have no recognizable initializer constructor.
Public properties with a private setter accessor are serializable even without this option.
Read-only collections with recognizable collection initializer constructor are serializable even without this option. Enabling this option can make it possible that properties without setter accessor will not be able to deserialized. Deserialization will fail if the read-only property returns or its content cannot be restored (e.g. it has a simple type or is a read-only collection). Use this option only if an object has to be serialized only for information (e.g. logging) and deserialization is not necessary.
Default state at serialization methods: Disabled
When both and this flag are enabled, then every type will be serialized with its actual assembly identity rather than considering the value of an existing .
This flag is ignored if is disabled.
summary.note: Enabling this flag may cause that the type will not be able to be deserialized on a different platform.
summary.para: Default state at serialization methods: Disabled

Indicates that properties with return type should also be serialized, which are omitted without using this flag. It treats properties like regular read-only properties regarding collections (see the details at the option).
summary.note: As objects with return type are not considered trusted types it might be needed to combine this flag with the option.
summary.para: Default state at serialization methods: Disabled

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncConfigBase
member.summary:
Represents the base class for configuration of possibly asynchronous and multi-threaded operations.
See the Examples section of the class for details.

member.summary:
Gets or sets an instance that can handle progress notifications.
Default value: .
See the Examples section of the interface for an example implementation.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncConfigBase.MaxDegreeOfParallelism
member.summary:
Gets or sets the maximum degree of parallelism. Zero or less means an automatic configuration based on CPU cores. Set one to execute the operation on a single core. The asynchronous operation will not be blocking even if 1 is set.
Default value: 0.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncConfigBase.ThrowIfCanceled
member.summary:
Gets or sets whether an should be thrown when ending or awaiting a canceled async operation. If the value of this property is , then canceled non-void operations will return some value, which is usually the default value of their return type.
Default value: .

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncConfigBase.State
member.summary:
Gets or sets a user-provided object that will be returned by the property that can be used to distinguish this particular asynchronous operation from other ones. This object will be returned also in the IAsyncContext.State property created by the methods of the class.
Default value: .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncHelper
member.summary:
A helper class to implement CPU-bound operations with adjustable parallelization, cancellation and progress reporting, allowing a single shared implementation for both sync and async overloads where the latter can be either or (.NET Framework 4.0 and later) returning methods.
See the online help for an example.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncHelper.DefaultContext
member.summary:
Gets a default context for non-async operations that allows to set the number of threads automatically, does not support reporting progress, and is not cancellable.
See the Examples section of the class for details.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext
member.summary:
Gets a predefined context for non-async operations that forces to run a possibly parallel algorithm on a single thread, does not support reporting progress, and is not cancellable. It actually returns a instance.
See the Examples section of the class for details about using .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncHelper.EndOperation(System.IAsyncResult,System.String)
member.summary:
Waits for the completion of an operation started by a corresponding BeginOperation, FromResult or FromCompleted call. If the operation is still running, then this method blocks the caller and waits for the completion. The possibly occurred exceptions are also thrown then this method is called.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.ParallelHelper
member.summary: The class contains similar methods to the Parallel.For overloads in .NET Framework 4.0 and later but the ones in this class can be used even on .NET Framework 3.5, support reporting progress and have async overloads. Furthermore, it also contains several sorting methods that can sort instances in place using multiple threads.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.ParallelHelper.CoreCount
member.summary: Gets the number of processor cores available for the current process.

remarks.para: Then targeting .NET 6.0 or later this property returns the same value as the Environment.ProcessorCount property. On earlier .NET versions the Environment.ProcessorCount property may return an incorrect value on Windows, because it does not respect the configured processor affinity of the current process.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.ParallelHelper.For(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Action{System.Int32})
member.summary: Executes an indexed loop synchronously, in which iterations may run in parallel.
member.param: The start index, inclusive.
The end index, exclusive.
The delegate that is invoked once per iteration.

remarks.para: This method is functionally the same as Parallel.For(int, int, Action<int>) but it can be used even in .NET Framework 3.5.
If is greater than or equal to , then the method returns without performing any iterations.
This method has no return type because if there was no exception, then the loop is guaranteed to be completed.
remarks.note: This method adjusts the degree of parallelization automatically, blocks the caller, and does not support cancellation or reporting progress. Use the overload to adjust parallelization, set up cancellation, report progress; or the / (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods to do these asynchronously.

remarks.para: This method is similar to Parallel.For(int, int, ParallelOptions, Action<int>) but it can be used even in .NET Framework 3.5 and supports reporting progress.
If is greater than or equal to , then the method returns without performing any iterations.

If is not , is set in and there is at least one iteration, then the IAsyncProgress.New method will be called before the first iteration passing the specified to the operationType parameter. It will be followed by as many IAsyncProgress.Increment calls as many iterations were completed successfully.
remarks.note: This method blocks the caller until the iterations are completed. To perform the execution asynchronously use the BeginFor or ForAsync (in .NET Framework 4.0 and above) methods.

To reconfigure the degree of parallelism of an existing context, you can use the class.

This method is not a blocking call even if the property of the parameter is 1.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.SimpleContext
member.summary:
Represents a predefined simple context for non-async, possibly parallel operations where the maximum degree of parallelism can be specified, but cancellation and reporting progress is not supported. Can be used for methods with an parameter where we do not have an existing instance from a higher level operation, and we want to force the degree of parallelism. To force a single threaded execution you can use the predefined AsyncHelper.SingleThreadContext property.
See the Examples section of the class for details about .

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.SimpleContext.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified maximum degree of parallelism.
member.param: Specifies the maximum degree of parallelism. If zero or less, then it will be adjusted automatically.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
The namespace contains the static class that makes possible to implement sync and async versions of a possibly parallel operation supporting cancellation and reporting progress using a single shared implementation. One built-in example is the class, but you can find many examples in other dependent libraries such as the KGySoft.Drawing.Core package that uses many parallel operations for image processing. Apart from these you can find here the and some other types related to configuring or tracking asynchronous operations.
If you are looking for thread-safe collections such as the , then see the KGySoft.Collections namespace instead.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext
member.summary:
Represents the context of a possibly asynchronous operation.
See the Examples section of the class to see how to create sync and async methods (supporting both and return types) using the same shared implementation with an parameter.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext.MaxDegreeOfParallelism
member.summary: Gets the maximum degree of parallelism. If zero or less, then it is adjusted automatically.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext.IsCancellationRequested
member.summary: Gets whether the cancellation of the current operation has been requested.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext.CanBeCanceled
member.summary: Gets whether this operation can be canceled.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext.Progress
member.summary: Gets an instance that can be used to report progress, or if no progress reporter belongs to the current operation.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext.State
member.summary: Gets the user provided object that was configured in the property this instance was created from.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncContext.ThrowIfCancellationRequested
member.summary: Throws an if returns .

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncProgress
member.summary: Represents a progress updates provider for asynchronous operations. It provides methods for updating the progress from concurrent threads.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncProgress.Report``1(KGySoft.Threading.AsyncProgress{``0})
member.summary: Reports a progress update to any arbitrary state. For parallel operations it is recommended to use the Increment method after starting a new progress because this method cannot guarantee that will be a strictly increasing value when called from members, for example.
member.typeparam: The type of the property in the specified .
member.param: The value of the updated progress.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncProgress.New``1(``0,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates that a new progress session is started that consists of steps.
member.typeparam: The type of the parameter.
member.param: An instance of that describes the type of the new operation.

Specifies the possible maximum steps of the new operation (the Increment method is recommended to be called later on if a parallel processing does not know or may reorder the current step). 0 means an operation with no separate steps. This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.

Specifies the initial current value for the new progress. Should be between 0 and . This parameter is optional.
Default value: 0.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncProgress.Increment
member.summary: Indicates a progress update of a single step. Expected to be called after the New or Report methods if they were called with nonzero maximum steps. The implementation should not be sensitive for concurrency racing conditions.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncProgress.SetProgressValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates that the current progress is at a specific position.
member.param: The current progress value. Should not exceed the maximum value of the last New or Report calls and should not be sensitive for concurrency racing conditions.

member.name: M:KGySoft.Threading.IAsyncProgress.Complete
member.summary: Indicates that a progress value of the last New or Report method should be set to the maximum value. It is not required to be called at the end of each sessions so it just indicates that whatever progress has reached the last step.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncProgress`1
member.summary: Represents the progress of an operation that can be reported by an implementation.
member.typeparam: The type of the descriptor of the operation returned by the property.

member.summary: Gets information about the current operation in progress.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncProgress`1.MaximumValue
member.summary: Gets the maximum steps of this operation.

member.name: P:KGySoft.Threading.AsyncProgress`1.CurrentValue
member.summary: Gets the current step of this operation. Its value is between zero and , inclusive bounds.

member.name: T:KGySoft.Throw
member.summary: Helper class for throwing exceptions from performance-critical types. For example, a generic indexer can be 2.5x times faster if it contains no throw but a method call just because the presence of throw prevents inlining.
